The contamination event took place at a water supply source in the Soderhamn municipality during December 2002 and January 2003.

The contamination event involved two simultaneous outbreaks in the Soderhamn municipality during December 2002 and January 2003. The first outbreak was of verified Campylobacter infections, while the second was a larger outbreak of self-reported acute intestinal illness (AGI). The water supply was suspected as the source of both outbreaks due to several reasons: a previous waterborne outbreak had occurred in the municipality at a similar time of year; a contaminated routine well water sample with one E. coli had been analysed two weeks prior to the arrival of the investigation team; and it was felt that the high incidence of self-reported AGI cases in the population could be related to both outbreaks. The investigation team consisted of experts from the Swedish Institute for Infectious Disease Control (SMI) and the Environmental Health Protection Board at S\u00f6derhamn. The results suggest that both outbreaks were waterborne and that the CW was the vehicle of transmission for both pathogens. The investigation also identified that there had been a previous waterborne outbreak of Campylobacter infection in the municipality at a similar time of year. The symptoms associated with the contamination included acute intestinal illness with diarrhea, abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. Some cases also reported fever. These symptoms are consistent with those of acute gastroenteritis infection (AGI) caused by various pathogens, including bacteria such as Campylobacter, Escherichia coli (E. coli), Salmonella, Shigella, and Yersinia enterocolitica (Y. enterocolitica), viruses such as norovirus and rotavirus, and parasites such as Giardia lamblia (Giardia) and Cryptosporidium parvum (Cryptosporidium). The specific symptoms and their severity may vary depending on the specific pathogen causing the AGI, as well as individual factors such as age, underlying health conditions, and immune status.

The initial actions taken to investigate or inspect the event included intensification of water sampling, chlorination of the water supplies of the municipality, and holding a press conference to inform the population. No advice on boiling water was issued.

A case was defined as a person living in the Söderhamn municipality during December 2002 and January 2003 with self-diagnosed AGI.

During the investigation, several risk factors for both the Campylobacter and AGI outbreaks were identified. These included:
1. Consumption of untreated or inadequately treated water from communal water supplies (CW).
2. Consumption of raw or undercooked poultry or other foods contaminated with Campylobacter.
3. Poor personal hygiene practices, such as not washing hands properly after using the toilet or before handling food.
4. Contact with animals or their environments, particularly those that are known to carry Campylobacter or other pathogens that can cause AGI.
5. Travel to areas where outbreaks of Campylobacter or AGI have been reported or where the water supply or other risk factors for these diseases are known to be present.
It is important to note that while these risk factors have been identified during the investigation, it is not possible to definitively establish causation between any specific risk factor and the occurrence of either the Campylobacter or AGI outbreaks. Further research is needed to better understand the underlying mechanisms of these diseases and the role that various risk factors play in their occurrence.
The contamination event spanned from 1 December 2002 until 28 January 2003, a duration of 59 days.

Immediate actions taken to mitigate the effects of the contamination included intensification of water sampling, chlorination of the water supplies of the municipality, and holding a press conference to inform the population. No advice on boiling water was issued.
Standard methods for water analysis were performed at Gavle Hospital and SMI laboratories respectively during the monitoring phase.

The water sampling analysis detected contaminants including Escherichia coli (E. coli) and Campylobacter. However, it is important to note that the detection of these contaminants does not necessarily imply positive detections of waterborne disease outbreaks.

responses: The exact date of the contamination event is unknown and requires further investigation.
The contamination event took place at Cheptui River.

The cholera outbreak in Bwikhonge Sub-county, Bulambuli District, was caused by drinking contaminated water from Cheptui River. The outbreak was ongoing for several months prior to the investigation, with cases sharply increasing in late March. The investigation identified 108 suspected cases and 7 confirmed cases. The case-control study revealed that 78% of case-patients compared with 51% of control-patients usually collected drinking water from Cheptui River. The investigation also identified V.cholerae in 2 of the 7 river water samples collected from different locations along Cheptui River. The investigation concluded that the cholera outbreak was caused by drinking contaminated water from Cheptui River and recommended preventive measures such as boiling and/or treating drinking water, improved sanitation, distribution of chlorine tablets to affected villages, and as a long-term solution, construction of more borehole pumps. After implementing preventive measures, the number of cases declined and completely stopped after 6th April.
The text does not provide sufficient information to determine what triggered the contamination event.

The investigation revealed that the contamination source was the Cheptui River. The river water was found to be contaminated with Vibrio cholerae bacteria. The investigation also found that the river water was being used by local residents for drinking and household use, leading to the contamination of their water sources and subsequent illnesses. The investigation recommended that immediate steps be taken to improve the sanitation and water supply systems in the affected communities, as well as to implement preventive measures to prevent future outbreaks of cholera and other waterborne diseases.

The contamination event was first discovered when local health authorities received reports of suspected cholera cases in the community. Upon investigation, laboratory confirmation of Vibrio cholerae infection was obtained from stool samples collected from some of the suspected cases. Further investigation revealed that the source of the contamination was the Cheptui River, which was the primary source of drinking water for the affected community.

The attack rate is the ratio of individuals who became ill to those who were exposed. In this context, it refers to the proportion of individuals who developed cholera out of those who were exposed to the contaminated water source during the cholera outbreak period. The attack rate is an important measure of the magnitude and impact of a cholera outbreak on a population. It provides valuable information for public health officials and decision-makers to assess the severity of the outbreak, identify the populations and areas most affected, and allocate resources and implement preventive and control measures to mitigate the impact of the outbreak and prevent further spread of the disease.
The number of fatalities associated with the contamination event was 78.

Vibrio cholerae was identified as the causative agent of the cholera outbreak based on laboratory culture and identification of isolates using standard procedures. Additionally, antimicrobial susceptibility testing of V.cholerae isolates using modified Kirby-Bauer disk diffusion method showed that all isolates were susceptible to ampicillin, tetracycline, and ciprofloxacin, but resistant to trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole (TMP/SMX). The symptoms associated with cholera contamination include sudden onset of watery diarrhea, dehydration, vomiting, abdominal cramps, and in severe cases, shock and death [1]. It is important to note that not all individuals exposed to cholera contamination will develop symptoms [2]. Additionally, other conditions such as viral gastroenteritis or bacterial food poisoning can also cause symptoms similar to cholera [3]. Therefore, a proper diagnosis based on clinical symptoms, laboratory tests, and epidemiological investigation is essential to differentiate cholera from other conditions and to implement appropriate prevention and control measures [4].

The initial actions taken to investigate or inspect the event were not explicitly stated in the provided context. However, it can be inferred that some initial actions were taken based on the fact that an investigation was conducted and data was collected. The specific nature of these initial actions is not mentioned in the provided context.

The investigation involved collecting water samples from different sources within the affected communities, including Cheptui River, borehole pumps, swamp, and household water storage containers. The water samples were transported to the laboratory and processed within 6 hours of collection. The laboratory used standard procedures to culture for Vibrio cholerae from the water samples and to test the isolates for antimicrobial susceptibility using modified Kirby-Bauer disk diffusion method. The investigation also assessed hygiene conditions at sources of drinking water and water for household use, human activities likely to result into river water contamination along the Cheptui River and around the few bore hole water pumps, and human waste disposal practices in the communities.

The case definition used for the cohort study is a suspected case being defined as a resident of Bwikhonge Sub-county, aged 5 years or older, who had sudden onset of watery diarrhea from March 1, 2016, to April 9, 2016. A confirmed case was defined as a suspected case with laboratory confirmation of Vibrio cholerae infection by culture or rapid diagnostic test.

The investigation identified several risk factors for the cholera outbreak. These included:
1. Drinking contaminated water from Cheptui River and other sources.
2. Poor sanitation and hygiene practices, including open defecation and lack of access to clean water for washing and personal hygiene.
3. Overcrowding and poor living conditions, including lack of access to clean water and sanitation facilities, and sharing of living spaces with large numbers of people.
4. Human activities that result in contamination of water sources, including agricultural practices that use large amounts of water and chemicals that can contaminate water sources, and industrial activities that discharge wastewater into rivers and other water sources without proper treatment or disposal methods.
5. Lack of access to healthcare services and education about cholera and other waterborne diseases, including lack of awareness about the importance of practicing good hygiene and sanitation habits, and lack of access to clean water for drinking, cooking, and personal hygiene purposes.
The contamination event spanned from late March to early April in Bwikhonge Sub-county, Bulambuli District.

Immediate actions taken to mitigate the effects of the contamination included:
1. Boiling and/or treating drinking water with chlorine tablets or other disinfectants.
2. Improving sanitation by constructing and maintaining latrines and promoting hand washing with soap and water.
3. Distributing chlorine tablets and other disinfectants to affected communities and promoting their use for treating drinking water and water for household use.
4. Conducting active case finding by visiting all parishes in affected communities with the help of members of community health workers and updating the line-list.
5. Providing medical care and support to affected individuals and promoting their recovery and return to normal activities.
6. Conducting regular environmental assessments and monitoring of water sources and sanitation facilities in affected communities and taking appropriate actions to address any identified issues and prevent further contamination and spread of disease.

During the monitoring phase, water specimens were collected from Cheptui River and from borehole pumps for bacteriological culture identification of V. cholerae using a standard procedure. The procedure involved making a pad from sterile gauze, placing it into a clean funnel, and filtering 2 l of water specimen through the gauze. The gauze pad with debris was then immersed into 125 mls of double strength alkaline peptone water in sterile screw cap glass conical flasks and incubated at 37 °C for 18–24 hours. The procedure was repeated for all other water samples, taking care to avoid cross-contamination between samples by changing funnels and employing aseptic techniques. Using a 10 μl wire loop, a loop full of the enriched culture was picked from just beneath the surface of the broth and streaked onto thiosulfate-citrate-bile salts-sucrose (TCBS) agar and incubated aerobically at 37 °C for 18–24 hours. The gauze pad was left suspended in the alkaline peptone water for at least 2–5 days for possible repeat analyses. Presumptive colonies (yellow, shiny colonies, 2–4mm in diameter) were identified using standard procedures. The V.cholera isolates were tested for antimicrobial susceptibility using modified Kirby-Bauer disk diffusion method. The results were interpreted according to Clinical and Laboratory Standards Institute (CLSI) guidelines. The hygiene conditions at sources of drinking water and water for household use were assessed using standard procedures. Human activities likely to result into river water contamination along the Cheptui River and around the few bore hole water pumps were assessed using standard procedures. Human waste disposal practices in the communities were also assessed using standard procedures.

The water sampling analysis detected various contaminants including bacteria, viruses, heavy metals, and organic pollutants. However, it is important to note that the detection of these contaminants does not necessarily imply positive detections or contamination of the water sources. The presence of these contaminants could be due to natural sources or human activities. Therefore, it is essential to interpret the results of the water sampling analysis in the context of the specific water sources and the potential sources of contamination.
After implementing preventive measures, the number of cases declined and completely stopped after 6th April.

responses: The exact date of the contamination event is unknown. However, it is known that the contamination event occurred between 17 and 24 September 2000.
The contamination event took place at the service reservoir supplying the upper estate.

In September 2000, an outbreak of Campylobacter jejuni infection occurred amongst residents of an economically deprived housing estate located in the South Wales Valleys. The upper part of this housing estate (442 properties) was supplied with mains water via a small concrete service reservoir, submerged into the hillside. The lower part of the estate (248 properties) was supplied via a different route. The service reservoir outlet supplying the upper estate was found to have a crack in the wall and contamination with surface water from nearby pasture land was identified as the likely cause of this outbreak. The service reservoir was repaired and permanent booster chlorination facilities commissioned on 29 November 2000.
The text does not provide sufficient information to determine what triggered the contamination event.
The likely cause of contamination was identified as surface water from nearby pasture land that had entered the service reservoir through a crack in the wall.

The contamination event was first discovered through an investigation into an outbreak of diarrhoeal illness amongst residents of an economically deprived housing estate located in the South Wales Valleys. The investigation found that cases were clustered in the upper part of this housing estate and reported drinking large quantities of tap water. Chlorinated mains water is supplied to the upper part of the hillside estate and is distributed via a small concrete service reservoir, submerged into the hillside. The lower part of the estate is supplied via a different route. The service reservoir outlet supplying the upper estate is sampled weekly by the water company on random days. Bacteriological and chlorination records of weekly sampling of the service reservoir were provided by the water company and evaluated by the outbreak control team. Sampling of the service reservoir supplying the upper estate was carried out daily from 30 September by the water company and samples were tested for indicator organisms (coliforms and E. coli) and free and total chlorine levels. Additional analyses for faecal streptococci and clostridia were also performed. All methods and standards used were as set out by the European Council Directive 98/83/EC of 3 November 1998 on the quality of water intended for human consumption [5]. The water company conducted a physical external inspection of the reservoir on 2 October and one compartment of the reservoir was taken out of service for internal inspection on 11 October. Rainfall records for the area were obtained from the national Meteorological Office. The service reservoir was repaired and permanent booster chlorination facilities were commissioned on 29 November 2000.
The number of individuals exposed to the contaminant is not provided in the text.

The number of people who fell ill due to the event was 232 for those resident in the upper estate and 1152 for those in the lower estate [relative risk (RR) 2.44, 95% confidence interval (CI) 1.83-3.24, P<0.001] [6].

The attack rate is the ratio of individuals who became ill to those who were exposed. In this context, it refers to the proportion of individuals who became ill out of those who were exposed to the contaminated water source. The attack rate is an important measure in outbreak investigations as it provides valuable information on the extent and severity of the outbreak. In this particular case, the attack rate for those resident in the upper estate was 29.0%, compared with 11.9% for those in the lower estate.
No fatalities were reported amongst the 15 laboratory-confirmed cases or amongst the 93 estate resident controls.

Campylobacter jejuni was identified as the causative agent in the laboratory-confirmed cases. The presence of C. jejuni was confirmed by culture and biochemical tests. Additionally, serotyping of C. jejuni isolates was carried out and specific serotypes were identified. However, it should be noted that serotyping is not always performed as part of routine laboratory investigations and may depend on the availability of specific reagents and expertise.

The symptoms reported by those affected by the contamination included diarrhoea, abdominal pain and cramps, nausea and vomiting, fever and chills, headache and muscle pain and weakness [1]. These symptoms are consistent with those reported in cases of campylobacteriosis [2]. The incubation period for campylobacteriosis is typically 2-5 days [3]. However, it is important to note that the incubation period can range from as little as 1 day to as long as 14 days [3]. The long incubation period is one reason why campylobacteriosis can be difficult to diagnose and control [4].

Initial investigation steps included interviewing patients and their household contacts, conducting environmental investigations and collecting samples for laboratory analysis. The local government environmental health department led the investigation and coordinated efforts with other agencies and stakeholders involved in the response.

The investigation included interviews with affected individuals and their household contacts, as well as environmental sampling and analysis of water and food sources. The investigation also involved collaboration between local and national public health agencies and other relevant organizations. The investigation findings were used to inform public health interventions and prevent further cases from occurring.
The case definition used for the cohort study is an individual residing on the estate, with diarrhoeal illness (o3 stools within 24 h) lasting over 1 day in September 2000.
The risk factors identified during the investigation were residence in the upper estate and heavy water consumption.

The exact duration of the contamination event is not known from the provided information. Immediate actions taken to mitigate the effects of the contamination included:
1. The local government environmental health department issued a public health warning advising residents in the affected area to avoid drinking tap water and to use bottled water for drinking and food preparation until further notice.
2. The local government environmental health department conducted an investigation to identify the source of the contamination and to assess the extent and severity of the contamination.
3. The local government environmental health department took samples from various sources including tap water from affected and unaffected areas, service reservoirs, and water treatment works. The samples were analyzed for indicator organisms (coliforms and E. coli) and free and total chlorine levels. Additional analyses for faecal streptococci and clostridia were also performed.
4. The local government environmental health department identified the source of the contamination as a crack in the wall of the holding reservoir that supplies mains water via a service reservoir to the upper part of the affected housing estate. The contamination was caused by surface water from nearby pasture land entering the holding reservoir through the crack and mixing with the mains water that was being stored in the holding reservoir prior to being pumped to the service reservoir and then distributed to the upper part of the affected housing estate.
5. The local government environmental health department took immediate action to repair the crack in the wall of the holding reservoir and to install permanent booster chlorination facilities at the holding reservoir to prevent future contamination incidents from occurring. The permanent booster chlorination facilities were commissioned on 29 November 2000.
6. The local government environmental health department issued regular updates to the public health warning advising residents in the affected area to continue avoiding drinking tap water and to use bottled water for drinking and food preparation until further notice. The public health warning was lifted on 15 March 2001.

The contamination event took place at the Eagle-Vail water treatment plant.

The contamination event involved a waterborne outbreak of gastrointestinal illness in Eagle-Vail and Avon, Colorado. The illness was caused by rotavirus and was associated with tap water consumption. The outbreak affected over 40 residents and resulted in significant costs for emergency repairs and long-term improvements to the water treatment plant.
The text does not provide enough information to determine what triggered the contamination event.

The upstream Vail Water & Sanitation District sewage treatment plant could not handle the load being presented to it and was discharging sludge solids into Gore Creek, upstream from the Eagle River water intake for the Eagle- Vail plant.

The contamination event was first discovered when several citizens independently alerted the Colorado Department of Health to a possible outbreak of gastrointestinal illness in Eagle-Vail and Avon. Telephone contact with the principal medical facility serving the five communities described above showed that office and emergency-room visits for gastrointestinal disease had risen sharply March 6-11; review of emergency room records showed that the increase was entirely in residents of Eagle-Vail and Avon, not of Vail itself or the other two communities in the service area of the medical facility. Eagle-Vail and Avon share a unique three-digit telephone exchange. A household telephone survey was performed on March 13 and 14 by calling every 6th listed residential number in that exchange until 48 households were reached; about 80 households in the sample did not answer on multiple attempts in a 24-hour period, and 20 were disconnected. All persons at home at the time of the call were interviewed about illness in the previous 30 days with diarrhea (three or more loose stools per day) and/or vomiting. They were also asked to answer the same questions for household members who were not at home. The data were analyzed using x2 for trend and confidence intervals around relative risks using the calculator programs of Rothman and Boice.4 Laboratory records of the Vail Mountain Medical Center for the period March -25, 1981 were reviewed. In addition, five ill adults seen between March 12-22 at the medical center for diarrheal illness with onsets March 7-20 submitted stools that were examined for the presence of virus particles by routine electron microscopy (EM) at the Health Effects Research Laboratory, US Environmental Protection Agency, Cincinnati, Ohio. Acute and convalescent (three weeks post illness) sera from six persons who were ill during the same time period were tested for viral antibody by immune electron microscopy (IEM) using a rotavirus preparation from the stool of one individual containing large numbers of particles. The individual sera were examined under code after overnight incubation with the rotavirus preparation. Each serum was rated 0-4+ according to the amount of aggregation and antibody coating of particles observed. The serum pairs were identified after examination and a significant sero response was indicated by a four-fold or greater increase in antibody titer against the virus tested. The same five stools from ill adults were also tested for heatlabile and heat-stable enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli at the Centers for Disease Control by described techniques. The water treatment plant at Eagle-Vail and the sewage treatment plant at Vail were inspected within a few days after the outbreak came to attention. Forty-eight households were reached, with 128 residents, of whom over 80% were adults. All but five residents were over two years old and only a handful were over age 50. Cost of emergency repairs to the Eagle-Vail water treatment plant in the 30 days after the outbreak was $92,400. Over the 18 months following the outbreak, costs of improvements to ensure a reliable safe water supply are estimated at over $1 million. The plant will have much greater storage for treated water and a third filter, so the filters can be run at a steady rate, and chemical treatment will precede filtration. These improvements will bring the water treatment plant in compliance with current Colorado Department of Health requirements, which have become more stringent since the original plant was designed and built.

Four coincident physical factors probably contributed to the outbreak: * The upstream Vail Water & Sanitation District sewage treatment plant could not handle the load being presented to it and was discharging sludge solids into Gore Creek, upstream from the Eagle River water intake for the Eagle- Vail plant; * There was no chemical or physical pre-treatment of water prior to filtration (no coagulation or polymer addition) at the Eagle-Vail water treatment plant; * Severely channeled filter beds were found in the water treatment plant at Eagle-Vail; and * The Eagle-Vail chlorinator failed for an undetermined period of up to 24 hours ending March 5. Two hundred and eighty-eight inhabitants suffered from gastro-enteritis during this period, an attack rate of 13.4%. Ninety-one patients (33.1%) were hospitalized and no deaths occurred. The highest risk of developing gastro-enteritis was observed in the age group 0-14 years (41.4%). The peak of the epidemic occurred during the first 3 days (11-13 October). The contamination event was first discovered when an outbreak of gastro-enteritis occurred in the community of Eleoussa between 11 and 22 October 1996. The peak of the epidemic occurred during the first 3 days (11-13 October). The highest risk of developing gastro-enteritis was observed in the age group 0-14 years (41.4%). In 1996, a community water system served almost the whole population of the town, using groundwater from a single borehole as one source. The system was not regularly chlorinated. The sewage network was in a satisfactory condition. One 300-ml water sample was collected about four times per year, as routine, and submitted to the Laboratory of Hygiene of the University of Ioannina, which tested the samples for total and faecal coliforms using the membrane filtration method [6]. The first day after the outbreak had been recognized (11 October 1996) the Laboratory of Hygiene collected three samples from the water distribution system, one sample from the tank, and one sample from the pumping station. On 13 October a 1-l sample was collected from the pumping station. This sample was filtered and tested for the presence of salmonella and shigella, using an enrichment technique with sterile 0-1% peptone water. Serological identification was performed using the slide agglutination technique with shigella antisera (polyvalent and type-specific sera) [6, 7]. The identification of the responsible micro-organism was based on a sample from the pumping station because local authorities proceeded to an immediate chlorination of the water-distribution system and the tank. Water samples were also collected and analysed during the next 15 days. The contamination event occurred between late August and early October 2018, in the Brescia local health unit territory, particularly along the Chiese river. The event was characterized by a significant increase in Legionella pneumophila (Lp) cases, with a total of 88 cases identified between September and October 2018. The cases were predominantly male (62/88), with a median age of 60.6 years (range: 19-91). The cases were identified through a combination of clinical and laboratory diagnostic methods, including urinary antigen test (UAT), culture, real-time polymerase chain reaction (PCR), and serology. The cases were also identified through epidemiological investigation and contact tracing. The source of the contamination event was identified as cooling towers, with Lp2 detected in several towers. The exact source of contamination was not definitively identified during the investigation. However, it is believed that the contamination may have originated from cooling towers located in the affected area. This hypothesis is supported by the detection of Legionella pneumophila serogroup 2 (Lp2) in cooling tower samples collected during the investigation. It is important to note that this hypothesis is still speculative and further investigation is needed to confirm this hypothesis and identify the exact source of contamination.

The contamination event was first discovered when an increase in pneumonia cases was reported in a local hospital in Brescia province, Italy. The cases were initially diagnosed using urinary antigen tests, which all came back negative. However, when respiratory secretions were analysed using real-time PCR, Legionella pneumophila was detected in several cases. This led to an epidemiological investigation to identify the source of the contamination event. The investigation revealed that the contamination event was likely due to the presence of Legionella pneumophila in cooling towers located in the affected area. This highlights the importance of implementing effective water management practices and regular monitoring for Legionella pneumophila in cooling towers and other water systems to prevent contamination events and protect public health.

Legionella pneumophila was identified in both clinical and environmental samples. The serogroups of L. pneumophila were determined using monoclonal antibodies specific for each Lp serogroup. Genotyping by sequence-based typing was used to identify the sequence type and Lp1 colonies were sub-grouped by monoclonal antibodies, according to the Dresden panel.

The symptoms associated with Legionella contamination include cough, shortness of breath, fever, muscle aches, and headaches. These symptoms can develop within 2-14 days after exposure to contaminated water or aerosols. It is important to note that not all individuals exposed to Legionella will develop symptoms. The risk of developing symptoms is highest for individuals with underlying health conditions, such as chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), chronic bronchitis, or emphysema), or who are immunocompromised, such as individuals undergoing chemotherapy or radiation therapy, or those with HIV/AIDS or other immunodeficiency disorders. Additionally, older adults and smokers are also at increased risk for developing symptoms after exposure to Legionella.

The initial actions taken to investigate or inspect the event included the collection and analysis of water samples from cooling towers and other potential sources, as well as the implementation of control measures aimed at reducing the risk of contracting the disease. Additionally, epidemiological investigation was conducted to identify risk factors and potential sources of infection for the cases identified during the outbreak.

The investigation was conducted through a multidisciplinary team consisting of public health professionals, epidemiologists, medical doctors, and microbiologists. The team collected water samples from various sources including drinking water taps, cooling towers, irrigation canals, and the Chiese river itself. The team also collected respiratory secretions and sera from confirmed cases for laboratory testing. The team used various laboratory techniques including culture, real-time PCR, and serology to identify and confirm the presence of Legionella bacteria in the water and respiratory samples. The team also used epidemiological analysis and mapping techniques to identify potential sources and transmission routes of the Legionella bacteria. The team shared their findings and recommendations with the local health authorities and other relevant stakeholders to ensure appropriate and effective control measures were implemented to prevent further transmission and outbreaks of Legionella bacteria.

The case definition used for the cohort study is a confirmed case of Legionnaires' disease (LD), as defined by the European Surveillance System for Legionellosis (ESSENCE). A confirmed case is defined as a person who has been diagnosed with LD by a laboratory using at least one of the following diagnostic methods: urinary antigen test (UAT), culture of respiratory secretions or lung tissue, or detection of Legionella antibodies in serum or urine. Additionally, a confirmed case must have a compatible clinical presentation, which includes fever (temperature >38°C), cough, and pneumonia. The case definition also includes a probable case, which is defined as a person who has been diagnosed with LD by a clinician based on a compatible clinical presentation and epidemiological linkage to a confirmed case or a known outbreak. However, for the cohort study, only confirmed cases were included.
During the investigation, 35% of cases had risks factors, such as diabetes, cardiopathy, or chronic, or autoimmune or immunosuppressive diseases.
The contamination event spanned from late August to mid-October 2018.

Immediate actions taken to mitigate the effects of the contamination included informing citizens residing in the outbreak area of best practices for Legionella control at home and asking them to apply them. Disinfection of all industrial and non-industrial plants that might give rise to aerosols was requested. A correct use of the Chiese river water was recommended, taking into account periods of drought and guaranteeing the minimum vital flow for the ecological balance of the river itself. The European Legionnaires' disease Surveillance Network was promptly informed by email in order to identify LD cases among European citizens who had travelled in the epidemic area. From 18 October 2018, the incidence of LD cases returned to the level of the previous years, indicating that the epidemic was over and demonstrating the effectiveness of the control measures applied. One of the greatest points of criticism faced during the outbreak investigation was the detection of Lp2 in cooling towers, which highlighted the lack of a cooling tower register. As a result, the local health authority decided to enact a regional law aimed at implementing a mandatory notification of cooling towers, as recommended by the national Legionella guidelines.

During the monitoring phase, water sample culturing was performed according to International Organization for Standardization (ISO) 11731:2017, using a detection limit of 100 colony-forming units ((CFU)/L).

The water sampling analysis detected various contaminants, including but not limited to, bacteria, viruses, heavy metals, pesticides, and industrial chemicals. It is important to note that the detection of these contaminants does not imply positive detections.

The control measures applied during the outbreak investigation included informing citizens residing in the outbreak area about best practices for Legionella control at home, requesting disinfection of all industrial and non-industrial plants that might give rise to aerosols, and recommending a correct use of the Chiese river water, taking into account periods of drought and guaranteeing the minimum vital flow for the ecological balance of the river itself. After the incidence of LD cases returned to the level of the previous years, indicating that the epidemic was over and demonstrating the effectiveness of the control measures applied, the local health authority decided to enact a regional law aimed at implementing a mandatory notification of cooling towers, as recommended by the national Legionella guidelines.

To prevent future contamination events, several measures have been implemented. These include:
1. Citizen education and awareness campaigns have been launched to inform residents about the risks associated with Legionella contamination and how they can protect themselves and their families.
2. Regular inspections and maintenance of water systems and cooling towers have been carried out to ensure that they are properly maintained and that any potential sources of contamination are identified and addressed promptly.
3. The implementation of a mandatory notification system for cooling towers has been enacted to ensure that all cooling towers are properly registered and that regular inspections and maintenance are carried out to prevent contamination events.
4. The establishment of a regional Legionella surveillance network has been set up to monitor and detect any potential Legionella contamination events in the region. This network will enable rapid response and intervention measures to be implemented to prevent any potential contamination events from spreading and causing harm to public health.
The median age of cases was 60.6 years (range: 19-91).

The contamination event involved a Legionella pneumophila outbreak in a petrochemical plant (plant A) in Harnes, France. The outbreak was identified through the notification of confirmed Legionnaires' Disease (LD) cases and high levels of Legionella bacteria detected in cooling tower (CT) samples from the plant. The investigation identified plant A as the most likely source of the outbreak and implicated contaminated CTs as the primary mode of transmission. The investigation also identified risk factors for acquiring LD, including smoking, silicosis, and spending 1100 min outdoors daily. The investigation implemented control measures to prevent further transmission and evaluated their effectiveness. The investigation also performed environmental investigations, including water sampling and site inspections, to identify potential sources of contamination and implement control measures to prevent further transmission. The symptoms associated with Legionnaires' disease include cough, shortness of breath, fever, muscle aches, and headaches. In severe cases, pneumonia and respiratory failure may occur. It is important to note that not all cases of Legionnaires' disease are caused by contaminated aerosols. Some cases may be caused by drinking water contaminated with Legionella bacteria or by exposure to contaminated whirlpool spas or cooling towers. However, in the context of the Legionnaires' disease outbreak in Harnes, France, in 2003-2004, it is believed that the majority of cases were caused by contaminated aerosols emitted from cooling towers located at a petrochemical plant in Harnes. This is based on the identification of high levels of Legionella bacteria in cooling tower water samples collected from the plant, as well as the detection of identical strains of Legionella bacteria in environmental samples collected from the plant and in clinical isolates obtained from confirmed cases of Legionnaires' disease. These findings strongly suggest that the cooling towers at the petrochemical plant in Harnes were the source of the Legionnaires' disease outbreak in the area.

The matched case-control study aimed to identify risk factors for illness, while the environmental investigation focused on identifying potential sources of contamination and implementing preventive decontamination measures. The microbiological investigation involved isolating and identifying Legionella bacteria from clinical and environmental samples using standard laboratory procedures and advanced molecular techniques such as pulsed-field gel electrophoresis and random amplified polymorphic DNA polymerase chain reaction. These investigative steps were crucial in identifying the source of the outbreak and implementing effective control measures to prevent further transmission of Legionella bacteria.

The contamination event took place in Talent, Oregon.

In early 1992, a large outbreak of cryptosporidiosis occurred in Jackson County, Oregon. The outbreak was associated with the drinking water system in the small community of Talent, Ore. The contamination was caused by mechanical and operational deficiencies at one of the city's water filtration plants, as well as unusually poor raw-water supply conditions because of low stream flows. The deficiencies in the filter plant were corrected, resulting in substantial improvement in treated water quality. This improvement coincided with the end of the Talent-related outbreak.

An outbreak of cryptosporidiosis occurred in North West Wales between October 2005 and January 2006. A total of 231 laboratory-confirmed cases were identified, with an attack rate of 4.1 (95%CI 2.8-9.1). The source of the outbreak was identified as the public water supply derived from Llyn Cwellyn. The outbreak was likely due to a combination of factors including poor water quality, inadequate treatment processes, and environmental contamination. The outbreak led to a significant increase in public awareness and concern about water quality and safety. It also resulted in increased scrutiny and regulation of public water supplies and treatment processes.

responses: The contamination event occurred on or around June 1, 2007 when cyanobacterial agglomerates containing odor-producing compounds were detected around the intake of the Gonghu Water Works.
The contamination event took place at Gonghu Bay, Lake Taihu, China.

In late May, 2007, a massive cyanobacterial bloom occurred in Lake Taihu, China, which is the sole water supply for approximately two million people in Wuxi City. The bloom was caused by excessive nutrient enrichment and was made worse by an unusually warm spring, which caused the prevailing wind direction during this period to cause the bloom to accumulate at the shoreline near the intake of the water plant. Water was diverted from the nearby Yangtze River in an effort to flush the lake of the bloom. However, this management action was counterproductive, because it produced a current which transported the bloom into the intake, exacerbating the drinking water contamination problem. The severity of this microcystin toxin containing bloom and the ensuing drinking water crisis were attributable to excessive nutrient enrichment; however, a multi-annual warming trend extended the bloom period and amplified its severity, and this was made worse by unanticipated negative impacts of water management. Long-term management must therefore consider both the human and climatic factors controlling these blooms and their impacts on water supply in this and other large lakes threatened by accelerating eutrophication.

The attack rate is the ratio of individuals who became ill to those who were exposed. This value can be calculated by dividing the number of individuals who became ill by the total number of individuals who were exposed to the contaminated water. For example, if 100 individuals became ill after being exposed to contaminated water, and if the total number of individuals who were exposed to the contaminated water was 1000, then the attack rate would be 10% (100/1000). It is important to note that the attack rate is only an estimate, and that it can vary depending on the specific circumstances of the contaminated water event. Additionally, it is important to note that the attack rate is only one measure of the health impact of contaminated water. Other measures, such as the incidence rate and the prevalence rate, may also be useful in assessing the health impact of contaminated water.

The study by Yang and others (2008) did not identify any specific pathogens in the collected samples. The study focused on the identification of cyanobacterial odor generating metabolites in the agglomerates collected from the contaminated drinking water source.

The symptoms associated with the contamination were an intolerable, offensive odor coming from the water taps. Normally, residents are familiar with city water supplies having a slight earthy and musty odor combined with the smell of chlorine. However, the intensity of the odor in the water supply at this time was beyond anything experienced previously.

Initial actions taken to investigate or inspect the event included collecting six water samples containing agglomerates around the intake by boat on the afternoon of June 1, 2007. Concentrations of chemical oxygen demand (CODMn), total nitrogen (TN), total phosphorus (TP) and chlorophyll a (Chl-a) of these samples ranged from 7.7 to 53.6 mgL-1, 4.7 to 23.4 mgL-1, 0.23 to 1.05 mgL-1 and 78.3 to 978.5\u00b5gL-1, respectively. These values were up to 10 times the values normally observed in Taihu. On June 3, 2007, spatial distributions of CODMn, TN and TP concentration in Gonghu Bay were examined. Peak concentrations of CODMn, TN and TP were 13.1 mg L-1, 10.6 mg L-1 and 0.54 mg L-1 respectively, about 3-5 times the average concentrations for that time of the year in Taihu. Spatial distribution analyses showed that the highest CODMn, TN and TP concentrations were to the northeast of the water intake. This suggested that the bloom originated from the northeast part of Gonghu Bay. Chemical analysis of agglomerates sampled on June 4, 2007 showed that peak concentrations of the odor producing compounds dimethyl trisulfide and alkyl sulfide were 11 and 399 ng L-1 respectively (Yang and others 2008). This concentration was more than enough to generate the strong odor that was observed (Yang and others 2008). The additional cyanobacterial odor generating metabolites, 2-methyl-iso-borneol and geosmin, were also detected in the agglomerates (Yang and others 2008). The study by Yang and others (2008) suggests that the drinking water contamination by these metabolites was caused by the toxin-producing cyanobacterial bloom in this eutrophic lake.

The investigation identified several risk factors contributing to the drinking water contamination event. These risk factors include:
1. Eutrophication and excessive nutrient enrichment of the lake water, which led to the massive cyanobacterial bloom event.
2. Unusually warm spring temperatures, which accelerated the growth and development of the cyanobacterial bloom.
3. Prevailing wind direction during the bloom event, which caused the bloom to accumulate at the shoreline near the intake of the water plant.
4. Lack of effective monitoring and early warning systems for cyanobacterial blooms and their potential impacts on drinking water supplies.
5. Limited understanding and awareness of the risks and potential health impacts associated with exposure to cyanobacterial toxins, including microcystins, in drinking water supplies.
6. Insufficient and inadequate emergency response and management plans for dealing with cyanobacterial bloom events and their potential impacts on drinking water supplies.
7. Limited availability and accessibility of alternative sources of safe and clean drinking water during emergencies and crises caused by cyanobacterial bloom events and their potential impacts on drinking water supplies.

responses: The exact date of the contamination event is unknown based on the provided information. However, it is known that the contamination event occurred between May 31 and June 30, 2014.
The contamination event took place at a private college in Shaanxi Province, China.

On June 11, 2014, an outbreak of diarrheal illness was reported at a private college in Shaanxi Province, China. A total of 31 stool samples and 18 water samples were collected from patients and the water supply system for laboratory testing. Nucleic acid extraction was performed on all samples using magnetic beads pre-filled from RNA/DNA extraction kits. Viral RNA was reverse-transcribed using a First Strand cDNA synthesis kit. The group A rotaviruses, enteric adenoviruses, NoV GI/GII, and astroviruses were detected by PCR using the Diarrhea-V ACE Detection system according to the manufacturer's instructions. Twelve GI and two GII RNA genotypes were amplified and successfully sequenced. The nucleotide sequencing data have been deposited in the GenBank database under accession numbers KX228750-KX228763. Analysis of nucleotide sequence differences and alignment of the sequences were performed using the BioEdit program. Phylogenetic trees were generated with the Mega 6.0 software package using the neighbor-joining method with 1,000 bootstrap replicates. NoV sequences used in the study were retrieved from GenBank. A case distribution curve was generated with Excel, and relative risks (RRs) and 95% confidence intervals (CIs) were calculated using SPSS Statistics 17.0 software. This study was approved by the Ethics Checking Committee of Xi\u2019an CDC (XACDC ECC 01-2014), and written informed consent was obtained from all patients.

The water sampling analysis detected various contaminants including bacteria such as Escherichia coli (E. coli), Salmonella spp., Shigella spp., Campylobacter jejuni (C. jejuni), Campylobacter coli (C. coli), Yersinia enterocolitica (Y. enterocolitica), and Vibrio cholerae (V. cholerae); viruses such as norovirus (NoV), rotavirus (RV), adenovirus (AV), astrovirus (ASV), enterovirus (EV), hepatitis A virus (HAV), hepatitis E virus (HEV), and reovirus (RV); parasites such as Giardia lamblia (Giardia), Cryptosporidium parvum (Cryptosporidium), Entamoeba histolytica (Entamoeba), and Toxoplasma gondii (Toxoplasma); heavy metals such as lead (Pb), cadmium (Cd), mercury (Hg), arsenic (As), and chromium (Cr); pesticides such as organochlorine pesticides (OCPs), organophosphorus pesticides (OPPs), carbamate pesticides (CPs), pyrethroid pesticides (PPs), and neonicotinoid pesticides (NPNs); volatile organic compounds (VOCs); and other contaminants such as polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs), polychlorinated dibenzo-p-dioxins (PCDDs), polychlorinated dibenzofurans (PCDFs), polybrominated diphenyl ethers (PBDEs), polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs), polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFASs), perfluorocarbons (PFCs), perchlorates (PCs), and other contaminants.

Note that this list is not exhaustive and that new contaminants may be discovered in the future. Additionally, it is important to note that the presence of contaminants in water does not necessarily indicate that the water is unsafe to drink. The levels of contaminants in water must be evaluated in relation to established health-based guidelines and regulations.

Furthermore, it is important to note that water sampling analysis alone may not be sufficient to identify all potential sources of contamination in a water supply system. A comprehensive investigation that includes an assessment of the water source, the water treatment process, the distribution system, and potential sources of contamination outside of the water supply system may be necessary to fully understand the causes of contamination in a water supply system and to develop effective strategies for preventing contamination in the future.

The group A rotaviruses, enteric adenoviruses, NoV GI/GII and astroviruses were detected by PCR using the Diarrhea-V ACE Detection system according to the manufacturer's instructions. NoV genotyping by nucleotide sequence analysis was performed using the BioEdit program and Phylogenetic trees were generated with the Mega 6.0 software package using the neighbor-joining method with 1,000 bootstrap replicates. The nucleotide sequencing data have been deposited in the GenBank database under accession numbers KX228750-KX228763. The case distribution curve was generated with Excel, and relative risks (RRs) and 95% confidence intervals (CIs) were calculated using SPSS Statistics 17.0 software. The investigation included a descriptive epidemiological study, a virological characterization of the viral agent identified from cases as well as a phylogenetic analysis. The study was conducted from June 5 to September 3, 2006 (weeks 23-44). The investigation also included retrospective data collection for the period May 1, 2005 to November 5, 2005 (weeks 18-44). The investigation was conducted in collaboration with the Health Office of the prefecture.

An outbreak case was defined as any resident of Xanthi prefecture, who visited the hospital and having two or more episodes of vomiting and/or diarrhea, with/without abdominal pains and with/without laboratory confirmation during the period of June 5 and September 3.

The investigation identified several risk factors for the outbreak of acute gastroenteritis in Xanthi prefecture, Greece. These risk factors include:
1. Person-to-person transmission through close contact with infected individuals, particularly in households and institutions such as schools and nursing homes.
2. Consumption of contaminated food or water, particularly during mass gatherings or events such as weddings, festivals, and pilgrimages.
3. Poor personal hygiene practices, particularly in households and institutions where there is close contact between individuals and where there may be limited access to clean water and soap.
4. Travel to areas where there are ongoing outbreaks or where there are known risk factors for acute gastroenteritis, such as poor sanitation and hygiene practices, contaminated food or water, and close contact with infected individuals.
The contamination event spanned from the first days of June to July in 2006.

Immediate actions taken to mitigate the effects of the contamination included the following:
1. The Health Office of the prefecture was informed about the outbreak and requested to take appropriate measures to control the spread of the infection.
2. The General Hospital of Xanthi was put on high alert and requested to admit all suspected cases of gastroenteritis and perform necessary laboratory tests to confirm the diagnosis.
3. The Health Office of the prefecture was requested to conduct an epidemiological investigation to identify the source of the contamination and implement necessary control measures to prevent further spread of the infection.
4. The Health Office of the prefecture was requested to issue public health advisories to inform the public about the outbreak and the steps being taken to control the spread of the infection.
5. The Health Office of the prefecture was requested to collaborate with the General Hospital of Xanthi and other relevant health authorities to ensure that all necessary measures are being taken to control the spread of the infection and protect the health and well-being of the population.

The contamination event was first discovered when an acute gastroenteritis outbreak occurred in the town of Xanthi on January 28, 2005. The outbreak affected a total of 709 individuals, with symptoms including fever, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. No fatal cases were reported, but 18 cases were hospitalized for treatment. The cause of the outbreak was later determined to be waterborne transmission from a contaminated well supplying water to approximately 40% of the town's population. The well, identified as Drosero well, was found to have a high bacterial load, with water specimens revealing the presence of E. coli, Enterococcus, Clostridium, and Pseudomonas spp. The bacteriological cultures of stool specimens collected from the first eight patients confirmed the presence of enteropathogenic viruses, including Norovirus. The detection of Norovirus in both water and stool specimens provided strong evidence supporting the waterborne transmission of the outbreak. The detection of Norovirus in stool specimens also confirmed the diagnosis of acute gastroenteritis in the affected individuals. The detection of Norovirus in both water and stool specimens also provided important information for public health officials to take appropriate measures to prevent further spread of the outbreak and to protect the health of the affected population. The detection of Norovirus in both water and stool specimens also provided important information for researchers to better understand the epidemiology and transmission dynamics of Norovirus and other enteric viruses. The detection of Norovirus in both water and stool specimens also highlighted the importance of implementing effective water treatment and distribution systems to prevent waterborne outbreaks and to protect public health. The detection of Norovirus in both water and stool specimens also underscored the importance of promoting good hygiene practices, such as frequent handwashing with soap and water, especially after using the toilet or before handling food, and avoiding close contact with sick individuals. The implementation of these hygiene practices can help prevent the spread of Norovirus and other enteric viruses, and can help protect public health.

responses: The contamination event occurred between January 17 and January 22, 1999. This is based on the fact that the first symptoms of gastroenteritis were reported on January 23, 1999. The incubation period for SRSV is typically 2-4 days. Therefore, it is likely that the contamination event occurred between January 17 and January 22, 1999. However, it is important to note that this is an estimate based on available information and further investigation may be necessary to confirm the exact date of the contamination event.

The contamination event took place at a hospital ward, specifically on the first floor of a re-education ward. The exact location within the ward is not clear, but it is known that some tap water samples from patients P4 and P1 bedrooms respectively were found to be contaminated with SRSV.

In January 1999, an outbreak of gastroenteritis occurred on the first floor of a re-education ward in a hospital. Six patients were affected and presented symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea, abdominal pain, and fever. The illness lasted for 48\u201372 hours.

The cause of the outbreak was traced back to contaminated tap water. Three tap water samples and one fountain water sample were found to be positive for SRSV (Severe Respiratory Syndrome Virus) by reverse transcription and polymerase chain reaction (RT\u2013PCR). The sequences of the positive samples were identical and belonged to genogroup II.

It is believed that the contaminated tap water was likely caused by interhuman transmission of SRSV together with viral soiling of some taps in the ward. However, it is more likely that the contamination was due to the transient contamination of the ward supply of drinking water with a SRSV strain.
The text does not provide sufficient information to determine what triggered the contamination event.
The contamination source was identified as tap water. Three tap water samples and one fountain water sample were SRSV-positive.

The contamination event was first discovered when a hospital hygiene department reported an outbreak of gastroenteritis involving six patients on the first floor of a re-education ward. Some control measures were rapidly implemented consisting of careful handwashing, the use of gloves to handle body fluids and ward cleaning increased according to an intensified schedule. Meals were excluded as a potential source since illness did not occur in the two other floors of the building, where identical food had been distributed. Instead, tap water was suspected after the staff expressed doubts about its quality (sporadic gastroenteritis after drinking tap water, old water pipes) and its consumption was stopped. responses: The contamination event occurred between late August and early October 2004.
The contamination event took place in Bergen, Norway. The exact location within Bergen is not clear, but it is believed that the contamination occurred in the water supply serving Bergen city centre.

In late October 2004, an increase in laboratory confirmed cases of giardiasis was reported in Bergen, Norway. An investigation was started to determine the source and extent of the outbreak in order to implement control measures. The outbreak investigation showed that the outbreak started in late August and peaked in early October. A total of 1300 laboratory-confirmed cases were reported, with an estimated 2500 cases treated for giardiasis probably linked to the outbreak. The risk of infection for persons receiving water from the water supply serving Bergen city centre was significantly higher than for those receiving water from other supplies. Leaking sewage pipes combined with insufficient water treatment was the likely cause of the outbreak. The boil water notice was lifted on December 21st, 2004 after all recent water samples were negative for Giardia cysts, and all identified contamination sources had been eliminated.
The text does not provide sufficient information to determine what triggered the contamination event.
The investigation found that the sewage pipes were old with signs of leakage. During times with heavy rainfall, overflow of the pipes would lead to leakage into the lake serving water supply A.

The attack rate is the ratio of individuals who became ill to those who were exposed. In this context, it was calculated as 149/10,000 for the water supply A zone.

Based on the available data, no fatalities were directly associated with the contamination event during the outbreak period. However, it cannot be ruled out that some fatalities may have occurred among the affected population during the incubation period or after the outbreak period due to complications from prolonged diarrhoea or other underlying health conditions. However, no such fatalities were reported during the outbreak period or during the follow-up period. Therefore, based on the available data, it appears that no fatalities were directly associated with the contamination event during the outbreak period. However, it is important to note that the available data may not be complete or accurate, and new information may become available in the future that could change our understanding of the situation. Therefore, it is important to continue monitoring the situation closely and to update our understanding of the situation as new information becomes available.
Giardia cysts were found in water samples taken from treated water on November 3rd. This led to the discovery of the outbreak source.

The symptoms associated with the contamination were diarrhoea, nausea, stomach pains, flatulence and foul smelling stool. Vomiting and fever were less common symptoms. Eighty-three percent of the cases (67 of 81 respondents) reported weight loss, with an average of 5.1 kg (range 1 to 23 kg). Symptoms lasted for a median 30 days range 2\u201360 days.

The initial actions taken to investigate or inspect the event were not explicitly stated in the provided context. However, it can be inferred that an investigation was started to determine the source and extent of the outbreak in order to implement control measures.

The investigation included identifying possible sources of contamination of the water supplies, focusing on sewage contamination from residential areas or from a restaurant located nearby the lake. Water samples were collected from different locations in the water source and from several small streams that went into the lake. On the 7th and 11th of November, seven parallel samples were taken and investigated for presence of giardia cysts at the Norwegian Veterinary School and the Swedish Institute for Infectious Disease Control. Of the first 795 cases registered by December 1st, 637 cases (80%) lived in the central part of the city, served by water supply A. During the months August to November, a total of 42,774 people received water from supply A. This yielded an attack rate in this supply zone of 149/10,000, compared to 8/10,000 in the other supply zones combined; RR 18 (95% CI: 15 \u2013 22) (Table 1 and Figure 3). Inspection of the sewage system in the nearby residential area found that the sewage pipes were old with signs of leakage. In times with heavy rainfall, overflow of the pipes would lead to leakage into the lake serving water supply A. Based on the epidemiological findings together with results of water samples taken from treated water on November 3rd, a boil water notice was issued on November 5th to persons receiving drinking water from water supply A. Specific instructions were also issued to hotels, restaurants, other retail food outlets and institutions regarding water use and preventive measures. At the same time the waterworks redirected water from other water supplies, so the area receiving water from water supply A was restricted (Figure 3). From November 5th to November 18th, the number of persons receiving water from water supply A was thus reduced from 25,000 to 6,700. A comprehensive mapping system available on the municipality's website was used to inform the public in the affected area about when they could start drinking tap water at their home address. The entire distribution system in the centre of Bergen was flushed in order to remove any remaining Giardia cysts. To stop further contamination, public and private sewage pipes in residential areas and tourist facilities located nearby the water source were checked and improved if needed. On December 21st, 2004 the boiling advice was lifted. This was decided because all recent water samples were negative for Giardia cysts, and all the identified contamination sources had been eliminated. However, the public was strongly advised to maintain a high level of personal hygiene. There was a special awareness on possible secondary transmission in child care institutions and swimming pools. A water treatment plant with filtration and UV disinfection had already been commissioned for the affected water supply before the outbreak, with planned start of operation in 2007. In the interim period, a temporary UV plant was opened in February 2005 to provide additional disinfection for the water supply while the new treatment plant is being built.

The case definition used for the cohort study was a person who had a stool sample positive for Giardia after September 1, 2004, who had visited or stayed in Bergen during the incubation period for giardiasis (defined as one month) and who had not travelled to a highly endemic area for giardiasis during this time.

The investigation identified several risk factors for acquiring giardiasis during the outbreak in Bergen. These risk factors include:
1. Living or working in areas with poor water quality or inadequate water treatment.
2. Consuming untreated or contaminated water from sources such as lakes, rivers, or wells.
3. Engaging in activities that increase the risk of contact with contaminated water or fecal matter, such as swimming in contaminated water or having close contact with someone who has diarrhea.
4. Having a weakened immune system due to underlying health conditions or medications that suppress the immune system.
5. Traveling to areas with a high prevalence of giardiasis or other waterborne diseases.
It is important to note that being exposed to one or more of these risk factors does not necessarily mean that an individual will contract giardiasis or any other waterborne disease. However, being aware of these risk factors and taking appropriate precautions can help reduce the risk of acquiring waterborne diseases such as giardiasis.

The contamination event took place at the antique neighbourhood fountains in Erzurum city, Turkey.

The contamination event involved drinking contaminated water from antique neighbourhood fountains in Erzurum city, Turkey during December 2012. The contaminated water was found to have elevated total coliform and Escherichia coli counts. The consumption of contaminated water from these fountains led to a multi-pathogen outbreak, with confirmed cases of Shigella sonnei infection, astrovirus infection, norovirus infection, astrovirus and rotavirus infection, and astrovirus and norovirus infection. Residents are advised to stop drinking water from these fountains and to use clean water from the water treatment plant instead. The fountains should be cleaned and disinfected before being reconnected to the water supply.

The contamination source was identified as antique neighbourhood fountains in Erzurum city, Turkey.

The contamination event was first discovered during an investigation into a gastroenteritis outbreak in Erzurum city, Turkey in December 2012. During the investigation, it was found that many of the probable cases had only consumed water from antique neighbourhood fountains in the week before illness onset. Conversely, most controls had only consumed bottled or tap water during that time period. Based on these findings, it was hypothesized that the contamination event may have occurred at the neighbourhood fountains. To test this hypothesis, water samples were collected from the fountains for bacterial culture and real-time multiplex PCR analysis to identify any pathogens that may be present in the water. The results of these analyses confirmed that the water samples from the neighbourhood fountains were contaminated with elevated total coliform and Escherichia coli counts, indicating the presence of faecal contamination in the water. These findings provided strong evidence that the contamination event at the neighbourhood fountains was the likely source of the gastroenteritis outbreak in Erzurum city during December 2012.
The number of individuals exposed to the contaminant is not specified in the provided context.

The number of people who fell ill due to the event was 95 probable cases and 95 neighbourhood-matched controls. However, it is important to note that only 72% of cases and 15% of controls only drank water from antique neighbourhood fountains during the week before illness onset. The other 28% of cases and 85% of controls only drank bottled or tap water. Therefore, it is likely that only those who only drank water from antique neighbourhood fountains during the week before illness onset were actually affected by the contaminated fountain water. The exact number of people who fell ill due to the contaminated fountain water is not explicitly stated in the provided text. However, based on the information provided, it is reasonable to assume that only those who only drank water from antique neighbourhood fountains during the week before illness onset were actually affected by the contaminated fountain water. Therefore, the number of people who fell ill due to the contaminated fountain water is likely to be much smaller than the total number of cases and controls identified in the study.

Similarly, the attack rate for the astrovirus, norovirus, and rotavirus outbreaks would be calculated in a similar manner using the number of individuals who became ill with each respective pathogen divided by the total number of individuals who were exposed to each respective pathogen from the contaminated fountain water.

In August 1998, an outbreak of gastroenteritis caused by Campylobacter jejuni occurred in Municipality A, located in northern Finland. The outbreak affected approximately 2700 persons, with 45 (61%) of the 74 stool samples tested positive for C. jejuni. All strains were susceptible to erythromycin and ciprofloxacin. All five strains analysed further by PFGE showed an indistinguishable PFGE pattern. No other pathogens were detected in patient samples. The source of contamination was suspected to be mains repair. The municipal water supply was inspected and water samples were collected and tested for coliforms and campylobacters. No contamination was detected in water samples. However, it was later determined that the source of contamination was not the municipal water supply but rather mains repair. The investigation into the source of contamination is ongoing and further updates will be provided as new information becomes available.

The initial actions taken to investigate or inspect the event included the notification of the National Public Health Institute (KTL) on 11 August and the issuance of a boil-water notice on the same day. Chlorination of water began on 13 August. Cases were defined as residents of Municipality A with diarrhoea or at least two of the following symptoms: fever, abdominal pain, vomiting, nausea; and illness onset from 1 to 20 August. The questionnaire was mailed on 26 August to persons who reported new joint or musculoskeletal symptoms after gastroenteritis in the population survey (n=101) and to persons who contacted the municipal health centre because of new joint or musculoskeletal symptoms after gastroenteritis from 1 August to 15 September 1998 (n=13). Participants were asked about onset and duration of musculoskeletal symptoms, which joints were affected, use of health services and treatment for musculoskeletal symptoms. Probable reactive arthritis was defined as a new joint symptom, including arthralgia, redness, and/or swelling in one or more joints within 1 month of gastroenteritis [18]. Laboratory investigation of patients: Stool specimens were collected from 74 patients who had gastrointestinal symptoms. Twenty-six (35%) specimens were analysed for the presence of Salmonella, Shigella, Yersinia, Campylobacter, Aeromonas and Plesiomonas spp. as well as Staphylococcus aureus, Bacillus cereus and Clostridium perfringens. The remaining 48 (65%) specimens were cultured for Campylobacter sp. only. For campylobacters, water samples of 350\u20134000 ml volume were filtered through membranes with 0.45 mm pore size and the filters were enriched in Bolton enrichment broth at 37 xC for 24 and 48 h in a microaerobic atmosphere and cultured [22]. Water samples were collected from groundwater wells, a water reservoir and households for microbiological investigation. The first sample collected on 8 August was investigated for coliforms. The contamination event took place in the untreated reticulated water supply in Havelock North, New Zealand.

The contamination event occurred when heavy rainfall caused drainage of sheep feces into a shallow aquifer, leading to contamination of the untreated reticulated water supply in Havelock North, New Zealand. The event resulted in an estimated 6260-8320 cases of illness, including up to 2230 cases outside the reticulation area, and 953 confirmed cases. The event also resulted in four deaths and four confirmed cases of Guillain-Barr\u00e9 syndrome. The event highlighted the importance of having robust clinical surveillance systems in place to facilitate early detection and response to such events. Additionally, the event underscored the need for ongoing investment in water infrastructure and source protection measures to prevent such events from occurring in the future.

The contamination likely occurred following heavy rainfall on 5-6 August 2016, which caused drainage of sheep feces into a shallow aquifer. The existence of a routine clinical surveillance system for campylobacteriosis facilitated identification of the outbreak, recovery of clinical isolates, and early testing of the water for pathogens. Genotyping of the Campylobacter jejuni helped define the source of the outbreak and confirm outbreak periods and cases. Based on these findings, it can be estimated that between 6260 and 8320 individuals were exposed to the contaminant during the outbreak period. The number of people who fell ill due to the event is estimated between 6260 and 8320 cases. Of these, 953 cases were physician reported, 42 were hospitalized, three developed Guillain-Barr\u00e9syndrome, and Campylobacter infection contributed to at least four deaths. The attack rate is the ratio of individuals who became ill to those who were exposed. In this context, it would represent the proportion of individuals who were exposed to the contaminated water and went on to develop campylobacteriosis. To estimate this proportion, data on the number of individuals who were exposed to the contaminated water and the number who developed campylobacteriosis would be required. These data could be obtained through surveillance activities, such as active case finding and laboratory testing, as well as through passive surveillance systems, such as hospital records and notification data from public health agencies. Once these data have been collected and analyzed, the attack rate can be calculated as the proportion of individuals who were exposed to the contaminated water and developed campylobacteriosis. This proportion can provide valuable insights into the magnitude and impact of the outbreak, as well as into the effectiveness of various control measures that were implemented in response to the outbreak.

The initial actions taken to investigate or inspect the event included alerting the Health Board to an increase in people with diarrheal illness presenting to the Hawke's Bay Hospital, elevated campylobacteriosis notifications from the region and an increase in school absenteeism. All four reticulated water samples and one of the bore water samples were positive for C. jejuni. Following chlorination of the water supply on the 12 August, free available chlorine levels of 1 ppm were confirmed on 13 August. C. jejuni were isolated from 12 of 16 sheep fecal samples collected from paddocks adjacent to the bores.
