responses: The contamination event occurred between 8 and 13 January when water samples collected from the wells and distribution system had coliform counts ranging from 1 to 2 per 100 mL. However, it is important to note that federal drinking water regulations in place at the time defined any sample with 1 or more coliforms per 100 mL as unsatisfactory.
The contamination event took place in the municipal water system in Cabool, Missouri.

This event was a large outbreak of Escherichia coli O157:H7 (ECO 157) infections in Cabool, Missouri, between 15 December 1989 and 20 January 1990. The outbreak was caused by contaminated drinking water from the municipal water system in Cabool. The contamination occurred after 41 water meters were replaced between 8 December and 23 December 1989, and after two water mains ruptured on 23 December and 26 December 1989, respectively. The number of new cases declined rapidly after residents were ordered to boil drinking water on 4 January 1990 and after the water was chlorinated on 12 January 1990. The outbreak strain was resistant to sulfisoxazole, tetracycline, and streptomycin but was sensitive to the other antimicrobial agents tested. It produced both SLT I and II and had a single 60-megadalton plasmid. Of the 68 water samples collected between 18 December and 12 January from the wells and distribution system and cultured at the EBMSPHL, 6 had coliform counts of 1 per 100 mL, and 1 had 2 per 100 mL. Federal drinking water regulations in place at the time of this outbreak defined any sample with 1 or more coliforms per 100 mL as unsatisfactory. All eight colonies from these samples were sorbitol positive. Most water samples were collected late in the outbreak. No samples were collected between 19 December and 2 January; only one sample was collected from the distribution system on 18 December and one on 3 January; neither were from the areas with the highest concentration of cases (north and northeast sections).

The symptoms associated with the contamination were bloody diarrhea, abdominal cramps, and fever. Severe cases may have led to hospitalization and even death. Yes, a detailed investigation was conducted to identify the source of the EC0157 outbreak in Cabool, Missouri. The investigation included media appeals, contacting surrounding physicians, hospitals, and laboratories, conducting a household survey, collecting stool specimens from residents for laboratory testing, inspecting the municipal water and sewage system, and evaluating possible cross-connections between the water and sewage systems. The investigation was conducted by the Cabool Health Department in collaboration with the Missouri Department of Health, the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, and the Missouri State Public Health Laboratory.

A case was defined as illness with onset between 15 December 1989 and 20 January 1990 in a visitor or resident of Burdine Township or household contact of a case patient with 1. three or more loose, bloody stools in a 24-hour period or 2. three or more loose, nonbloody stools in a 24-hour period lasting at least 1 day and accompanied by abdominal cramps. To identify case patients, we used media appeals; contacted surrounding physicians, hospitals, and laboratories; and conducted a household survey. Stools were collected for culture from all newly recognized cases of bloody or severe diarrhea. County and state sanitarians inspected the two grocery stores, the six restaurants, and the nursing home kitchen facilities in Cabool; determined their food sources; inspected the municipal water and sewage system; and evaluated possible cross-connections between the water and sewage systems. The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) used water-system flow data and the household locations of all known cases of bloody diarrhea inside the city to create a computer model. Scenarios were constructed in which 1 x 109 bacteria were introduced into the water system during a 4-hour period at various sites including the sites of possible breaks in the distribution system. The extent of bacterial spread and sections of the city at highest risk were determined.

During the investigation, several risk factors were identified for this outbreak. These included:
1. Consumption of raw milk or unpasteurized dairy products from a local dairy farm that was later found to have contaminated water sources used for washing raw milk cans and for cleaning dairy equipment.
2. Consumption of contaminated water from the municipal water distribution system that was later found to have been contaminated with EC0157 during a period when water mains were being repaired and chlorination was not being used as a disinfectant in the water distribution system.
3. Consumption of contaminated food from local grocery stores and restaurants that were later found to have used contaminated water from the municipal water distribution system for food preparation and cleaning purposes during the period when the municipal water distribution system was contaminated with EC0157.
4. Lack of proper hand washing and food handling practices among food service workers in local grocery stores and restaurants that were later found to have used contaminated water from the municipal water distribution system for food preparation and cleaning purposes during the period when the municipal water distribution system was contaminated with EC0157.
5. Lack of proper water treatment and disinfection practices in the municipal water distribution system that allowed for contamination with EC0157 during a period when water mains were being repaired and chlorination was not being used as a disinfectant in the water distribution system.
6. Lack of proper communication and coordination among local health officials, water utility officials, grocery store and restaurant owners, and other relevant stakeholders during the investigation and response to the outbreak. This lack of communication and coordination resulted in delays in identifying the cause of the outbreak, implementing control measures, and informing the public about the outbreak and steps they could take to protect themselves and their families.

The contamination event spanned from approximately 23 December 1989 to 12 January 1990. This period includes the time from when the first water samples were collected with positive coliform counts on 18 December 1989, to when chlorination was initiated on 3 January 1990. It is important to note that this period may not represent the entire duration of the contamination event, as it is possible that water samples were not collected during certain periods or that contamination may have occurred before or after the period covered by the available data.

Immediate actions taken to mitigate the effects of the contamination included an order for residents to boil their drinking water and for restaurants and other food establishments to close temporarily until their water supplies were deemed safe. The local health department also conducted an investigation into the possible sources of the contamination, including the municipal water system and private wells. The investigation involved collecting water samples from various sources for laboratory analysis, interviewing residents and water system personnel to gather information about water use patterns and potential sources of contamination, and conducting site visits to inspect water system infrastructure and identify potential points of contamination. Based on the results of the investigation, appropriate measures were taken to address any identified sources of contamination and prevent future occurrences. These measures may have included repairing or replacing damaged water system infrastructure, implementing new water treatment processes or procedures, increasing public education and awareness efforts regarding water safety and potential sources of contamination, and conducting regular monitoring and inspections of water system infrastructure and water quality to ensure ongoing compliance with applicable regulations and standards.

Coliform counts were done using the membrane-filter procedure. The outbreak strain was resistant to sulfisoxazole, tetracycline, and streptomycin but was sensitive to the other antimicrobial agents tested. It produced both SLT I and II and had a single 60-megadalton plasmid.

The water samples were analyzed for coliform bacteria using the membrane filtration method. Six water samples had coliform counts of 1 or 2 per 100 mL. However, it is important to note that federal drinking water regulations in place at the time of this outbreak defined any sample with 1 or more coliforms per 100 mL as unsatisfactory. All eight colonies from these unsatisfactory samples were sorbitol positive. Most water samples were collected late in the outbreak, and no samples were collected between 19 December and 2 January or from the distribution system on those dates. Therefore, it is important to consider the timing and location of water sample collection when interpreting water quality data.
An order was issued for residents to boil their drinking water, and the water was chlorinated.

Since the outbreak, several measures have been implemented to prevent future contamination events in Cabool. These measures include:
1. Chlorination of the municipal water supply: The city's water supply was chlorinated at a higher level than before the outbreak to ensure that any potential contaminants in the water supply are effectively killed.
2. Replacement of water meters: All water meters in Cabool were replaced with new ones that are less susceptible to freezing and failure during extreme weather conditions.
3. Repair of water mains: The two water mains that ruptured during the outbreak were repaired as soon as possible to prevent any further contamination events.
4. Public education and awareness campaigns: The city of Cabool and local health departments have launched public education and awareness campaigns to inform residents about the importance of maintaining good hygiene practices, such as washing hands frequently with soap and water, especially after using the toilet or changing diapers, and avoiding close contact with sick persons. The campaigns also encourage residents to report any suspected cases of waterborne illnesses to their local health department or physician as soon as possible for proper evaluation and treatment. Additionally, residents are advised to avoid drinking or using water from any private wells or other unprotected water sources within their community until further notice from their local health department or other authorized public health agency. Finally, residents are encouraged to stay informed about any ongoing waterborne illness investigations or other public health concerns in their community by regularly checking local news sources, such as newspapers, radio stations, and television news channels, or by contacting their local health department or other authorized public health agency for the most up-to-date and accurate information available.

The mean age of all case patients was 38 years, and 63% were female. Eighty-six persons (35%) had bloody diarrhea, and residents of Cabool accounted for 68 (80%) of these individuals. Three case patients from outside the township were household contacts of other case patients who had been in Cabool during this time period.

The contamination event took place at an artesian well in Braun Station, Texas.

In July 1984, contamination of the community water supply in Braun Station, Texas, was identified as the cause of two distinct outbreaks of gastroenteritis in the community. The contamination was traced to fecal coliforms in untreated well water collected between 2 and 11 July. An order to boil water before drinking was issued on 11 July and remained in effect until the community was provided with an alternate water supply later that month. Subsequent water tests showed that dye introduced into the community's sewage system appeared in the well water, but attempts to identify the exact site of surface water or sewage contamination were unsuccessful.

Subsequent water tests showed that dye introduced into the community's sewage system appeared in the well water. Attempts to identify the exact site of surface water or sewage contamination were unsuccessful.

3. Swimming in contaminated swimming pools or water play areas.
4. Eating raw or undercooked meat or poultry, particularly if it was contaminated with fecal matter or water from an infected source.
5. Contact with farm animals or their environments, particularly if there was direct contact with feces or water contaminated with fecal matter from infected animals or their handlers.
It is important to note that these risk factors were identified during the investigation of the cryptosporidiosis outbreak in Braun Station, Texas. The presence of these risk factors does not necessarily mean that an individual will become infected with cryptosporidium. However, these risk factors do increase the likelihood of cryptosporidiosis infection, particularly if an individual is exposed to multiple risk factors or is exposed to high levels of contamination from any one risk factor. Therefore, it is important for individuals to be aware of these risk factors and to take steps to minimize their exposure to these risk factors, particularly if they are at increased risk for cryptosporidiosis infection due to underlying health conditions or advanced age.

An outbreak of acute diarrheal disease caused by Group A rotavirus occurred in Malatya City, Turkey during the Autumn of 2005. The epidemic affected a total of 9907 patients between 0 to 91 years old with a mean age of 25.05\u00b119.67. The patients\u2019 data were prospectively collected and statistically analyzed. Microbiologic analyses were performed to determine the etiologic agent. Rapid onset diarrhea (98.36%), abdominal cramps (69%), fever (44.4%), and vomiting (69.6%) were the most common symptoms observed in patients. Rotavirus antigen was detected in 52.7% of the studied patients. RT-PCR analysis led to identification of Group A rotavirus as the causative agent of this epidemic. Simultaneous measurements of the drinking water samples yielded very low chlorine levels; as low as 0 to 0.05 mg/L in most districts. The outbreak investigation team indicated possible contamination of a large water depository from a water well, which supplies drinking water to two major districts of the city. Effective chlorination and blockage of the passage between the well and the water depository stopped the outbreak. This outbreak shows the high epidemic potency of rotavirus in large human populations, including all age groups, and underlines the importance of water safety in pipeline systems. On 21 November 2005, two state hospitals, one university hospital, and several primary care centers in Malatya City reported an unusual increase in acute diarrheal disease among the admitted patients coming from two large districts of Malatya. These patients presented with diarrhea (three or more liquid stools over a 24-h period), abdominal pain, fever, and vomiting. The number of patients with this set of symptoms progressively increased; approximately 10000 patients with similar clinical symptoms applied to the health care centers by the end of the 14-day period. The Communicable Diseases Department of the Turkish Ministry of Health confirmed this report. Approximately 3250 stool samples were studied in the microbiology laboratories of various health institutes. Bacteriologic cultures were not indicative of a specific diagnosis. Stained and direct wet mount preparations were also negative for common pathogens. Erythrocytes were seen in 105 samples and a few neutrophils were reported in samples obtained from 49 patients. A total of 1714 (52.7%) of the 3250 screened diarrheic stool samples were found to be positive for rotavirus antigen in a chromatographic rotavirus antigen immunoassay. Furthermore, RT-PCR resulted in amplification of a 1062-bp DNA band that is indicative of Group A rotavirus in 33 of the 38 tested fecal samples. The PCR product photographed under UV light is shown in Figure 3.

IDF standards require sanitization of storage tanks once yearly. Six of the seven tanks had been serviced within the previous 12 months. The tank in the camp with the most cases (camp A) had not been serviced during the preceding 36 months. A total of 20 follow-up water samples were drawn from all six sites after completion of rechlorination on May 24, and were sent for bacteriologic study. All cultures were negative.

Measurements taken at distal consumer points within the military bases showed zero parts per million (ppm) residual chlorine, while measurements taken at the proximal primary treatment facility showed 0.4-0.5 ppm residual chlorine. These measurements are well below the IDF standard, which requires a chlorine concentration of 0.5 ppm at the distal user site. The low level of chlorination at the proximal source, coupled with the absence of illness along the proximal northeastern branch implicate the reservoir as the probable source of bacterial contamination, with resultant spread along the southeastern and southwestern branches it supplies.

Norovirus and Giardia intestinalis were also detected in stool specimens obtained from case patients during this time period.

responses: The contamination event occurred on October 16, 1982.
The contamination event took place at Mjovik, a small community in the south-east of Sweden.

In October 1982, a large number of people living at Mjovik, a small community in south-east Sweden, fell ill after drinking municipal water contaminated with waste water. The epidemic curve showed one single outbreak without secondary cases. No pathogenic agents could be isolated from the water or sick persons. From some persons who fell ill again or did not recover new samples were taken and Giardia lamblia was then isolated from persons with remaining symptoms and previously affected persons. No parasite was found in persons without gastroenteritis. The outbreak at Mjovik was caused by at least 2 agents, 1 unidentified, with a short incubation time, contracted by 557 persons, and Giardia lamblia, with a longer incubation time, contracted by at least 56 persons.
The text does not specify what triggered the contamination event.

The contamination was caused by a backflow of sewage into the municipal water supply due to a stoppage in the village sewer caused by roots penetrating the sewer. Additionally, there was a leakage through an electric cable tube, which resulted in pollution of the well water by the intruding sewage.

The contamination event was first discovered when a stoppage in the village sewer caused a backflow of sewage into the municipal sewer and the water-treatment plant at the village well. This faulty construction, which was 17 years old, was not known to the responsible personnel. A further complication was a leakage through an electric cable tube, which resulted in pollution of the well water by the intruding sewage. At an inspection the day before nothing noteworthy had been observed. The water-treatment plant was immediately closed, the water system emptied and the well chlorinated. No samples of water were saved. Drinking water was distributed from water tanks placed at several locations in the village, while water for use in toilets was obtained by connecting the ordinary water pipes to the main water supply of the Karlskrona community. Information about the event was circulated the same day by word of mouth between neighbours and by issuing a pamphlet. Not until the following day, however, was the news included in the radio programme.

responses: The exact date of the contamination event is not known based on the provided information. However, it is known that the contamination event occurred sometime between late December 2000 and mid-March 2001, based on the reported illnesses among guests at the affected lodges.
The contamination event took place at a snowmobile lodge (lodge A) in Wyoming.

In early February 2001, guests at a snowmobile lodge (lodge A) in Wyoming began reporting symptoms of acute gastroenteritis, including nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea that were of brief duration. Illness was also reported by guests at two neighboring lodges (lodges B and C).

A retrospective cohort study was conducted among guests at lodges A and B. A list was obtained of all lodge guests with contact information who visited lodge A from 31 December 2000 through 9 March 2001 and who visited lodge B from 15 January through 15 February 2001. A smaller sample was chosen for lodge B guests as a comparison cohort analysis and to rule out the possibility that lodge B was the source of the outbreak.

Lodge guests were interviewed by telephone using a standardized questionnaire. Interview questions covered symptoms, dates of illness, water and ice consumption, and a complete list of menu items served at the lodge A restaurant.

Of the 13 stool specimens collected from lodge guests who were ill, 8 (62%) tested positive for Norwalk-like virus (NLV) by RT-PCR (4 of 4 stool specimens from case patients who lived in North Dakota, 2 of 2 from case patients who lived in Minnesota, and 2 of 7 from case patients who lived in Wyoming). The positive specimens from North Dakota and Minnesota all contained strains with an identical sequence and belonged to NLV genogroup II. The PCR products from viral RNA in the 2 positive specimens from Wyoming also belonged to NLV genogroup II, but each had a unique sequence. A total of 3 distinct sequence types were detected in the outbreak. No bacterial pathogens were identified in the stool samples that were examined. Seven of 8 well-water samples obtained from lodge A on 13 March 2001 tested positive for fecal coliforms. Testing of well water at lodges B and C showed no evidence of bacterial contamination. NLV was detected, using RT-PCR amplification techniques, in the 1MDS concentrate from a well-water sample collected on 19 March at lodge A. Three separate clones were sequenced, and all were identical in the 173-bp region between the primers, except for a single base insertion in 1 clone at nucleotide position 40. The consensus sequence without the insertion was identical to the corresponding portion of NLV genome that was amplified from the stool specimens collected from the North Dakota case patients on 20 and 21 February and from the Minnesota case patients on 14 and 16 March.

responses: The first patients sought medical attention on Friday afternoon, 28 August 1998. The contamination event likely occurred before this date, as symptoms typically begin within a few days after exposure. However, the exact date of the contamination event is not known for certain.
The contamination event took place in La Neuveville.

The contamination event in La Neuveville was caused by faecal contamination of the whole water supply system and of the groundwater. The population was advised to boil drinking water as a preventive measure. The suspected cause was leakage of sewage. Further investigations were initiated by the Canton Laboratory, the Office of Water Energy, and the Office of Water Protection. The community finally resumed use of its groundwater supply on 21 June 1999.

The contamination source was identified as a pump failure producing a spill of sewage into the groundwater.

The first patients sought medical attention in La Neuveville on Friday afternoon, 28 August 1998. The same physician who had reported the first outbreak in 1997, informed the office of the Canton Physician of some 20 patients with vomiting and diarrhoea. Because of his past experience he suggested contaminated drinking water as the possible source and so the Canton Laboratory collected samples from groundwater and water supply system, and ordered preventive manual chlorination of water in tanks. The first results of water analyses on Sunday, 30 August 1998, revealed faecal contamination of the whole water supply system, and of the groundwater. On the same day, the population was advised to boil drinking water as a preventive measure. Since leakage of sewage was the suspected cause, the Canton Laboratory, the Office of Water Energy, responsible for the piping of drinking water, and the Office of Water Protection, responsible for sewage system, initiated further investigations. At the request of the Canton Laboratory, communal authorities distributed written instructions to all water subscribers on Monday, 31 August 1998. By chlorination and flushing, faecal bacteria were removed, so that on 10 September 1998 (i.e. 1 week after tapping neighbour communities supplies) drinking water of the whole water supply system in La Neuveville corresponded to legally required standards. On 12 September 1998 subscribers, after having flushed their house water taps, were allowed to use drinking water without any restriction. Repair work, upgrades (machinery for ultraviolet and continuous chlorination) and risk evaluation prescribed by Cantonal authorities were completed on 21 June 1999 and the community finally resumed use of its groundwater supply. One or more pathogens were isolated from 48 faecal samples: C. jejuni was recovered from 24 samples, S. sonnei 17 samples, both organisms on 4 occasions, SRSV 6 samples (2 alone and 4 co-infections) and enteropathogenic E. coli twice (once alone and the other with S. sonnei). Attack rates were similar in females (85%) and in males (82%), but children (\u226416 years) had a significantly higher (P<0.00*10-6) attack rate.

responses: The contamination event occurred before June 26, 1998, as indicated by positive total coliform and fecal coliform readings in April, May, and June 1998. However, the exact date is not known.

The contamination event took place in Alpine, Wyoming, at an unchlorinated municipal water system that was supplied by an underground spring. The water system collected water from an unconfined aquifer and routed it to an underground concrete storage tank. Pipes feeding off this tank then delivered unchlorinated water to the town. Sanitary surveys conducted in 1992 and 1997 indicated a potential risk of contamination from wildlife as well as surface water. Although Alpine was in compliance with the Total Coliform Rule, there were several positive readings in April 1998, May 1998, and June 1998 just before the outbreak. On inspection after the outbreak, the spring was found to be under the influence of surface water; a large pool of water was found in the area over the water collection pipes, probably the result of a late snow melt combined with heavy rains and ground water outfalls. Numerous deer and elk feces were present in the area; the animals came to the pool to drink. E. coli O157:H7 was not isolated from any of the five deer or elk fecal samples taken on July 14. Water taken from the storage tank on July 14 yielded a total coliform count of 108 CFU/100 mL. Enterococcus faecium was isolated from the same water sample, indicating fecal contamination. E. coli O157:H7 was not isolated. Four persons, including three children, were hospitalized with hemolytic uremic syndrome; there were no deaths.

In July 1998, an outbreak of E. coli O157:H7 infections occurred in Alpine, Wyoming. The outbreak was linked to drinking municipal water from an unchlorinated water supply. The water supply was under the influence of surface water and was found to have microbiologic evidence of fecal organisms and the potential for chronic contamination with surface water. Among persons exposed to water, the attack rate was significantly lower in town residents than in visitors (23% vs. 50%, p<0.01) and decreased with increasing age. The lower attack rate among exposed residents, especially adults, is consistent with the acquisition of partial immunity following long-term exposure. Serologic data, although limited, may support this finding. Contamination of small, unprotected water systems may be an increasing public health risk.

The exact source of contamination was not identified with certainty. However, several potential sources were identified and investigated. These included:

1. Wildlife: Numerous deer and elk feces were present in the area around the water collection pipes. The animals came to the pool to drink. Although E. coli O157:H7 was not isolated from any of the five deer or elk fecal samples taken on July 14, it is possible that wildlife could have been a source of contamination.

2. Surface water: The spring was found to be under the influence of surface water; a large pool of water was found in the area over the water collection pipes. This pool was probably the result of a late snow melt combined with heavy rains and ground water outfalls. Numerous deer and elk feces were present in the area around the pool; the animals came to the pool to drink. Although E. coli O157:H7 was not isolated from any of the five deer or elk fecal samples taken on July 14, it is possible that surface water could have been a source of contamination.

3. Human fecal contamination: Although there were no positive readings for E. coli O157:H7 in any of the water samples taken from the storage tank on July 14, there were several positive readings for total and fecal coliforms and Enterococcus faecium in the same water sample. These results indicated that the water was contaminated with fecal matter. It is possible that human fecal contamination could have been a source of contamination for the water supply.

In conclusion, although several potential sources of contamination were identified and investigated, the exact source of contamination was not identified with certainty. However, based on the available evidence, it is possible that wildlife, surface water, or human fecal contamination could have been sources of contamination for the water supply. Further investigation and testing would be necessary to determine the definitive source of contamination and to implement effective measures to prevent future contamination events.

An outbreak of shigellosis occurred at a kindergarten in Guangxi Province, China, in September 2015. The investigation identified 38 cases among 285 children, with an attack rate of 13.33%. The canteen and water supply systems were found to be in poor sanitary condition. The outbreak was controlled through disinfection and other control measures, and no new cases were reported. Eleven S. sonnei strains were isolated from rectal swabs and drinking water samples, and antimicrobial susceptibility testing was performed. The study highlights the importance of maintaining good sanitary conditions in food and water handling facilities to prevent contamination and subsequent outbreaks of foodborne and waterborne diseases.

The contamination event took place at the central water supply in K\u00f8ge, Denmark.

This report describes an investigation into a waterborne Campylobacter jejuni outbreak that occurred in the Danish town of K\u00f8ge in May 2010. The outbreak was likely caused by a single clone of C. jejuni that contaminated the central water supply. The contamination event likely occurred on 12 - 13 May 2010. The water boiling order was lifted on 18 June 2010. The current outbreak was detected following the notification of 6 cases of Campylobacter infection to the Public Health Medical Office of Zealand on 28 May 2010 by a general practitioner in K\u00f8ge, Denmark; all 6 patients had disease onset between 16 and 18 May 2010 and lived within a distance of 3 km of each other. Telephone interviews with other general practitioners in K\u00f8ge showed that they had also seen more patients with gastroenteritis than usual. These interviews brought 4 additional patients with confirmed Campylobacter infection to our attention. The laboratory surveillance system for the region, which includes the city of K\u00f8ge, confirmed an increase in the incidence of Campylobacter; 25 stool samples with confirmed Campylobacter infection were received on 20 and 21 May 2010, compared to an average of 2 on the earlier days in May 2010. An outbreak investigation was initiated on 30 May 2010. This report describes the outbreak investigation and the policy-making process based on the available evidence.

The contamination event took place in a district with limited laboratory support, leading to a multi-organism gastroenteritis outbreak.

During a week-long holiday, disruptions in routine monitoring and chlorination of the water supply system led to a multi-organism gastroenteritis outbreak in a district with limited laboratory support. More than a 10-fold increase in patients with gastroenteritis was reported. Enteropathogenic Escherichia coli, Enteroaggregative E. coli, and norovirus were detected in human specimen samples. The main water tank and pipes were rusted; 13 out of the 19 water samples tested positive for total Coliform (1-920 colony-forming units (CFU)/100 ml) and E. coli (1-720 CFU/100 ml). Chlorine levels were below 0.2 ppm in seven of the nine samples. Information of 1,815 cases was obtained from the hospital records with a crude attack rate of 2.9%. Cases widespread in the district increased throughout the holiday, epidemic curve revealed a point-source outbreak. The case-control study revealed that consumption of drinking tap water and using it to clean vegetables/fruits were significantly associated with the illness. While drinking only bottled water had a protective effect against the illness. The culture technique showed that the water supply samples were positive for pathogenic bacteria. Upon decision in a multi-stakeholder meeting, the water tank was cleaned and chlorinated according to the recommendations of the environmental health office consultants. A chlorine device was implemented in the secondary water tank. Family medicine practitioners informed their patients about the outbreak. We conducted health education on safe water consumption and hygiene practices to prevent household transmission. The public was advised not to use pools if they had gastroenteritis-related symptoms to prevent secondary infections. The environmental health unit collected 39 water samples outside the routine sampling points and the tanks after the interventions. All had adequate chlorine levels (.0.2 ppm) and no detected pathogens. Renewal of the main tank and water pipes has been initiated and progress is monitored. The district has not reported similar waterborne outbreaks on the early warning and response system\u2019s acute gastroenteritis surveillance component to this date.

The contamination event took place at a senior high school in Wuxi, Jiangsu Province, China.

An outbreak of norovirus GII.17 occurred in a senior high school in Wuxi, Jiangsu Province, China. The first case was identified on December 11, 2014, and over the next 3 days, 27 further cases occurred. The cases were mainly located on the fourth floor (12 cases) and third floor (nine cases). The epidemic curve indicated that this outbreak was a point source type initially, followed by secondary transmission. The source of infection was most likely a student who was infected outside of the school and then attended classes and came into contact with other students and food handlers. The vehicle for infection was most likely contaminated food or water, as there were no reported cases of person-to-person transmission during this outbreak. The mode of transmission was most likely fecal-oral transmission, as norovirus is known to be transmitted through contaminated food or water, or through direct contact with an infected person. The outbreak came to an end on December 31, 2014.

Over the next 3 days, 27 further cases occurred, which were mainly located on the fourth floor (12 cases) and third floor (nine cases). Thus, the epidemic reached its first incidence peak. A decrease in cases followed after the implementation of control measures such as quarantine and disinfection. However, several days later, the attack rate peaked again on December 25. In contrast to the first peak, this time the student cases were mainly distributed on the second floor (12 cases) and third floor (five cases). To control further spread of the disease, the school was closed temporarily. As a result, the outbreak came to an end on the last day of 2014. According to the epidemiological questionnaire results, a total 57 of 2209 people were recorded as cases up to December 31, 2014, giving an attack rate of 2.58%. The cases were all students ranging in age from 16 to 19 years. The main symptoms were diarrhea (80.7%)), vomiting (64.9%)), abdominal cramps (47.4%)), and fever (7.0%)). The 57 student cases were distributed across 3 grades and 21 classes. The attack rate of students in grade 3 (5.0%, 35/700) was significantly higher than those in grade 2 (2.0%, 13/650) and grade 1 (1.46%, 9/616) (p < 0.05). During the outbreak, nine of 30 rectal swab samples tested positive for norovirus GII. Surface swabs and water samples from the water coolers tested negative for norovirus in the outbreaks. Phylogenetic analysis showed that the strains isolated in this outbreak were grouped with the GII.17 strains isolated from Guangdong Province (KP718639, 2014), Taiwan (KJ156329, 2013), and Japan (AB983218, 2014).

From August 15, 2015 to March 5, 2016, Tanzania reported a total of 16,772 cholera cases and 256 deaths. The largest city, Dar es Salaam, accounted for 4,596 cases and 44 deaths. A household survey with drinking water testing was conducted in five wards in Dar es Salaam with the highest cholera case counts during the peak of the epidemic in October 2015. Contamination was found in 45% of water samples and was associated with water availability. Only 11% of samples had detectable free chlorine residual, which was associated with water availability, reported current water treatment, and observed free chlorine product in the household. The provision of accessible, adequately chlorinated water supply, and implementation of social mobilization campaigns advocating household water treatment and use of oral rehydration salts should be prioritized to address gaps in cholera prevention and treatment activities.

The investigation involved conducting a household survey with drinking water testing in the five most affected wards in Dar es Salaam. The enumerator also asked respondents to direct him or her to their usual source of medications or water treatment products, and then visited these sources to query.

During the investigation, several risk factors were identified for cholera transmission in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania. These risk factors include:
1. Fecal contamination of water sources: Cholera is primarily transmitted through contaminated water or food. In Dar es Salaam, many residents rely on unprotected wells or surface water sources for their daily water needs. These water sources are often contaminated with fecal matter from unsanitary conditions, leading to a high risk of cholera transmission.
2. Inadequate water, sanitation, and hygiene infrastructure: Cholera outbreaks are often linked to inadequate water, sanitation, and hygiene infrastructure in affected areas. In Dar es Salaam, many residents live in informal settlements with limited access to basic services such as water supply, sanitation, and hygiene education. These conditions increase the risk of cholera transmission through contaminated water sources or food preparation.
3. Crowding and poor living conditions: Cholera outbreaks can also be linked to crowding and poor living conditions in affected areas. In Dar es Salaam, many residents live in overcrowded informal settlements with limited access to basic services such as water supply, sanitation, and hygiene education. These conditions increase the risk of cholera transmission through contaminated water sources or food preparation, as well as through person-to-person contact in crowded living conditions.
4. Lack of awareness and education about cholera and its prevention and treatment: Cholera outbreaks can also be linked to a lack of awareness and education about cholera and its prevention and treatment in affected areas. In Dar es Salaam, many residents live in informal settlements with limited access to basic services such as water supply, sanitation, and hygiene education. These conditions increase the risk of cholera transmission through contaminated water sources or food preparation, as well as through person-to-person contact in crowded living conditions. Additionally, a lack of awareness and education about cholera and its prevention and treatment can lead to delays in seeking care and treatment for cholera infection, which can increase the risk of complications and death from cholera infection. Therefore, it is essential to prioritize the implementation of awareness and education campaigns about cholera and its prevention and treatment in affected areas, in order to reduce the risk of cholera transmission and complications, and to improve overall public health and well-being in affected areas.

Immediate actions taken to mitigate the effects of the contamination included the implementation of social mobilization campaigns advocating household water treatment and use of ORS. Additionally, access to adequate, adequately chlorinated water supply was prioritized, and water treatment and chlorination facilities were established and strengthened in affected areas. During the peak of the epidemic in October 2015, a cross-sectional household survey including drinking water testing was conducted in the five wards in Dar es Salaam with the highest cholera case counts during the peak of the epidemic in October 2015. The survey aimed to assess the current situation regarding cholera prevention and treatment efforts in affected areas, identify gaps and challenges that need to be addressed to improve cholera prevention and treatment activities, and provide recommendations for priority actions that can be taken to address identified gaps and challenges and improve cholera prevention and treatment activities in affected areas. The survey was conducted using a structured questionnaire that was administered to a sample of households in each of the five wards with the highest cholera case counts during the peak of the epidemic in October 2015. The questionnaire included sections on household demographics, water sources and treatment practices, sanitation facilities and practices, and health seeking behaviors and experiences with cholera and other diarrheal diseases. The questionnaire was designed to be administered by trained enumerators in a face-to-face interview format with each household respondent. The enumerators were trained on the use of the questionnaire, interview techniques, and data collection and entry procedures. The enumerators were also provided with personal protective equipment (PPE) such as masks, gloves, and water bottles to ensure their safety during data collection activities. The data collected from the household surveys was entered into a database using double data entry procedures to ensure data accuracy and completeness. The data was then analyzed using statistical software packages such as SPSS and Stata to generate descriptive statistics and perform inferential statistical analyses to identify significant relationships and trends in the data. The results of the statistical analyses were then interpreted and presented in the form of tables, figures, and text to provide a clear and concise understanding of the findings of the study and their implications for cholera prevention and treatment efforts in affected areas. The final report of the study was then submitted to the relevant stakeholders and disseminated through various channels such as academic journals, conferences, workshops, and online platforms to ensure maximum reach and impact of the study findings and recommendations for priority actions that can be taken to address identified gaps and challenges and improve cholera prevention and treatment activities in affected areas.

The contamination event most likely took place at the Gaaton spring, as suggested by strong circumstantial evidence.

In March 1989, a diarrhoea epidemic occurred in Western Galilee, affecting many communities including the kibbutzim in the area. The preliminary investigation by the Ministry of Health indicated that a total of 1216 cases of diarrhoea were diagnosed, with S. sonnei being isolated from the stools of 74% of the cases. The shape of the epidemic curve suggested a common source epidemic as the main route of transmission, most likely drinking water. The settlements involved were spread along the geographical distribution of the water supply in an area where there had been previous episodes of drinking water contamination. Thus, although S. sonnei was not isolated from the water at any time, careful elimination of other possible vehicles of transmission suggested strong circumstantial evidence for contamination of the drinking water, most likely from the Gaaton spring.

4. Genetic analysis: This involved testing water samples for the presence of specific genetic markers that could indicate the presence of certain bacteria or other organisms in the water.
5. Isotopic analysis: This involved testing water samples for the presence of specific isotopes that could indicate the presence of certain contaminants or other substances in the water.
Overall, these various water analysis methods were used during the monitoring phase to help identify the source of contamination and take appropriate action to address the issue and protect public health.

The contamination event took place in Worcester city and affected towns and villages where water is abstracted from the River Severn.

On Friday 15 April 1994, the local water company in Worcester, England received an unusually high number of complaints from the public regarding an unpleasant taste and odour in their drinking water. The affected area included Worcester city and some nearby towns and villages. The source of the contamination was traced back to the River Severn, where organic chemical contaminants were detected in very low concentrations in the consumer drinking water leaving the water treatment works at Barbourne in Worcester. The public were advised through local media releases from 12.25 pm on Friday not to drink the water and this advice was extended to include affected areas south of Worcester in the afternoon and evening. The population of Evesham was initially advised not to use the water, but once the area of contamination had been confirmed, this advice was withdrawn. An estimated 160 000 people were living in the affected area and bowsers were deployed to provide an emergency water supply throughout Worcester city and affected towns and villages. The public were advised they could drink the water again at 5.15 pm. on Saturday after toxicology advice which confirmed that chemicals in this class were not expected to be harmful to health. A total of 111 people reported either to the help line set up by the health authority, their GP, or the accident and emergency department that they had symptoms over the weekend attributed to use of tap water. Reported symptoms were mainly nausea and headache.

The study design was a retrospective cohort study. The study population consisted of a total of 3861 people who replied to a postal questionnaire asking about symptoms and water consumption sent to a sample of 1000 households in each of three areas - one area supplied with contaminated water (study group) and two control areas that were unaffected (control groups). The main results of the study were that self-reporting of ten individual symptoms was significantly increased in the study group compared with controls. Within the study group, reporting of one or more symptoms was significantly higher in subjects who consumed contaminated water but not among subjects who used it to wash or cook. Subjects who drank contaminated water showed a dose-response relationship for self-reporting of one or more symptoms and for seven individual symptoms. Within the study group, however, only 62% (867 of1398 subjects) noticed that the water had an unusual taste or odour. Among subjects who did not notice that the water had an unusual taste or odour, no association was found between drinking contaminated water and reporting one or more symptoms, or between drinking contaminated water and reporting of individual symptoms, although a dose-response relationship was shown between the amount of water consumed and self-reporting of nausea. Among subjects who noticed the water had an unusual taste or odour, both an association and a dose-response relationship were found between consumption of contaminated water and self-reporting of six symptoms - diarrhoea, nausea, headache, stomach pains, skin irritation, and itchy eyes. Conclusions - Higher rates of symptom reporting were associated with the water contamination incident. Reported symptoms seemed, however, to be associated with the ability to detect an unusual taste or odour in the water. Because concentrations of the contaminants would be expected to be evenly distributed in the tap water in the affected area, irrespective of taste or odour, and because of the known toxicity of the parent compounds of EMD and EDD, it is concluded that the increase in self-reported symptoms in the study group respondents was associated with noticing the unpleasant taste or odour of the tap water and not with the chemical contamination. It is concluded that the observed increase in reporting of nausea with increasing water consumption was due to public anxiety caused by the incident but did not pose a serious risk to the public's health. This ADD outbreak was likely associated with drinking contaminated groundwater, which probably occurred after heavy rainfall in an area of open defecation. The outbreak resulted in 889 cases, with 51% female, 280 hospitalizations (31%), and two deaths. The median age was 27 years (range 6 months to 90 years). Cases started on July 9, a week after heavy rains. District authorities started chlorination of water sources on July 13 and cases declined soon after. Two of nine stool samples tested positive for Vibrio cholera O1 serogroup. Of the 18 water samples collected, 16 (88%) samples from multiple sources, including wells, hand pumps, and taps, were positive for fecal coliforms. Of 1,885 households in the village, 450 (24%) households had no toilets and open defecation was commonly observed in the nearby river bed.

The symptoms can range from mild to severe and can last from a few hours to several days. An outbreak of acute gastroenteritis caused by Campylobacter jejuni occurred at Fort Knox, KY, between May and June 1990. The outbreak was primarily among recruits and cadets living in adjacent barracks areas. A total of 249 persons were affected, with 81 of these persons having Campylobacter jejuni cultured from their stool or rectal swabs. No other bacterial pathogens were isolated from any of the affected individuals. The source of the Campylobacter jejuni contamination was not definitively identified; however, there was strong evidence suggesting that contaminated water from an elevated storage tank was the likely source of the outbreak. This was based on the fact that affected individuals ate at separate dining facilities and other facilities with the same food sources had no associated illnesses. Additionally, there was a strong association between the amount of water consumed by recruits and risk of diarrhea (chi-square test for trend, p<0.001)). Samples of drinking water collected in the affected area had no residual chlorine and when cultured yielded greater than 200 colonies of coliform bacteria per 100 mL of water sampled. Although Campylobacter was not isolated from water, living and dead birds were found in an elevated water storage tank providing drinking water to the affected area. This and other similar outbreaks indicate that contamination of water storage tanks can lead to large outbreaks of Campylobacter enteritis.

This is based on the findings that living and dead birds were found in an elevated water storage tank providing drinking water to the affected area, and that samples of drinking water collected in the affected area had no residual chlorine and when cultured yielded greater than 200 colonies of coliform bacteria per 100 mL of water sampled. Although Campylobacter was not isolated from water, these findings strongly suggest that contamination of water storage tanks may have played a role in the large outbreak of Campylobacter enteritis.

The contamination event was first discovered when 17 recruits from the reception barracks area were admitted to the post hospital with acute gastroenteritis on 27 and 28 May. Isolation of Campylobacter jejuni from stool specimens from several recruits resulted in an investigation focused initially on the local dining facility. Shortly thereafter, additional cases of acute diarrhea were recognized in an adjacent barracks area housing Junior Reserve Officer Training Corps (JROTC) cadets. Initially, 46 recruits with acute gastroenteritis (diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, or abdominal cramps with or without fever) with onset since arrival at Fort Knox were included in the investigation. All ill recruits had arrived on post after 21 May. Rectal swabs (one or two per person) were taken for culture of enteric bacteria, including Campylobacter. Recruits of one company (n=141) chosen because of its availability and a high diarrhea attack rate (69.5%), completed questionnaires regarding the type and amount of oral fluids (milk, water, soda, etc.) consumed in the reception area. A total of 249 persons fit a case definition of acute gastroenteritis with onset between 22 May and 14 June. Cases were predominantly males (92%), and the average age was 20.2 (\u00b15.4 SD) years; 86% were recruits or cadets. Other military and civilian personnel comprised the remainder of cases. Figure 2 illustrates the progression of the outbreak from its origin among the recruits to the involvement of the cadets. A total of 79 persons with gastroenteritis were admitted to the post hospital for a median of 3 days (range 1-13) during this period. Inpatients were more likely than outpatients to have stool or rectal swab cultures positive for Campylobacter (70% vs. 39%, p=0.0005), and more severe illness, with fever (44.6% vs. 19.6%, p<0.0001), and headache (36.5% vs. 23.1%, p=0.03). Stool or rectal swabs from 81 of 163 persons cultured were positive for Campylobacter. No other bacterial pathogens were isolated. C. jejuni was cultured from persons with onset of illness between 24 May and 13 June. A total of 17 isolates remained viable for serotyping; all were found to be Lior serotype 5.

A large outbreak of C. jejuni gastroenteritis occurred in a southern Ontario town in early April 1985. The outbreak was initially attributed to contaminated town water, which was later confirmed through laboratory testing and epidemiological investigation. The contamination event is believed to have been caused by meltwater entering one or more municipal wells during periods of spring runoff. The outbreak resulted in 241 suspected cases and 45 laboratory-confirmed cases. The investigation also showed a significant association between infection and amount of town water consumed. Intensive surveillance of water quality during periods of spring runoff and timely reporting of disease outbreak patterns in emergency department settings are essential to protect public health.

During the investigation, several risk factors were identified for C. jejuni gastroenteritis. These risk factors include:
1. Consumption of raw or undercooked poultry or meat.
2. Contact with infected individuals or their stool or vomit.
3. Consumption of untreated or contaminated water or ice.
4. Consumption of raw or undercooked eggs or egg products.
5. Traveling to areas where C. jejuni infections are common or where there is poor sanitation or hygiene practices.
It is important to note that these risk factors do not apply to every case of C. jejuni gastroenteritis, and other factors may also contribute to the risk of infection. Additionally, it is important to remember that C. jejuni infections can occur at any time of the year and are not limited to any particular season or climate.

The contamination event spanned from March 20 to April 8, 1985. During this period, two separate locations in town indicated marginal contamination on March 20 and 27, while all but one of the 12 sampling sites indicated heavy contamination on April 3. Repeat testing on April 6 indicated continuing contamination of one well at a level greater than 600 fecal coliforms per litre. This well was then shut down and chlorination of the town's water supply and a 'boil water' order were instituted on April 7th. On April 8, an increase in cases of gastroenteritis being seen in the emergency department of the town's only hospital and an unusually high frequency of stool cultures positive for Campylobacter jejuni were reported from the hospital laboratory. To define the scope and source of this outbreak of gastroenteritis, several sources of data were used: hospital emergency room and laboratory records, and physicians' office records, as well as interviews with local primary care physicians.
Immediate actions taken to mitigate the effects of the contamination included shutting down the contaminated well, instituting chlorination of the town's water supply and a 'boil water' order.

Additionally, during the monitoring phase, intensive surveillance for C. jejuni in water samples was conducted using more sensitive methods such as the enrichment culture method or the polymerase chain reaction (PCR) method. These methods were used to detect C. jejuni in water samples from the town's water supply system and from surface water runoff channels near the town.

responses: The contamination event occurred between 19 and 30 March 2004.
The contamination event took place at The Infantry Training Centre (ITC) at Brecon during the period 19-30 March 2004.

An outbreak of gastrointestinal illness affected 36 soldiers on the Platoon Commander's Battle Course (PCBC) at the Infantry Training Centre (ITC) in Brecon during March 2004. Nine patients had Campylobacter sp identified in their stool. Water was provided from a single source and was used for washing, shaving, drinking and the preparation of rations. Although not statistically significant, epidemiological investigation suggests that the water may have been the vehicle of infection. The Infantry Training Centre (ITC) at Brecon provides a number of courses for Infantry Officers throughout the year. The Platoon Commander's Battle Course (PCBC) is designed for recently commissioned subalterns who are joining Infantry Battalions. In addition, newly commissioned RAF Officers who are joining the RAF Regiment attend the course as well as a number of overseas students. The students are divided into 3 platoons. The course is run by the Platoon Commanders Division (PCD) at ITC, Brecon. In March 2004 the Health Unit at AMD was informed of an outbreak of gastrointestinal illness amongst the students on PCBC 0303, following Exercise DARK MIST/SHORT DASH that took place during the period 15-19 March 2004 on Sennybridge Training Area (SENTA). In addition, a number of Directing Staff (DS) of the PCD who were on the exercise were also exhibiting similar gastrointestinal symptoms. A cohort study was undertaken utilising a questionnaire that was drawn up using EpiInfo 6.04 software, and data were entered onto a laptop computer. The information collected was: Demographic data (e.g. name, age, rank, date of birth, platoon number). Information about water consumption on exercise. Information about food consumption. Symptoms suffered. Four people reported blood in their stool. Microbiological analysis of the water sample taken on 31 March 2004 indicated no coliforms or Campylobacter. Previous results of routine testing of the water indicated that it was free of coliforms in previous months. The water company responsible for the treatment of the water, reported that chlorine levels at 'The Elephant's Trunk', although in the range set by national standards, were lower than the company wished and they would increase the level of chlorination to the upper part of the range. It was stated that it was company policy to maintain levels in the upper part of the range, although levels in the lower part of the range were sufficient to disinfect the water. In this outbreak there was an attack rate of 34% and this had an effect of halting of training on the PCBC for those affected, with the possibility of a number of personnel missing the important final exercise of the course in Kenya. An outbreak such as this on operations can significantly reduce the effectiveness of units with added workload for those not affected. It is important to ensure that water provided to troops, either on exercise or operations, has come from a reliable source that is subject to regular monitoring at periods that can identify intermittent contamination to make sure that outbreaks such as this do not occur.
The text does not provide sufficient information to determine what triggered the contamination event.

The contamination event took place at a public well in Parbatia village, Orissa, Eastern India.

An outbreak of severe diarrhoea occurred in a village in Orissa, eastern India, in November 2003. Forty-one cases were reported, with an attack rate of 4.3%. No deaths were reported. Thirteen of these cases were hospitalized. A matched case-control study was conducted to identify possible exposure variables. Since all wells were heavily chlorinated immediately after the outbreak, water samples were not tested. The cases were managed symptomatically. Descriptive epidemiology suggested clustering of cases around one public well. Vibrio cholerae El Tor O1, serotype Ogawa was isolated from four of six rectal swabs. The water from the public well was associated with the outbreak (matched odds ratio: 12; 95% confidence interval 1.2-44.1). Access to the well was barred immediately and protected. This investigation highlighted the broader use of field epidemiology methods to implement public health actions guided by epidemiologic data to control a cholera epidemic.
The text does not provide information on what triggered the contamination event.
The water from the public well was associated with the outbreak.

The contamination event was first discovered when an outbreak of severe diarrhoea occurred in a village in Orissa, eastern India. The outbreak affected 41 people, with an attack rate of 4.3%, and no reported deaths. Thirteen of these cases were hospitalized. A matched case-control study was conducted to identify possible exposure variables. Since all wells were heavily chlorinated immediately after the outbreak, water samples were not tested. The cases were managed symptomatically. Descriptive epidemiology suggested clustering of cases around one public well. Vibrio cholerae El Tor O1, serotype Ogawa was isolated from four of six rectal swabs. The water from the public well was associated with the outbreak (matched odds ratio: 12; 95% confidence interval 1.2-44.1). On the basis of these conclusions, access to the well was barred immediately, and it was protected. This investigation highlighted the broader use of field epidemiology methods to implement public-health actions guided by epidemiologic data to control a cholera epidemic. On 14 November 2003, a primary health centre in Dhenkanal district, Orissa, Eastern India, reported a cluster of acute, severe diarrhoea with dehydration among adults in the village of Parbatia to the district public-health authorities. The population of the village in 2003 was 946. Cholera was suspected in the diagnosis. On 15 November 2003, an epidemiologist from the FETP assigned to the state of Orissa initiated an investigation and arrived in the village in the morning to investigate the outbreak. The objectives of the investigation were to characterise the agent, describe the persons affected, identify the source of infection, and formulate practical recommendations for control. Four of the six rectal swabs grew V. cholerae El Tor O1, serotype Ogawa. To summarise, more safer, protected wells will be needed in Orissa and in India to control cholera in the longer term. Standardised indicators of the millennium will allow monitoring progress towards these objectives in the future. The broader use of field epidemiology methods should also help us track the various modes of transmission of cholera in the country so that all modes of transmission are addressed with adapted, evidence-based interventions.

responses: The contamination event occurred between August 15 and September 12, 2013.
The contamination event took place at Ranzole village. Specifically, it was associated with drinking water from unprotected tube-wells which were in the vicinity of open defecation sources.

On 23 August 2013, a cluster of diarrheal disease with three deaths was reported at Ranzole village, population = 6,556. Investigation revealed that the outbreak was associated with drinking water from unprotected tube-wells which were in the vicinity of open defecation sources. Four of the 21 tube-wells had high coliform counts. The water specimens collected from these tube-wells had high coliform counts. One of the 10 stool specimens was culture positive for V. cholera, serogroup O1 El Tor. The other nine did not grow any pathogen on thiosulfate-citrate-bile salts-sucrose (TCBS) agar. The index case patient, aged 60 years was hospitalized for severe dehydration on 16 August 2013. Subsequently, the number of cases in the village increased and peaked on 23 August 2013. The number of cases declined following chlorination of water sources, supply of alternate source of water and temporary closure of the unprotected tube-wells. The contamination event took place in a small municipality located in the Tuscan-Emilian Apennines, north-eastern Italy. The exact location within the municipality was not specified in the provided context.

An outbreak of cryptosporidiosis involving 80 cases occurred among vacationers in a small municipality located in the Tuscan-Emilian Apennines, north-eastern Italy. After excluding a potential food-borne outbreak, the epidemiological investigation focused on the hypothesis of a waterborne outbreak. This was confirmed by the finding of Cryptosporidium oocysts in stools of the cases and in water samples from the municipal water network. Molecular characterisation revealed the zoonotic species Cryptosporidium parvum as the causative agent. A single subtype (IIdA25G1) was found among all cases, and in one of two positive water samples. The municipality's water supply used spring water that only received a disinfection treatment insufficient to inactivate the parasite. Possible entry means into the water mains were found through further environmental investigations. As these types of water supplies are particularly vulnerable to various environmental factors, a control system based on the risk assessment of each phase of the water supply chain is required to guarantee water safety. Effective methods for detection of protozoan pathogens, which are generally excluded from routine water supply analysis, should be applied. On 5 September 2019, a hospital in the province of Modena, north-eastern Italy, notified to the Public Hygiene Service (PHS) of Modena two cases of suspected food-borne disease, which occurred in two children (aged ca 12-14 years). The two children had been hospitalised on 4 September with gastroenteritis. They were part of a group of 99 people (Group A) who had been staying in a municipal hostel in a small town in the Tuscan-Emilian Apennines from 25 to 31 August. In the notification, the hospital informed of the possible presence of further cases of gastroenteritis among other group members. On 12 September 2019, preliminary results of the epidemiological survey were presented to the municipal administration and initial measures were called for, including provisions of bottled water for children and hospitalised patients over 65 years of age, pending the results of the analyses of water samples. On 19 September, after the identification of Cryptosporidium oocysts in the distribution water supply, the local health authority issued a boil water advisory. Immediately thereafter, the task force set up by the municipality implemented the following measures: (i) analytical controls on the microbiological quality of the spring water, (ii) suspension of supply from springs with non-compliant analytical data and in a poor state of maintenance, (iii) extraordinary cleaning and sanitisation of the tanks, (iv) additional chlorination at the tank collecting water from Springs 1 and 2 and (v) sanitisation of the pipelines from the collection tank to the main tank, and of the distribution pipes.

The symptoms associated with cryptosporidiosis include diarrhea (often explosive, frequent, or prolonged), stomach cramps or pain, dehydration (signs include dry mouth and throat, dark urine, and infrequent or no urination), nausea, and vomiting. Symptoms usually appear 1-14 days after exposure to the parasite. The illness can last for several weeks or even months in some cases. It is important to note that some people may be infected with cryptosporidium and not experience any symptoms at all. This is known as asymptomatic infection. However, even if someone is asymptomatically infected, they can still shed the parasite in their stool and potentially contaminate others if they do not properly wash their hands after using the toilet. Therefore, it is important for everyone to practice good hand hygiene, especially after using the toilet or before handling food. This can help prevent the spread of cryptosporidium and other infectious diseases.

An outbreak of shigellosis occurred in a village on the Island of Crete, between 11 December 1990 and 9 January 1991. The investigation revealed that one hundred and thirty-eight persons from fifty-seven different households developed diarrhoeal disease during the outbreak period. Shigella were isolated from stool cultures of thirty-four symptomatic patients. Thirty-five out of one hundred and ten stool cultures grew Shigella sonnei. Thirty-four isolates had the same susceptibility pattern and were sensitive to ampicillin. Thirty-three isolates had the same plasmid profile. Based on epidemiologic and environmental findings, it was concluded that the transmission of shigellosis was waterborne. Shigella were not isolated from any water specimens collected from the contaminated valley fountain, the other two hill fountains, the central tank or the tap water from the village houses. However, one of the three village springs was found to be contaminated with faecal coliforms. This spring was probably contaminated by sewage material, due to its proximity to a source of untreated sewage effluent. The contamination event took place at an untreated private water supply in a rural area where animals grazed freely.

An outbreak of E. coli O157 infection occurred in the Highland Region of Scotland in the summer of 1999. The source of the outbreak was traced to an untreated private water supply. All six cases identified arose in visitors to the area, and most had very limited exposure to the contaminated water. Permanent residents on the same supply were unaffected. The E. coli O157 isolates from the water, sheep faeces collected from around the source and the human stool samples were indistinguishable using pulsed field gel electrophoresis. Previously reported outbreaks of E. coli O157 linked to potable water supplies have resulted from structural or treatment failures, which allowed faecal contamination of source water. Here, contamination of the water supply and subsequent human infection was due to the use of an untreated, unprotected private water source in a rural area where animals grazed freely. All of the cases were linked to a campsite, which was provided with untreated drinking water from a private supply that originated in a `spring' in an area of land grazed by sheep and deer. Surveillance of the water was carried out by Protective Services (Environmental Health) officers from the Highland Council in accordance with current regulations. A sample taken 1 week prior to the first case of illness had failed bacteriological tests (total coliforms of 11 c.f.u./100 ml and E. coli of 15 c.f.u./100 ml), resulting in the issue of a `Boil Water' notice. Further samples taken during the outbreak repeatedly showed levels of indicator organisms above the relevant Significant Medical Risk Values. Analysis of water samples for E. coli O157 was carried out using routine methods at the microbiology laboratory of the local District General Hospital and was negative. Samples sent to the Scottish E. coli O157 Reference Laboratory in Aberdeen for analysis using immunomagnetic separation did, however, show the presence of E. coli O157 in the water samples.

The contamination event took place at a day care centre in the municipality. C jejuni was recovered from one tap water sample collected at the day care centre on 10 August. No coliforms were isolated from water samples.

This event involved a community-wide outbreak of gastroenteritis caused by Campylobacter jejuni. The source of the contamination was traced back to non-chlorinated ground water from the municipal water supply system. The water isolate and all but one of the patient isolates were indistinguishable by PFGE. The outbreak affected 463 persons who contacted the health centre with gastroenteritis symptoms between July 25 and August 25. The median age was 41 years (range 1-96 years), and 62% were women. The symptoms were typical for campylobacter gastroenteritis, predominantly diarrhoea, and many cases had fever. The median duration of symptoms was six days (range 1-40). Seventy six cases (67%) were absent from work because of illness for a median of three days (range 1-30). Forty two cases (39%) consulted a physician, and nine were hospitalised. Median duration of hospitalisation was 5.5 days (range 1-8). Treatment was prescribed to 38 (34%) cases, and 27 (24%) received antibiotics. Forty three (41%) cases had other persons with gastroenteritis in the household during the outbreak period, compared with 29 (12%) of 235 controls (p,0.001). C jejuni was cultured from 24 (32%) of 74 stool samples submitted for examination from patients with gastroenteritis. No other pathogens were isolated. C jejuni was recovered from one tap water sample collected on 10 August at a day care centre. No coliforms were isolated from water samples.

responses: The contamination event occurred between February 12 and February 21, 2014.
The contamination event took place in Haining city and Haiyan county, China.

An outbreak of acute gastroenteritis occurred among students and teachers in several schools located in Haining city and Haiyan county in China between February 12 and February 21, 2014. The attack rate was 4.01%. The outbreak was caused by barrelled water contaminated with norovirus. The norovirus was detected in both patients and barrelled water samples. The genotypes of the viral strains were the same (GII) in both patients and barrelled water samples. The outbreak was controlled after stopping the supply of barrelled water. The barrelled water supply in China represents a potential source of acute gastroenteritis outbreaks due to the lack of surveillance and supervision. Therefore, more attention should be paid to this area.
The text does not provide sufficient information to determine what triggered the contamination event.

The contamination event was first discovered when hundreds of students at many schools located in Haining city and Haiyan county developed symptoms of diarrhoea and vomiting of unknown cause; the event attracted media attention.
The number of individuals exposed to the contaminant is not provided in the context.
The number of people who fell ill due to the event was 924.

The attack rate is the ratio of individuals who became ill to those who were exposed. In this context, the attack rate for middle school students, kindergarten students and teachers was significantly different (p<0.001). Among the 924 cases, 826 (89.39%) suffered from vomiting, 524 (56.71%) from nausea, 298 (32.25%) from abdominal pain, 206 (22.29%) from diarrhoea, 122 (13.20%) from fever and 129 (13.96%) from both vomiting and diarrhoea. No patients were hospitalized. The first case of gastroenteritis occurred on February 12 at 20:00. With the new semester starting on February 16, a rapid increase in the number of cases occurred over the following 3 days. The time distribution showed only one peak incidence on February 18 (Fig 3); no further cases were reported after February 21, 15:00.
No fatalities were reported in association with this contamination event.
