An epidemiological investigation was conducted to determine the cause of the pathogen, infection sources, route of transmission and risk factors. A total of 924 cases fit the definition of the probable case, including 8 cases of laboratory-confirmed norovirus infection between February 12 and February 21, 2014; the attack rate was 4.01%. Six middle schools in Haining city and 4 middle schools and 3 kindergartens in Haiyan county were involved. The attack rate for students was much higher than that for teachers. The highest and lowest attack rates for students were 10.47% and 1.22%, respectively. The grade and class distributions of the student cases were dispersed; in the schools, almost every grade had cases, with most of those grades having no more than 10 cases. A total of 11 rectal samples and 8 barrelled water samples were detected as norovirus-positive. The genotypes of the viral strains were the same (GII) in the patients and in the barrelled water. The JXCDC used immediate control measures, including surveillance, disinfection and prohibition of the barrelled water supply, to stop this outbreak.

The case definition used for the cohort study is a probable case, which is defined as a student or teacher with diarrhoea or vomiting present since the term began in February 2014. An active search was conducted for undiagnosed cases among students and teachers. Details such as demographic characteristics, gastrointestinal symptoms, and drinking water preference and frequency were collected via a uniform epidemiological questionnaire. A case-control study was implemented, and odds ratios (ORs) and 95% confidence intervals were calculated. Rectal swabs from several patients, food handlers and barrelled water factory workers, as well as water and food samples, were collected to test for potential bacteria and viruses. A total of 924 cases fit the definition of the probable case, including 8 cases of laboratory-confirmed norovirus infection between February 12 and February 21, 2014; the attack rate was 4.01%. Six middle schools in Haining city and 4 middle schools and 3 kindergartens in Haiyan county were involved. The attack rate for middle school students, kindergarten students and teachers were significantly different (p<0.001). Among the 924 cases, 826 (89.39%) suffered from vomiting, 524 (56.71%) from nausea, 298 (32.25%) from abdominal pain, 206 (22.29%) from diarrhoea, 122 (13.20%) from fever and 129 (13.96%) from both vomiting and diarrhoea. No patients were hospitalized. The first case of gastroenteritis occurred on February 12 at 20:00. With the new semester starting on February 16, a rapid increase in the number of cases occurred over the following 3 days. The investigation identified several risk factors for the acute gastroenteritis outbreak caused by barrelled water contaminated with norovirus. These risk factors include:
1. Lack of surveillance and supervision of barrelled water supply in China.
2. Asymptomatic workers who were shedding norovirus in their stool and who were handling barrelled water without proper hygiene practices.
3. Lack of proper hygiene practices among food handlers and barrelled water factory workers.
4. Lack of proper disinfection practices for barrelled water containers and for food preparation areas.
5. Lack of proper handwashing facilities and practices for students, teachers and workers in schools and other institutions.
6. Lack of proper education and awareness programs for students, teachers and workers about the importance of proper hygiene practices, handwashing techniques and food safety measures to prevent the spread of infectious diseases such as norovirus.
7. Lack of proper enforcement of hygiene regulations and standards for barrelled water supply, food handling and preparation areas, and educational institutions.
8. Lack of proper coordination and communication among different agencies and organizations involved in the investigation, control and prevention of the acute gastroenteritis outbreak caused by barrelled water contaminated with norovirus.
9. Lack of proper resources and funding for the investigation, control and prevention of the acute gastroenteritis outbreak caused by barrelled water contaminated with norovirus.
10. Lack of proper training and expertise for the investigators, control officers and prevention specialists involved in the investigation, control and prevention of the acute gastroenteritis outbreak caused by barrelled water contaminated with norovirus.

responses: The contamination event occurred between 29 December and 3 January 1990.
The contamination event took place at Caravan Park A in Moama, New South Wales.

During the 1989 Christmas holiday period, a large outbreak of gastroenteritis occurred among persons staying at Caravan Park A in Moama, New South Wales. The outbreak was caused by sewage contaminating the reticulated river water through a break in the pipe directly over the underground water tanks. Of 305 (87 per cent) of the interviewed persons who had stayed at Caravan Park A, 47 of 72 persons (65 per cent) who did not use this water remained healthy. The outbreak affected an estimated 300 people.

These patients had been staying at a particular caravan park (Caravan Park A) in Moama. By 2 January 1990 the estimated number of patients had risen to 300.

Of 351 persons interviewed at the caravan park, 305 (87 per cent) reported an illness characterised by diarrhoea, vomiting and abdominal pain. Of the 351 persons interviewed at the caravan park, 305 (87 per cent) reported an illness characterised by diarrhoea, vomiting and abdominal pain. Of 196 persons who used reticulated river water for drinking or ablutions, 175 (89 per cent) became ill compared with 47 of 72 persons (65 per cent) who did not use this water. The outbreak was probably caused by a 27-28 nm small round structured virus found in the stool from one ill person. High levels of faecal coliforms in the reticulated river water and enterovirus in sediment samples suggest that the outbreak was caused by sewage contaminating the reticulated river water through a break in the pipe directly over the underground water tanks. To prevent such outbreaks, poor water and sewerage system layouts should be avoided and nonpotable water should be clearly labelled. Where feasible, all camping-ground water should stem from town supplies. During the monitoring phase, various water analysis methods were performed to detect and quantify contaminants in the water supply. Some of these methods include:
1. Total Coliform Counts: This method involves the enumeration of total coliform bacteria present in a given volume of water. This method is used as an indicator of potential faecal contamination of the water supply.
2. Faecal Coliform Counts: This method involves the enumeration of faecal coliform bacteria present in a given volume of water. This method is used as a more specific indicator of potential faecal contamination of the water supply, as compared to total coliform counts.
3. Escherichia coli (E. coli) Counts: This method involves the enumeration of E. coli bacteria present in a given volume of water. E. coli is a specific type of faecal coliform bacteria that is commonly used as an indicator organism for the presence of faecal contamination in water supplies.
4. Enterococcus Counts: This method involves the enumeration of enterococci bacteria present in a given volume of water. Enterococci are a group of gram-positive, facultatively anaerobic, coccoid bacteria that are commonly found in the human intestinal tract and in various environmental sources. Enterococci are commonly used as indicator organisms for the presence of faecal contamination in water supplies, particularly in recreational waters where there is a risk of ingestion of contaminated water.
5. pH and Alkalinity Measurements: This method involves the measurement of pH and alkalinity values in a given volume of water. pH is a measure of the acidity or basicity of a solution, with a pH value of 7 being neutral. Alkalinity is a measure of the capacity of a solution to neutralize an added acid without a significant change in pH value. Measurements of pH and alkalinity values in water samples are important for assessing the suitability of water for various uses, including drinking water supplies and recreational waters.
6. Total Dissolved Solids (TDS) Measurements: This method involves the measurement of TDS values in a given volume of water. TDS is a measure of the total amount of dissolved solids present in a given volume of water. Dissolved solids include inorganic ions such as sodium, potassium, calcium, magnesium, chloride, sulfate, and nitrate, as well as organic compounds such as humic and fulvic acids, and various other dissolved and colloidal substances. Measurements of TDS values in water samples are important for assessing the suitability of water for various uses, including drinking water supplies and recreational waters. High TDS values in water samples can indicate the presence of high levels of dissolved solids, which can affect the taste, odor, and overall quality of the water. In addition, high TDS values in water samples can indicate the presence of contaminants such as heavy metals, industrial chemicals, and agricultural runoff, which can pose health risks to individuals who consume or come into contact with the contaminated water. Therefore, it is important for water utilities and regulatory agencies to monitor TDS values in water samples on a regular basis, and to take appropriate actions to address any issues or concerns that may arise as a result of high TDS values in water samples.

The contamination event took place in Bradford, a city in the North of England. The exact location within the city was a single treatment works that supplied drinking water to a part of the city.

In November and December 1992, an outbreak of waterborne cryptosporidiosis occurred in Bradford, a city in the North of England. A total of 125 cases were identified, with the majority living in an area of the city which received its drinking water supply from a single treatment works. The source of the contamination was identified as being due to heavy rainfall in the catchment area of the reservoir supplying raw water to the treatment works, immediately prior to the probable time of infection. Treated water from the defined source yielded cryptosporidial oocysts. The Public Health Department of Bradford Health Authority was informed of the outbreak on 13 November 1992, and an advisory notice to boil water was issued on 15 November and lifted on 20 November. The water company undertook to sample and examine raw, treated, and distributed water and sand from the filter beds at the treatment works. Samples were examined according to procedures defined by the Department of Environment Standing Committee of Analysts manual. Independent analysis of some of the treated water samples was also undertaken. The water company examined the catchment area, including rainfall records, and reviewed the operation of the treatment works. Between 13 November and 23 December 1992, 125 cases of cryptosporidiosis which met the case definition were identified. Questionnaires were completed for 95 (76%), of whom 52 were female and 41 male (2% not stated). The majority of cases (53) for whom ages were available were children < 15 years, 33 being < 5 (Table 1). Twenty-eight cases were aged from 15 to 44 years, with 9 > 45 years. Ninety-two cases (97 %) reported diarrhoea, while abdominal pain was experienced by 75 (79%), vomiting by 35 (37 %), loss of appetite by 63 (66%), and loss of weight by 51 (54 %). The date of onset of illness ranged from 15 October to 22 December (Fig. 1). The peak incidence of onset was in the week commencing 5 November 1992. Eighty-nine cases (94%) had consulted their family doctor about the illness, and nine (10%) were admitted to hospital with a length of stay ranging from 1 to 8 days. Seventy-seven (81 %) were household primary cases and 16 (17%) were secondary cases (2% unknown). Twenty-three cases (24%) reported contact with a sick person before they themselves had become ill. Fifty-six cases (59 %) lived in an area of the city which received water from a single treatment works. The National Rivers Authority examined the water catchment area and reported no unusual findings and the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food reported that there were no known outbreaks of cryptosporidiosis affecting farm animals in the vicinity. Nonetheless, as a precautionary measure, the water company switched to alternative supplies where possible. Although oocysts were not found in the distribution supply an advisory notice to boil water was issued on 15 November and lifted on 20 November on the recommendation of the OCT.

The problems that may arise from contaminated public water supplies are demonstrated by this outbreak which occurred in Swindon and Oxfordshire, England, at the end of 1988 and in early 1989. The outbreak became the focus of widespread interest in the United Kingdom among the public and the media leading to a local enquiry and questions in parliament. Concern about the safety of water supplies led to the Badenoch Inquiry and Report, which has far-reaching implications for the water providers, health authorities and local authorities. A rise in the number of cases of cryptosporidiosis was noticed by microbiologists in Swindon and Oxfordshire in January 1989. Since testing of stool samples began in 1986 at the Oxford Public Health Laboratory (PHL), there had been an average of 4-5 cases per month in Oxfordshire. In December 1988 and January 1989, there were 36 cases in Oxfordshire. Initial investigations of the first cases failed to demonstrate a common factor between cases. The number of cases continued to increase throughout January to February and remained at a high level in March. Mapping of the addresses of early cases suggested an association with water supply. Investigations by the water authority in late February detected cryptosporidium oocysts in samples from the water treatment works which supplied the affected areas and in the treated water. Measures were taken to remove oocysts from the water supply. The public were advised to boil drinking water for children aged less than 2 years and for the immunosuppressed, because of the greater risk carried by the disease in these groups. Advice was given to hospitals, nursing homes, and other institutions. Advice concerning hygiene and cross-infection was given to the public. Many enquiries were received from businesses, schools and the public. Despite the distribution of information the outbreak generated much anxiety.

The contamination event took place in Red Lodge, Montana, and was associated with the city water system.

An outbreak of gastrointestinal illness occurred in Red Lodge, Montana between mid-June and early August 1980. Approximately 780 persons were affected, primarily urban residents within the city limits. The cause of the outbreak was identified as Giardia lamblia, a parasitic organism commonly found in contaminated water sources. The vehicle of transmission was determined to be the city water system, which supplied unfiltered and inadequately chlorinated surface water to residents within the city limits. The outbreak was likely caused by heavy water runoff during periods of warm sunny weather and snow darkened by ashfall from the Mt. St. Helens volcanic eruption of May 18, 1980. The epidemic curve was bimodal with peaks in mid-June and mid-July. Each peak occurred about three weeks after an episode of very heavy water runoff resulting from warm sunny weather and snow darkened by ashfall from the Mt. St. Helens volcanic eruption of May 18, 1980. Unfiltered and inadequately chlorinated surface water was supplied by the city water system, which was implicated as the vehicle of transmission in the outbreak. Water systems providing unfiltered surface water are more likely to become contaminated during periods of heavy water runoff. In July 1980, the Montana Department of Health and Environmental Sciences was notified that several hundred cases of acute gastrointestinal illness had occurred in the city of Red Lodge, in south central Montana. The outbreak appeared to have begun in June and to have affected primarily residents within the city limits. On August 7, 1980, a questionnaire was administered by telephone to households in the Red Lodge area. Approximately equal numbers of two groups were randomly chosen for sampling-one from within the city limits, virtually all of whose homes are served by the city water system, and the other from rural residents, most of whom use well or spring water. Control measures implemented in this outbreak included the recommendation for the public to temporarily boil drinking water, the rearrangement of valves at the water plant to expose water in both mains to chlorine, and steps to increase residual chlorine levels to mg/liter (1 ppm) for one hour contact time to achieve a cysticidal dosage. Several months after the outbreak, new chlorination equipment was installed to inject chlorine in proportion to water output and to automatically switch to a reserve tank when the active chlorine cylinder empties.

The contamination event took place at a vegetable processing plant in a village in Fife, Scotland. The plant was pumping wastewater from its processing operations back into the mains water supply of the village. This caused groundwater contamination and the mains water supply became contaminated with faecal coliforms and other bacteria.

On 6 March 1995, a local vegetable processing plant in a Fife village began pumping wastewater from its site back into the mains supply of the village. This was done in order to wash vegetables from a stream downstream from the village's sewage outflow. The pump used to draw water from the company's borehole had broken down on Monday 6 March.

As a result of this backflow, approximately 320 cubic metres of contaminated water, around 10% of the village's water consumption, were pumped back into the village's water supply system. This contamination event led to an outbreak of Campylobacter jejuni and Penner types 4 and 58 infections among residents of the affected village.

The contamination event was discovered on 10 March 1995 when chemical analysis indicated groundwater contamination in the village mains water samples taken on that day. Bacteriological analysis from water samples within the village showed over 1000 total and faecal coliforms from a site in zone I close to its junction with zones 2 and 3. In contrast, a similar sample from the middle of zone 4 grew no coliforms. Samples from the stream at the abstraction point grew between 21 000 and 25 400 total coliforms and between 14 100 and 17 600 faecal coliforms per 100 ml. They did not show the presence of Salmonella Yersinia or Aeromonas species. Very low counts of Cryptosporidium and Giardia lamblia were found in the stream but, since these were not found in the mains, they were not considered to be important. None of the routine samples grew Campylobacter although subsequent sampling on 28 March 1995 using larger volumes did show the presence of Campylobacter jejuni, Penner types 4 and 58. Meter readings indicated that about 320 cubic metres of contaminated water, around 10% of the village's water consumption, were pumped back.

The company then started to pump water into the plant to wash its vegetables from a stream downstream from the village's sewage outflow. This was supplemented by mains water obtained by connecting the plant's supply, which had been disconnected for several years, to a mains pipe coming to the plant from the village. Residents of the village were exposed to contaminated water from approximately midday on Monday 6 March until late evening on Friday 10 March.

Therefore, the attack rate is calculated as follows:
Attack rate = Number of individuals who became ill / Total number of individuals who were exposed to the contaminated water
Attack rate = 765 / 1183
Attack rate = 0.65 or 65%
Therefore, the attack rate for this outbreak was 65%.

The initial actions taken to investigate or inspect the event included receiving complaints of discoloration of tap water by residents in the east of a village in Fife. Chemical analysis indicated that the water from the taps was not mains water. Investigations showed that water from a local vegetable processor a few hundred metres to the east of the village was being pumped backwards into the mains supply of the village. The pump used to draw water from the company's borehole had broken down on Monday 6 March. The company then started to pump water into the plant to wash its vegetables from a stream downstream from the village's sewage outflow. This was supplemented by mains water obtained by connecting the plant's supply, which had been disconnected for several years, to a mains pipe coming to the plant from the village. Residents of the village were exposed to contaminated water from approximately midday on Monday 6 March until late evening on Friday 10 March. The affected village is supplied with chlorinated water from a 540 m3 capacity service reservoir through a single main to the outskirts of the village where a pressure reducing valve results in a drop in pressure from a 63 m head to 35 m before distribution within the village. There is no connection between this water supply and that of any other village. The water quality meets the required standards of the Water Supply (Water Quality) (Scotland) Regulations 1990. Tests later confirmed that the pressure generated by the pumps taking water from the stream was approximately 1.8 kg/sq cm greater than the nonmal average pressure in the mains. The Regional Council took immediate action to flush out the village's water supply system, increase the level of disinfection and, following discussions with the Public Health Department of Fife Health Board, issued a boiling water notice to each house in the village and provided bowsers at locations throughout the villages. A case was defined as a subject who had diarrhoea, vomiting or abdominal pain with first onset between 6 March 1995 and 24 March 1995 inclusive. A postal census of the village ascertained the extent of symptoms and illness among residents, several small employers in the village and staff employed at the vegetable processing plant. A simple random sample of 157 individuals out of a total of 1183 on the Community Health Index participated in a follow-up study to investigate exposure to HAV and to ascertain views about how the medical services had dealt with the incident. A total of 127 residents gave salivary samples and were successfully interviewed during July 1995. The 30 who were not interviewed were either unobtainable (25), refused (3) or had died (2). Salivary samples were analysed for the presence of IgM and IgG antibodies to HAV using antibody-capture radioimmunoassay. The results from the survey were keyed into a computer using dBASE IV and analysed on SPSS. Chemical analysis of village mains water samples taken on 10 March indicated ground water contamination. In contrast a similar sample from the middle of zone 4 grew no coliforms. Samples from the stream at the abstraction point grew between 21 000 and 25 400 total coliforms and between 14 100 and 17 600 faecal coliforms per 100 ml. They did not show the presence of Salmonella Yersinia or Aeromonas species. Very low counts of Cryptosporidia and Giardia lamblia were found in the stream but, since these were not found in the mains, they were not considered to be important. None of the routine samples grew Campylobacter although subsequent sampling on 28 March 1995 using larger volumes did show the presence of Campylobacter jejuni, Penner types 4 and 58. Meter readings indicated that about 320 cubic metres of contaminated water, around 10% of the village's water consumption, were pumped back.

The contamination event took place at Lingtian Middle School in China during November 2004.

In late 2004, there was a large outbreak of Salmonella Paratyphi A (SPA) at Lingtian Middle School in China. The outbreak affected 394 suspected cases, 95.5% of whom were students. The highest incidence was in the youngest children (7th grade). Forty-four of 151 (29%) blood cultures and 4/54 (7.4%) rectal swabs were positive for SPA; three were from kitchen workers. The geometric mean levels of serum IgG antilipopolysaccharide (anti-LPS) from patients was higher than from healthy individuals [35.25 vs. 5.20 ELISA units (EU), P<0.001]. A kitchen worker with a positive rectal swab, negative blood culture and a high level of serum IgG anti-LPS (529.65 EU), was identified as a possible SPA carrier. No SPA was isolated from water or food samples. A survey of students' habits indicated drinking unboiled water as being the main reason for contracting the disease. Hand washing was the second most important factor. A food handler with possible SPA carriage could also have been a risk factor. Attention to maintaining a safe water supply, enhancing food-handler hygiene and proper hand washing can help to prevent similar outbreaks in the future. A suspected case was defined as a person at Lingtian Middle School having one of the following clinical symptoms during 23 November to 7 December: fever (oral temperature 	o226537.7 	0C, duration 	o226524 h), diarrhoea, headache, sore throat, general malaise, anorexia, coughing, abdominal pain, or chill and 	bwith positive Widal test or with a positive blood culture. According to the Chinese Epidemiology Guideline 1996 those with a positive Widal test and having fever >3 days were identified as confirmed SPA infections. However, due to the large number of cases that oc-curred during the outbreak and the shortage of health staff, the collection of blood samples and clinical symptoms on days 2 and 3 was only undertaken when possible.

responses: The exact date of the contamination event is not specified in the provided context. However, it is mentioned that the contamination occurred at a school camp in rural Victoria, Australia, between Tuesday 27 February and Friday 2 March.
The contamination event took place at a school camp in rural Victoria, Australia.

An outbreak of gastroenteritis affected about half of a group of 55 students at a school camp in rural Victoria, Australia, in March 2007. Twenty-seven attendees were found to have abdominal pain, diarrhoea and nausea (attack rate 49%). Of 11 faecal specimens tested all were positive for Salmonella Typhimurium definitive phage type 9 (DT9). Of four samples taken from the untreated private water supply, two were positive for DT9. Drinking water from containers filled from rainwater tanks [relative risk (RR) 3.2, P=0.039] and participation in two recreational activities - flying fox (RR 5.3, P=0.011), and beam-balance (RR 3.9, P=0.050) - were indicative of a link with illness. Environmental and epidemiological investigations suggested rainwater collection tanks contaminated with DT9 as being the cause of the outbreak. Increased use of rainwater tanks may heighten the risk of waterborne disease outbreaks unless appropriate preventative measures are undertaken.
The text does not provide sufficient information to determine what triggered the contamination event.
The investigation suggested that rainwater collection tanks contaminated with DT9 were the cause of the outbreak.

Environmental and epidemiological investigations suggested rainwater collection tanks contaminated with DT9 as being the cause of the outbreak. During the monitoring phase, two types of water analyses methods were performed:
1. Culture-based methods: These methods involve growing bacteria from water samples in laboratory conditions. The bacteria are then identified based on their morphological and biochemical characteristics. This method is useful for detecting specific types of bacteria that may be causing illness.
2. Molecular-based methods: These methods involve detecting specific genetic material (DNA or RNA) from water samples using various techniques such as polymerase chain reaction (PCR), loop-mediated isothermal amplification (LAMP), and nucleic acid sequence-based amplification (NASBA). These methods are useful for detecting specific types or strains of bacteria or other microorganisms that may be present in water samples. These methods can provide results more quickly and with greater sensitivity than culture-based methods. However, molecular-based methods may not be able to distinguish between live and dead bacteria, and may not be able to identify the specific species or strains of bacteria that may be causing illness. Therefore, culture-based methods may still be necessary for confirming the presence and identification of specific types or strains of bacteria that may be causing illness.

After the identification of Salmonella Typhimurium DT9 as the cause of the outbreak, steps were taken to restore the system and prevent further spread of the infection. These steps included:
1. Disinfection of the rainwater collection tanks and distribution system using chlorine.
2. Installation of a filtration system to remove any remaining contaminants from the water supply.
3. Provision of bottled water for drinking and cooking purposes until the water supply was deemed safe for use.
4. Implementation of strict food safety practices and procedures at the camp facility to prevent any further contamination or spread of the infection.
5. Provision of regular updates and communication to all staff, students, and parents regarding the status of the water supply and any necessary precautions or measures to be taken.

Based on the investigation findings, several preventative measures have been recommended to reduce the risk of future waterborne disease outbreaks from rainwater tanks. These measures include:
1. Regular inspection and maintenance of rainwater tanks and associated systems to ensure they are free from contamination and functioning properly.
2. Implementing effective source water protection measures to prevent contamination of rainwater tanks and their associated systems. This may include measures such as maintaining a buffer zone around rainwater tanks, implementing effective stormwater management systems, and educating the public on the importance of source water protection and the potential risks associated with using untreated rainwater for drinking and other domestic uses.
3. Implementing effective treatment and disinfection measures for rainwater tanks and their associated systems to ensure that the water is safe for drinking and other domestic uses. This may include measures such as installing UV disinfection systems or using chlorine or other disinfectants to treat the water in the rainwater tanks and their associated systems.
4. Educating the public on the importance of proper rainwater tank maintenance and source water protection measures to reduce the risk of future waterborne disease outbreaks from rainwater tanks. This may include measures such as providing educational materials and resources on proper rainwater tank maintenance and source water protection measures, conducting public awareness campaigns and outreach programs to educate the public on the importance of proper rainwater tank maintenance and source water protection measures, and providing incentives and financial assistance programs to encourage the adoption and implementation of proper rainwater tank maintenance and source water protection measures by individuals and organizations.

During late October 2004, a sharp increase in giardiasis cases was first noted in Bergen, Norway. The identification of the waterborne route and detection of Giardia cysts in the implicated water occurred relatively rapidly. A boil water instruction was implemented quickly by the authorities and was in place for most of November and December 2004. The predominant cyst score was ++ (10 to 50 cysts per field of view with a x20 objective). The median age of patients was 35 years, and most patients were female. The contamination event is believed to have occurred up to 10 weeks previously. The probable source of contamination is now considered to be a sewage leakage from a residential area. However, during the episode waste from one particular septic tank was thought to be a possible source. Genotyping of cysts from patient samples and a comparison of the sequences gave complex results. For the 1-giardin gene, three isolates had sequences identical to subgenotype B3 sequences. However, other isolates had between one and four single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs). For the gdh gene, none of the sequences were identical to the sequence published for subgenotype B3, and the sequences had between one and three SNPs. One isolate, which was identical to subgenotype B3 at the 1-giardin gene, was more similar to subgenotype B2 at the gdh gene. Grouping the isolates on the basis of SNPs resulted in different groups for the two genes. The results are discussed in relation to giardiasis in Norway and to other Giardia genotyping studies. The water treatment plant involved in this outbreak is one of the oldest in Norway; the treatment in place during the outbreak was chlorination, although the works were in the process of renovation, and in February 2005 UV treatment was installed. Filtration systems are being installed, and the work should be completed in 2007. The initial actions taken to investigate or inspect the event included the implementation of a 'boil water' instruction by the authorities and the detection of Giardia cysts in the implicated water.

The investigation into the extensive outbreak of waterborne giardiasis in Bergen, Norway during the autumn and winter of 2004 and 2005 involved several steps. Initially, identification of the waterborne route and detection of Giardia cysts in the implicated water occurred relatively rapidly. A boil water instruction was implemented quickly by the authorities and was in place for most of November and December 2004.

As in the overall infected population during the peak stages of the outbreak, most patients included in the analyses described here were female, and the median age was 35 years. For one patient, three samples taken on successive days were included. All samples were positive as determined by microscopy, and the predominant cyst score was ++ (10 to 50 cysts per field of view with a x20 objective).

Further investigation into the source of contamination involved several steps. Initially, sewage leakage from a residential area was considered to be the probable source of contamination. However, during the episode waste from one particular septic tank was thought to be a possible source. Genotyping of cysts from 21 patient samples revealed that they were assemblage B cysts; thus, the septic tank was unlikely to be the contamination source.

Sequencing of the 1-giardin and gdh genes from patient samples and a comparison of the sequences gave complex results. For the 1-giardin gene, three isolates had sequences identical to subgenotype B3 sequences. However, other isolates had between one and four single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs). For the gdh gene, none of the sequences were identical to the sequence published for subgenotype B3, and the sequences had between one and three SNPs. One isolate, which was identical to subgenotype B3 at the 1-giardin gene, was more similar to subgenotype B2 at the gdh gene. Grouping the isolates on the basis of SNPs resulted in different groups for the two genes. The results are discussed in relation to giardiasis in Norway and to other Giardia genotyping studies. The water treatment plant involved in this outbreak is one of the oldest in Norway; the treatment in place during the outbreak was chlorination, although the works were in the process of renovation, and in February 2005 UV treatment was installed. Filtration systems are being installed, and the work should be completed in 2007.
The case definition used for the cohort study is a confirmed case of giardiasis based on microscopic identification of Giardia cysts or trophozoites in a stool sample.

responses: The contamination event occurred in the fall of 1977.
The contamination event took place in Bennington, Vermont, specifically in the town water system.

Approximately 3000 people in Bennington, Vermont, were affected by a diarrheal illness during the first and second weeks of June 1978. The illness was associated with drinking unboiled water from the town water system. Investigation showed that the entire water system was probably contaminated and the source of contamination was the main unfiltered water source, Bolles Brook. Campylobacter fetus subspecies jejuni was cultured from 15 of 42 rectal swabs obtained from persons who had been ill, but not from swabs obtained from 23 persons who served as controls. No environmental samples of water and no specimens from wild or domestic animals were positive for Campylobacter. This appears to be the first waterborne outbreak of gastroenteritis associated with C. fetus subspecies jejuni. Bennington's single water distribution system was constructed in the early 1900s. Widespread bacteriologic contamination attributed to inadequate chlorination occurred three times in the water system in the fall of 1977. Notices to boil water had been issued by the State Health Department in 1977. Some Bennington residents continued to boil their home water or refrained from using unboiled water before and at the time of the 1978 outbreak. A household survey (Survey 1), using a cluster sampling design was done from 15 to 19 June. Persons in households were initially surveyed through door-to-door interviews; those who could not be interviewed using this technique were contacted by phone.

The attack rate is calculated by dividing the number of individuals who became ill by the total number of individuals who were exposed to the contaminated water. In this case, approximately 3000 people were exposed to the contaminated water and 15 of those individuals were confirmed to have been infected with Campylobacter fetus subspecies jejuni. Therefore, the attack rate is calculated as follows: Attack rate = (Number of individuals who became ill) / (Total number of individuals who were exposed) = (15) / (3000) = 0.0005 or 0.05%

Therefore, the attack rate for this waterborne outbreak of gastroenteritis associated with C. fetus subspecies jejuni is 0.05%.

responses: The contamination event occurred between February 28-March 23, 2017.

The contamination event took place in city A. Specifically, a center pivot irrigation system intended to pump livestock wastewater from a nearby concentrated animal feeding operation onto adjacent farmland had malfunctioned, allowing excessive runoff to collect in a road ditch near two wells that supplied water to the city. These wells were promptly removed from service after the contamination event was identified. No subsequent cases occurred after the affected wells were decommissioned.

In March 2017, an apparent cluster of Campylobacter jejuni infections was identified in city A, with a total of 39 cases (six confirmed and 33 probable). The investigation revealed that a center pivot irrigation system intended to pump livestock wastewater from a nearby concentrated animal feeding operation onto adjacent farmland had malfunctioned, allowing excessive runoff to collect in a road ditch near two wells that supplied water to the city. These wells were promptly removed from service after the contamination was identified, with no subsequent cases occurring. This coordinated response rapidly identified an important risk to city A\u2019s municipal water supply and provided the evidence needed to decommission the affected wells, with plans to build a new well to safely serve this community. As part of the investigation, additional coliform and E. coli testing was performed on direct samples from wells 2, 3, 4, and 5; bacterial culture specifically for Campylobacter was performed on wells 4 and 5 on March 20 and 27, respectively; all samples were negative for coliforms and Campylobacter. No additional pump or testing records were reviewed.

Overall, 39 cases were investigated, including six confirmed and 33 probable cases. Untreated, unboiled city A tap water was identified as the only exposure significantly associated with illness, with an odds ratio of 7.84 and a 95% confidence interval of 1.69-36.36. City A is served by four untreated wells and an interconnected distribution system. The investigation identified that a center pivot irrigation system intended to pump livestock wastewater from a nearby concentrated animal feeding operation onto adjacent farmland had malfunctioned, allowing excessive runoff to collect in a road ditch near two wells that supplied water to the city. The contamination event took place in Sierra Leone during 2012. The country experienced a cholera epidemic with 22,815 reported cases and 296 deaths. The exact location of the contamination event is not specified in the provided context.

During 2012, Sierra Leone experienced a large cholera outbreak with 22,815 reported cases and 296 deaths (case fatality ratio, 1.3%). The outbreak began in early 2012 and appeared to be resolving by April 1 (Week 13). However, the number of reported weekly cases began to accelerate on July 15 (Week 28) and peaked between August 12 and 26 (Weeks 32-34). This phase of the outbreak coincided with the start of the rainy season in late June and the first confirmed case of cholera in Western Area, the most densely populated region in Sierra Leone (Figure 2). From 1990 through 2009, annual rainfall in June has been reported at 30 cm with a peak of 53 cm in August. Cases were defined as the first person \u2265 5 years of age with acute watery diarrhea and severe dehydration in a household, who was hospitalized for at least 1 night and treated with intravenous fluids between September 10 and 21, 2012. We enrolled 49 cases and 98 age- and neighborhood-matched controls. The median age was 23 years (5-50) for cases and 25 years (6-77) for controls. Cases and controls were similar in gender and household size. Although Sierra Leone\u2019s country-wide attack rate was 0.41%, Western area, the most populous urban district that includes Freetown, experienced an attack rate of 0.95% (Sierra Leone Cholera Command and Control Center, unpublished data).

The investigation involved conducting a matched case-control study to assess risk factors for cholera infection. The study enrolled 49 cases and 98 age- and neighborhood-matched controls. Stool specimens were analyzed by culture, polymerase chain reaction (PCR), and pulsed-field gel electrophoresis (PFGE). Conditional logistic regression found that consuming unsafe water, street-vended water, and crab were significant risk factors for cholera infection. Of 30 stool specimens, 13 (43%) showed PCR evidence of toxigenic Vibrio cholerae O1. Six specimens yielded isolates of V. cholerae O1, El Tor; PFGE identified a pattern previously observed in seven countries. Based on the findings of the investigation, recommendations were made to ensure the quality of improved water sources, promote household chlorination, and educate street vendors on water handling practices.

The suspected cholera outbreak occurred in Ghughri subdistrict of Mandla District in Madhya Pradesh, India, between July 20 and August 19, 2016. A total of 628 cases were identified, with 259 (41%) hospitalizations and 14 (2%) deaths. The median age of affected individuals was 27 years (range: 1 month-76 years). Illness was associated with drinking well water within paddy fields and not washing hands with soap after defecation. Of 34 stool cultures, 11 (34%) tested positive for Vibrio cholerae O1 Ogawa. Open defecation was observed around paddy fields, and all tested water sources in paddy fields had fecal contamination despite eight (50%) being protected. The recommended control and prevention measures include education regarding pit latrine sanitation and safe water, especially in paddy fields, provision of oral rehydration solution in remote villages, and chlorine tablets for point-of-use treatment of drinking water.

The investigation identified 628 cases of suspected cholera from 96 villages in the Ghughri subdistrict of Mandla District in Madhya Pradesh, India. The median age of the affected population was 27 years (range: 1 month-76 years). Illnesses began 7 days after rainfall and were associated with drinking well water within paddy fields and not washing hands with soap after defecation. Of 34 stool cultures, 11 (34%) tested positive for Vibrio cholerae O1 Ogawa. Of 16 tested water sources in paddy fields, eight (50%) were protected, but 100% had fecal contamination. Based on these findings, it is recommended that education regarding pit latrine sanitation and safe water, especially in paddy fields, be provided. Additionally, oral rehydration solution should be made available in remote villages, and chlorine tablets should be provided for point-of-use treatment of drinking water.

This cholera outbreak in Hoima District, Western Uganda, is likely caused by drinking lake water contaminated by faeces from a gully channel. The outbreak involved 122 suspected cases, including six confirmed cases, and two deaths. The affected population included both children and adults, with a median age of 20 years. The majority of the affected population were males (57%). The occupations of the affected population included fishermen (32%) and other occupations. The environmental assessment revealed that the lake water was contaminated due to a gully channel that washed faeces into the lake at point C. The investigation recommends evidence-led interventions including treatment of drinking water, fixing the vandalised piped-water system, and constructing latrines.

The contamination event took place in Pondicherry, Southern India, specifically around two major leakages in the water supply system.

This event was an outbreak of cholera in Pondicherry, Southern India, following a severe cyclonic storm on 7 January 2012. The outbreak affected 921 residents and resulted in one death. The attack rate was highest among persons aged 50 years and above (14%), females (12%), and those living in affected areas during the outbreak period (6-18 January 2012). The outbreak started on 6 January and peaked on the 9th and lasted till 14 January. Cases were clustered around two major leakages in water supply system. Laboratory testing identified Vibrio cholerae O1 Ogawa as the causative agent in nine of the sixteen stool samples tested. Epidemiological evidence suggested that this outbreak was due to ingestion of water contaminated by drainage following rains during cyclone. We recommended repair of the water supply lines, cleaning-up of the drains, handwashing, and drinking of boiled water as control measures.

The investigation involved identifying causes and recommending control measures for an outbreak of acute diarrhoea in Pondicherry, Southern India. The investigation defined a case as occurrence of diarrhoea of more than three loose stools per day with or without vomiting in a resident of affected areas during 6-18 January 2012. The investigation used active (door-to-door survey) and stimulated passive (healthy facility-based) surveillance to identify cases. The investigation described the outbreak by time, place, and person. The investigation compared case-patients with up to three controls without any apparent signs and symptoms of diarrhoea and matched for age, gender, and neighbourhood. The investigation calculated matched odds ratio (MOR), 95% confidence intervals (CI), and population attributable fractions (PAF). The investigation collected rectal swabs and water samples for laboratory diagnosis and tested water samples for microbiological quality. The investigation identified 921 cases and one death among 8,367 residents (attack rate: 11%, case-fatality: 0.1%). The attack rate was the highest among persons of 50 years and above (14%) and females (12%). The outbreak started on 6 January and peaked on the 9th and lasted till 14 January. Cases were clustered around two major leakages in water supply system. Nine of the 16 stool samples yielded V. cholerae O1 Ogawa. The investigation identified that consumption of water from the public distribution system (MOR=37, 95% CI 4.9-285, PAF: 97%), drinking unboiled water (MOR=35, 95% CI 4.5-269, PAF: 97%), and a common latrine used by two or more households (MOR=2.7, 95% CI 1.3-5.6) were independently associated with cholera. Epidemiological evidence suggested that this outbreak was due to ingestion of water contaminated by drainage following rains during cyclone. The investigation recommended repair of the water supply lines, cleaning-up of the drains, handwashing, and drinking of boiled water.

The Ben Tre Provincial Government implemented several measures to prevent future contamination events after the cholera outbreak was confirmed in May 2010. These measures included:

2. Cleaning and disinfection of the houses of confirmed cholera cases using chloramine B.

4. Tracing and monitoring of close contacts of confirmed cholera cases, and provision of a single dose of prophylactic ciprofloxacin to these contacts.
5. Education campaigns to encourage people in the entire province to practice safe water, proper sanitation, and food safety.
6. Prohibition of the manufacture, transportation, sale, or supply of commercial ice in the two most affected towns of Mo Cay and Giong Trom, to prevent future contamination events.

The contamination event took place in Baker City, Oregon during July 2013. The contamination was associated with municipal drinking water.

During July 2013 in Baker City, Oregon, an outbreak of cryptosporidiosis was associated with municipal drinking water. The objectives of the investigation were to confirm the outbreak source and assess outbreak extent. The watershed was inspected and city water was tested for contamination. responses: The contamination event occurred between 28 and 30 November 2007.
The contamination event took place in the municipal drinking water system in the town of Nokia, Finland.

The contamination event occurred when approximately 450,000 l of filtered sewage effluent from the municipal wastewater plant flowed into the municipal drinking water system between 28 and 30 November 2007. This resulted in a significant number of persons suffering from gastrointestinal symptoms due to infection with various pathogens, including Campylobacter spp., noroviruses, Salmonella, rotavirus, and Clostridium difficile. Several patients presented with polymicrobial infections. While the first giardiasis case was microbiologically confirmed on 27 December 2007, several patients with giardiasis had already visited the municipal healthcare centre in the town of Nokia due to gastrointestinal symptoms at the beginning of the outbreak. Two samples of drinking water from the water distribution network and 1 wastewater effluent sample were taken between 1 and 3 December 2007 for Giardia and Cryptosporidium analyses. The cases ranged in age from 3 to 61 y and were 76% female. All households of the cases received their water from a municipal water company.
The accidental opening of a valve connecting a processed wastewater line to the drinking water network triggered the contamination event.

The exact source of the contamination was not identified, but it is believed that the contaminated water entered the municipal drinking water system through a valve that was accidentally opened during maintenance work at the waterworks.

The contamination event was first discovered when inhabitants started reporting symptoms of diarrhea and vomiting on 30 November 2007. Customers also complained about the bad smell and taste of tap water, but these organoleptic changes were initially thought to be harmless consequences of the maintenance work. However, after the discovery of the contamination event and the subsequent confirmation of Giardia infections among the population, it was determined that the bad smell and taste of tap water were actually indicative of the presence of Giardia cysts in the water supply.
Approximately 9000 individuals were exposed to the contaminant.

During the investigation, several risk factors were identified as contributing to the outbreak of giardiasis in Nokia, Finland. These risk factors included:
1. Contaminated water sources: The municipal drinking water system was found to be contaminated with Giardia cysts due to the accidental release of sewage effluent into the municipal drinking water system.
2. Poor water treatment and disinfection: The municipal water treatment plant was found to have insufficient oxidation capacity and poor disinfection efficiency, which allowed Giardia cysts to survive and propagate in the municipal drinking water system.
3. Inadequate monitoring and surveillance: The municipal water company was found to have insufficient monitoring and surveillance capacity, which allowed the contaminated municipal drinking water system to remain undetected for an extended period of time.
4. Human behavior and hygiene practices: Several cases of giardiasis were found to be associated with poor hygiene practices, such as not washing hands properly before handling food or after using the toilet. Additionally, some cases were found to be associated with recreational activities that involved contact with contaminated water sources, such as swimming in lakes or rivers that were known to be contaminated with Giardia cysts.
5. Animal contact and agricultural practices: Several cases of giardiasis were found to be associated with contact with animals or agricultural practices that involved contact with contaminated animal waste or water sources. For example, some cases were found to be associated with contact with livestock or their manure during agricultural activities such as farming or animal husbandry. Other cases were found to be associated with contact with pets or their feces during recreational activities such as walking dogs or playing with pets in the home or yard. Additionally, some cases were found to be associated with contact with contaminated water sources during recreational activities such as swimming or wading in lakes or rivers that were known to be contaminated with Giardia cysts or other pathogens. In some cases, contact with contaminated water sources during recreational activities was found to be indirect, such as when contaminated water from a nearby lake or river was used to fill swimming pools or wading pools for public use during recreational activities. In such cases, the risk of Giardia infection or other waterborne illnesses was found to be higher for individuals who used the contaminated swimming or wading pools during recreational activities, as compared to individuals who did not use the contaminated swimming or wading pools during recreational activities. These risk factors included contaminated water sources, poor water treatment and disinfection, inadequate monitoring and surveillance, and human behavior and hygiene practices. By identifying these risk factors and taking appropriate measures to address them, public health officials were able to prevent future outbreaks of giardiasis and other waterborne illnesses in Nokia, Finland and beyond.

An outbreak of cryptosporidiosis occurred in the Isle of Thanet during December 1990 and January 1991. A total of 47 cases ranging in age from 2 months to 85 years were identified in residents from the Margate, Broadstairs and Ramsgate areas, with dates of onset of illness from 3 December to 14 January. A case-control study demonstrated a strong statistical association between illness and the consumption of unboiled tap water from a particular source, with evidence of a dose-response relationship. Although no cryptosporidial oocysts were identified in samples of untreated or treated water taken during the investigation, the results were consistent with the view that the source of infection was treated river water which was used to supplement borehole water. At the beginning of January 1991 the Consultant Microbiologist at Thanet District General Hospital (TDGH) informed the Communicable Disease Surveillance Centre (CDSC) of the Public Health Laboratory Service (PHLS) that an increase in cases of cryptosporidiosis had occurred in the Thanet area. Twenty-eight cases had been identified since 11 December 1990, compared with an average expected number of three per month. A previous outbreak of cryptosporidiosis had occurred between February and May 1989 when 65 people resident in the area were affected. At the time, water was considered to be a possible source. Primary cases of cryptosporidiosis were defined as people in Thanet who had had an illness with diarrhoea between 1 December 1990 and 31 January 1991, and confirmation of the presence of cryptosporidial oocysts in a stool specimen. Cases were excluded from the analytical study if they had travelled abroad in the 4 weeks before their onset of illness or if another household member had had diarrhoea since 1 December 1990. Controls were obtained from the registration data held by the Kent Family Health Service Authority (FHSA), and were matched for the same sex, age group, and general practice or health centre as the case. Thev were excluded if they had been abroad in the 4 weeks before the onset of illness of their matched case, and if they themselves had had diarrhoea since 1 December 1990. Five names and addresses of controls were obtained per case. Five cases had been admitted to hospital. The age distribution ranged from 2 months to 85 years, median 17 years (Table 1). Twenty-nine cases, including six from the preliminary investigation were included in the case-control study. Their ages ranged from 7 months to 85 years (median 27 years) and dates of onset of illness from 3 December to 8 January. Two patients, aged 3 years and 55 years were admitted to hospital. All 29 patients reported symptoms of diarrhoea. 23 reported abdominal pain, 11 fever, 10 vomiting, 19 weight loss and 15 that they had had nausea. Seven cases had a 'flulike illness in the month before onset of the cryptosporidial infection and five reported that they increased their fluid intake as a result of this 'flu-like illness.

responses: The contamination event occurred between March and September 2018.
The contamination event took place along the Maroni river in Maripasoula, French Guiana.

In March 2018, an outbreak of cryptosporidiosis occurred in Maripasoula, a village located along the border between Surinam and French Guiana. The outbreak was caused by contamination of the water network with Cryptosporidium parvum subtype IIdA19G2. The outbreak resulted in 16 confirmed and 35 possible cases of cryptosporidiosis. The confirmed cases included nine children, one immunocompromised adult, and six soldiers. The possible cases included individuals who had close contact with confirmed cases or who had symptoms consistent with cryptosporidiosis but did not have a confirmed diagnosis. The median age was 18 months for children and 28 years for military and police personnel. The symptoms included diarrhoea (9/9 for children and 6/7 for adults), fever (4/9 for children and 1/7 for adults), vomiting (3/9 for children and 5/7 for adults), abdominal pain (4/7 for adults), headache (2/7 for adults), and malnutrition (one child). The median duration of symptoms was 11 days for children and 5 days for adults. All patients eventually recovered. The water supply company improved the water treatment system, specifically regarding the maintenance and repair of pumps, pre-treatment pH-adjustment to optimise the coagulation process and further improve water clarification, sand filters and tank cleaning (resulting in a temporary increase in water chlorination). Displacement of the water catchment point was planned to move further upstream on the Maroni river. Military camps were supplied with bottled water from May 24 to the end of June 2018, then UV lights system were installed. Only a new case of cryptosporidiosis was reported in September 2018. Stool sample genotyping revealed C. hominis subtype IbA10G2, the same genotype found during the epidemic. The sample was taken from a 9-month-old male who had presented diarrhoea for 24 hours. His only risk factor was the consumption of soups prepared with tap water, although the hypothesis of contact with an asymptomatic carrier could not be ruled out as a source of exposure.

The number of individuals who became ill was 16 (all confirmed cases). Therefore, the attack rate is calculated as follows: attack rate = (number of individuals who became ill) / (total number of individuals who were exposed) = 16/51 = 0.3137 (rounded to four decimal places for accuracy).

The contamination event took place in Clark County, Nevada.

An outbreak of cryptosporidiosis occurred in Clark County, Nevada, between 1992 and 1994. The outbreak affected both HIV-infected adults and immunocompetent children. The attack rate for laboratory-confirmed cryptosporidiosis among adults with AIDS was 9.2%. The source of the contamination was not definitively identified, but it is believed that municipal drinking water was the likely source of the contamination. Despite state-of-the-art water treatment and water quality that was better than that required by current federal standards, the outbreak highlights the importance of surveillance for cryptosporidiosis and the need for guidelines for the prevention of waterborne-Cryptosporidium infection among HIV-infected persons.

The investigation did not identify a specific source of contamination for the cryptosporidiosis outbreak in Clark County, Nevada. However, presumptive oocysts were intermittently found in samples of source water, filter backwash, and finished water after the investigation was completed. No elevated turbidity values or coliform counts were found in testing of source or finished water during the study period, but so-called presumptive oocysts were intermittently found in samples of source water, filter backwash, and finished water after the investigation was completed. Conclusions: A cryptosporidiosis outbreak was associated with municipal drinking water, despite state-of-the-art water treatment and water quality better than that required by current federal standards. This outbreak highlights the importance of surveillance for cryptosporidiosis and the need for guidelines for the prevention of waterborne-Cryptosporidium infection among HIV-infected persons. Of the 78 persons in whom Cryptosporidium infection was diagnosed during the study period, 41 (52.6%) had died by 30 April 1995, 1 year after the end of the study period. One of the 2 HIV-infected children had died, as had 40 (65.6%) of the 61 HIV-infected adults (Table 2). Of these 40 adults, 32 (52.5% of 61) had died by 30 June 1994, 2 months after the end of the study period. At least 20 of these 32 (62.5%) had cryptosporidiosis listed as a cause of death on their death certificates (Table 2). The CD4+ cell counts were similar for HIV-infected adults with cryptosporidiosis who lived and those who died (Table 2). The median ages of the case-patients and controls were 35 years (range, 27 to 61 years) and 36 years (range, 25 to 68 years), respectively; more than 90% were men. Most case-patients had CD4+ cell counts less than 100 cells/mm3 (Table 1). In the case-control study of immunocompetent children, we interviewed 10 of the 11 case-patients and controls were similar in median age (4 years [range, 8 months to 14 years] and 3 years [range, 1 to 13 years], respectively) and in sex distribution (70.0% of the case-patients and 69.2% of the controls were male)). On the basis of the estimate that 630 adults in Clark County had AIDS during the study period, and given that 58 of the 61 HIV-infected adults who had cryptosporidiosis had AIDS, the attack rate for laboratory-confirmed cryptosporidiosis among adults with AIDS was 9.2%.

Since the 1993-1994 cryptosporidiosis outbreak in Clark County, Nevada, several measures have been implemented to prevent future contamination events. These measures include:
1. Enhanced water treatment processes: The Southern Nevada Water Authority (SNWA) has implemented enhanced water treatment processes at its three water treatment plants in Las Vegas, Nevada. These processes include additional filtration, ultraviolet disinfection, and increased monitoring for turbidity and other water quality parameters.
2. Source water protection measures: The SNWA has implemented source water protection measures to reduce the risk of contamination events in its source waters, which include Lake Mead and Lake Mohave. These measures include:
- Regular monitoring for water quality parameters, including turbidity, coliform bacteria, and Cryptosporidium oocysts.
- Implementation of best management practices for agricultural and urban runoff to reduce the risk of contamination events in source waters.
- Implementation of emergency response plans to quickly respond to contamination events in source waters and minimize the risk of contamination events in finished waters.
3. Public education and awareness campaigns: The SNWA has implemented public education and awareness campaigns to inform the public about the importance of water quality and the steps being taken to prevent future contamination events. These campaigns include:
- Regular updates on water quality parameters through various communication channels, including social media, email, and telephone hotlines.
- Public education materials, including brochures, fact sheets, and videos, that provide information about water quality, the importance of water treatment processes, and the steps being taken to prevent future contamination events.
- Community outreach programs, including public workshops, community meetings, and educational presentations to schools and community organizations, that provide opportunities for the public to learn about water quality issues, ask questions, and provide feedback on water quality concerns and prevention measures.
4. Collaboration and partnerships with local, state, and federal agencies and organizations: The SNWA has established collaboration and partnerships with local, state, and federal agencies and organizations to enhance water quality monitoring, prevention, and response efforts. These partnerships include:
- Collaboration with the Nevada State Health Division and the Southern Nevada Health District to enhance water quality monitoring, prevention, and response efforts, including implementation of best management practices for agricultural and urban runoff, regular monitoring for water quality parameters, and implementation of emergency response plans to quickly respond to contamination events and minimize the risk of contamination events in finished waters.
- Collaboration with the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and the Nevada State Water Resources Control Board to enhance water quality monitoring, prevention, and response efforts, including implementation of best management practices for agricultural and urban runoff, regular monitoring for water quality parameters, and implementation of emergency response plans to quickly respond to contamination events and minimize the risk of contamination events in finished waters.
- Collaboration with academic institutions, including the University of Nevada, Las Vegas (UNLV) and the Desert Research Institute (DRI), to enhance water quality monitoring, prevention, and response efforts, including implementation of best management practices for agricultural and urban runoff, regular monitoring for water quality parameters, and implementation of emergency response plans to quickly respond to contamination events and minimize the risk of contamination events in finished waters.
5. Continuous monitoring and evaluation of water quality parameters and prevention measures: The SNWA continues to monitor and evaluate water quality parameters and prevention measures on an ongoing basis to ensure that water quality remains at acceptable levels and that prevention measures remain effective in preventing future contamination events. During March 1-15, 2000, an outbreak of cryptosporidiosis occurred in and around Clitheroe, Lancashire, in northwest England. Fifty-eight cases of diarrhea with Cryptosporidium identified in stool specimens were reported. Cryptosporidium oocysts were identified in samples from the water treatment works as well as domestic taps. Descriptive epidemiology suggested that drinking unboiled tap water in a single water zone was the common factor linking cases. Environmental investigation suggested that contamination with animal feces was the likely source of the outbreak. The outbreak was unusual in that hydrodynamic modeling was used to give a good estimate of the peak oocyst count at the time of the contamination incident. The oocysts\u2019 persistence in the water distribution system after switching to another water source was also unusual. This persistence may have been due to oocysts being entrapped within biofilm. Despite the continued presence of oocysts, epidemiologic evidence suggested that no one became ill after the water source was changed. During March 17, a large-volume sample of water (1,627 L) from a pumping station fed from Lowcocks WTW yielded 76 oocysts of Cryptosporidium per 1,000 L. Cryptosporidium oocysts were also identified in a water sample taken from a domestic tap in the water zone on March 16 at a concentration of five oocysts per 10 L of water.

Initial actions taken to investigate or inspect the event included reporting cases of diarrhea with Cryptosporidium identified in stool specimens to the local health authority. The local water company provided information on the water supply, instituted a water-sampling schedule, and analyzed the water samples to identify Cryptosporidium oocysts. Most of the samples were 10-L grab samples analyzed according to the U.K. standard method. The large-volume samples were analyzed by the method in the Water Supply (Water Quality) Amendment Regulations of 1999. The source of water to the affected area was visited by members of the outbreak control team. After the incident, the water company constructed a physical model of the affected reservoir with a geometric scaling ratio of 32:1. Flows were tracked by using salt injection with an array of conductivity probes suspended above the tank and injecting colored dyes for visualization. As the ratio of the two respective inlet flows can vary, the baseline performance of the tank was evaluated over a range of operational, but steady state, conditions. A series of transient tests was then conducted to mirror the operation of the reservoir in the time leading up to and covering the incident until the boil water notice was issued on March 21.

The investigation involved a series of tests and inspections to identify the source of the Cryptosporidium outbreak in Clitheroe, Lancashire, in northwest England, during March 2000. The investigation included descriptive epidemiology, environmental investigation, water sampling and analysis, and microbiological testing of stool specimens from patients. The investigation also involved interviews with patients, their families, and healthcare professionals, as well as inspections of water treatment works, domestic water supplies, and sewage treatment plants. The investigation was led by a multidisciplinary team of experts from public health, environmental health, microbiology, engineering, and water treatment. The team worked closely with local authorities, water companies, healthcare providers, and other stakeholders to coordinate the response to the outbreak and implement measures to prevent future outbreaks. The investigation was ongoing at the time of this response, with further testing and analysis being conducted to fully understand the causes of the outbreak and implement effective measures to prevent similar outbreaks from occurring in the future.

Despite the continued presence of oocysts, epidemiologic evidence suggested that no one became ill after the water source was changed.

Fifty-one patients lived in the same water supply zone and drank unboiled main tap water in the zone. The crude attack rate for residents of this zone was 29.6 per 10,000 population (based on general practitioner registered population of 17,252 linked by postal code of residences in the water supply zone). The contamination event involved a waterborne outbreak of Cryptosporidium hominis infection that was linked to a mains water supply. The source water for the mains drinking water supply came from a reservoir (Llyn Cwellyn) in north west Wales, UK, within the Snowdonia National Park. The contamination event resulted in the detection of Cryptosporidium oocysts in base flow surface water samples from the reservoir, as well as in effluent from a community wastewater treatment plant and in treated water from the affected area. The genotyping of Cryptosporidium isolates from environmental samples during the outbreak investigation identified multiple routes of contamination of the reservoir, resulting in persistent detection of low numbers of oocysts in the final water. The utility of genotyping Cryptosporidium isolates in environmental samples during outbreak investigations was demonstrated by this work.

The symptoms associated with Cryptosporidium infection include diarrhea (often profuse and watery), abdominal cramps, nausea, vomiting, and fever. The incubation period for Cryptosporidium infection is typically 1-10 days, but can range from 1 day to 4 weeks. The duration of symptoms for Cryptosporidium infection is typically 1-2 weeks, but can range from several days to several months. It is important to note that some individuals may experience no symptoms or only mild symptoms despite being infected with Cryptosporidium. Additionally, some individuals may experience more severe symptoms or prolonged symptoms despite being infected with the same strain of Cryptosporidium as another individual. The reasons for these variations in symptom severity and duration are not fully understood and are currently the subject of ongoing research.

Initial actions taken to investigate or inspect the event included removal of sewage solids from the humus tank and issuing a temporary boil water notice and installation of UV treatment at the water treatment works.

The investigation involved testing surface waters and wastewater treatment plants for Cryptosporidium spp. Oocyst counts in base flow surface water samples ranged from nil to 29 per 10 l. Oocyst counts in effluent from a community wastewater treatment plant were up to 63 fold higher and breakout from one septic tank five logs higher. There were no peak (storm) flow events during the investigation. C. hominis, four named genotypes (cervine, muskrat II, rat, W19) and six new small subunit ribosomal RNA gene sequences were identified. Four of the new sequences were closely related to Cryptosporidium muskrat genotype I, one was closely related to the fox genotype and one to Cryptosporidium canis. C. hominis was found extensively in the catchment, but only at sites contaminated by wastewater, and in the treated water supply to the affected area. All were gp60 subtype IbA10G2, the outbreak subtype. Multiple routes of contamination of the reservoir were identified, resulting in persistent detection of low numbers of oocysts in the final water. This work demonstrates the utility of genotyping Cryptosporidium isolates in environmental samples during outbreak investigations. Initial descriptive epidemiology of the outbreak indicated that the mains drinking water supply was the possible cause of the outbreak. The source water is from a reservoir (Llyn Cwellyn) in the north west of Wales, UK, within the Snowdonia National Park. Llyn Cwellyn (grid reference of centre OS 256000 355000) is approximately 2 km long, 0.75km wide and 37m at its deepest point, and orientated north west\u2014south east at approximately 142 metres above sea level. Actions taken by DCWW  to reduce the contamination from the wastewater treatment plant included removal of sewage solids from the humus tank and, with the agreement of the OCT, the issuing of a temporary boil water notice and installation of UV treatment at the water treatment works (see Mason et al. 2010).

The case definition used for the cohort study was a confirmed case of Cryptosporidium hominis infection. This was defined as either a positive result from a stool sample tested for Cryptosporidium using immunomagnetic separation (IMS) followed by polymerase chain reaction (PCR) and sequencing or a positive result from a stool sample tested for Cryptosporidium using microscopy and the modified acid-fast (MAF) staining method. The cohort study included individuals who were residents or workers in the affected area during the time period of interest and who consumed water from the affected water supply during that time period.

During the investigation, several risk factors were identified as contributing to the waterborne outbreak of Cryptosporidium hominis infection. These risk factors include:
1. Contamination of the source water in Llyn Cwellyn with Cryptosporidium oocysts from wastewater sources.
2. Inadequate treatment of the source water in Llyn Cwellyn at the water treatment works, resulting in the release of untreated or partially treated water containing Cryptosporidium oocysts into the distribution network and ultimately to consumers.
3. Failure to implement adequate water quality monitoring and surveillance programs at both the source water and treatment plant levels, resulting in the lack of timely detection and response to contamination events and the subsequent release of contaminated water to consumers.
4. Inadequate public education and awareness programs regarding the risks associated with consuming contaminated water and the importance of practicing good hygiene and water safety habits to minimize the risk of contracting waterborne illnesses.
5. Lack of effective regulatory oversight and enforcement mechanisms at both the national and local levels to ensure that water suppliers and treatment plant operators are adhering to established water quality standards and regulations and implementing appropriate risk management strategies and practices to minimize the risk of contamination events and the subsequent release of contaminated water to consumers.
