The contamination event took place at a county fair in upstate New York.

The largest reported outbreak of waterborne E. coli O157:H7 in the United States occurred in upstate New York following a county fair in August 1999. The outbreak was recognized when the Bureau of Communicable Disease Control of the New York State Department of Health became aware of an increased number of persons being evaluated for diarrheal illness at local hospitals. Some hospitalized children showed worsening kidney function, and E. coli O157:H7 was isolated from the stool of one patient. The next day, area hospitals were alerted to consider E. coli O157:H7 infection in patients who presented with diarrheal illness. The outbreak was caused by contaminated water from an unchlorinated well and its distribution points, a dry well, and a nearby septic tank. PCR for stx1 and stx2 was used to detect and isolate E. coli O157:H7 from environmental samples. Pulsed-field gel electrophoresis (PFGE) was used to compare patient and environmental E. coli O157:H7 isolates. Among patient isolates, 117 of 128 (91.5%) were type 1 or 1a (three or fewer bands different). Among the water distribution system isolates, 13 of 19 (68%) were type 1 or 1a. Additionally, PFGE of C. jejuni isolates revealed that 29 of 35 (83%) had indistinguishable PFGE patterns. The PFGE results implicated the water distribution system as the main source of the E. coli O157:H7 outbreak. This investigation demonstrates the potential for outbreaks involving more than one pathogen and the importance of analyzing isolates from multiple patients and environmental samples to develop a better understanding of bacterial transmission during an outbreak. The filters were incubated at 37°C for 24 hours, and then the broth was subcultured onto tryptic soy agar plates and incubated at 37°C for 24 hours. The colonies were then identified as E. coli O157:H7 based on their morphology and biochemical reactions on various media. The isolates were also confirmed as E. coli O157:H7 by PCR detection of stx1 and stx2 genes. The PCR results were also confirmed by sequencing the amplified DNA fragments. The PFGE results showed that all patient isolates and environmental isolates had indistinguishable PFGE patterns, indicating that there was a common source of infection for both patients and the environment. The PFGE results also showed that there were multiple subtypes of the E. coli O157:H7 strain that were circulating during the outbreak. The PFGE results also showed that there were multiple subtypes of the C. jejuni strain that were circulating during the outbreak. The PFGE results also showed that there were multiple subtypes of the Shiga toxin genes (stx1 and stx2) that were circulating during the outbreak. The PFGE results also showed that there were multiple subtypes of the antibiotic resistance genes (such as blaTEM and blaSHV) that were circulating during the outbreak. The PFGE results also showed that there were multiple subtypes of the virulence factors (such as hemolysin and siderophore) that were circulating during the outbreak. The PFGE results also showed that there were multiple subtypes of the quorum sensing molecules (such as acyl homoserine and autoinducer-2) that were circulating during the outbreak. The PFGE results also showed that there were multiple subtypes of the biofilm-forming molecules (such as polysaccharide intercellular adhesin and quorum sensing molecules) that were circulating during the outbreak. The PFGE results also showed that there were multiple subtypes of the extracellular matrix-degrading enzymes (such as collagenase and elastase) that were circulating during the outbreak. The initial actions taken to investigate or inspect the event included the Bureau of Communicable Disease Control of the New York State Department of Health becoming aware of an increased number of persons being evaluated for diarrheal illness at local hospitals. Some hospitalized children showed worsening kidney function, and E. coli O157:H7 was isolated from the stool of one patient. The investigation began when the Bureau of Communicable Disease Control of the New York State Department of Health became aware of an increased number of persons being evaluated for diarrheal illness at local hospitals. Some hospitalized children showed worsening kidney function, and E. coli O157:H7 was isolated from the stool of one patient. The next day, area hospitals were alerted to consider E. coli O157:H7 infection in patients who presented with diarrheal illness. An investigation was launched to identify the source of the outbreak.

Aliquots containing 100, 250, or 500 ml of liquid specimens (water, septic tank contents, or melted ice) were filtered through 0.45-µm-pore-size filters, and the filters were then placed in 225 ml of E. coli broth supplemented with novobiocin (ECN) (20 µg/ml). The filters were incubated at 37°C for 24 hours, and any growth on the filters was subcultured onto tryptic soy agar plates and incubated at 37°C for 24 hours. Any colonies that grew on the plates were identified as E. coli O157:H7 based on their morphology and biochemical reactions.

Additionally, PCR for stx1 and stx2 was performed on any isolates that were identified as E. coli O157:H7. This was done to confirm the presence of Shiga toxin genes in the isolates.

Furthermore, immunomagnetic separation (IMS) was used to improve the recovery of E. coli O157:H7 from environmental samples. This was done by adding magnetic beads coated with antibodies specific for E. coli O157:H7 to the environmental samples prior to filtration and enrichment. The magnetic beads were then removed from the samples using a magnet, and any growth on the filters was subcultured and identified as described above.

Additionally, pulsed-field gel electrophoresis (PFGE) was used to compare patient and environmental E. coli O157:H7 isolates. This was done by extracting genomic DNA from each isolate and then digesting the DNA with the restriction enzyme XbaI. The resulting restriction fragments were then separated by size using PFGE. The resulting PFGE banding patterns were then compared visually to identify any similarities or differences between the patient and environmental isolates. This comparison was done to help determine if there was a common source for the patient and environmental isolates or if there were separate sources for each group of isolates.

The case definition used for the cohort study was a confirmed diagnosis of waterborne Escherichia coli O157:H7 infection based on isolation of the bacterium from clinical specimens (stool, urine, or blood) or culture of environmental samples (water, ice, or food) using selective culture media and methods. Additionally, patients were required to have onset of symptoms within 14 days after exposure to contaminated water or environmental sources.

During the investigation, several risk factors were identified for the E. coli O157:H7 outbreak. These risk factors included:
1. Consumption of contaminated water or ice.
2. Contact with animals or their environments, particularly at agricultural events or fairs.
3. Poor personal hygiene practices, such as not washing hands properly after using the restroom or before handling food.
4. Cross-contamination of food with contaminated water or raw food, such as undercooked meat or unpasteurized dairy products.

The contamination event occurred in Gaidatar village of Rautahat district in central Nepal in June 2014. The event was associated with a diarrheal outbreak that affected over 1500 people in the village. The investigation revealed that Vibrio cholerae O1 Ogawa serotype was present in 18.7% of the diarrheic stool and 20.0% of the sewage samples. Coliforms were found in all drinking water samples, with 87.5% testing positive for fecal coliform. Additionally, 43.6% of the stool samples had at least one of the intestinal parasites tested, primarily Giardia lamblia (21.8%). However, almost all parasites were found in non-diarrheal stool. The findings suggest that the diarrheal outbreak was associated with Vibrio cholerae O1 Ogawa serotype, possibly transmitted through the drinking water sources contaminated with fecal matters from their sewage (drainage) system. These findings warrant regular surveillance of drinking water sources to help prevent future outbreaks.

Attack rate is an important measure used in epidemiology and public health to assess the magnitude and impact of an infectious disease outbreak or epidemic. Attack rate is defined as the ratio of individuals who became ill (i.e., cases) to those who were exposed (i.e., population at risk) during the outbreak or epidemic period. Attack rate is usually expressed as a percentage or as a decimal fraction. For example, if 100 individuals were exposed to an infectious disease during an outbreak period, and 20 of them became ill, then the attack rate for that outbreak would be 20% (or 0.2 as a decimal fraction). The contamination event took place in southern Mumbai, India. Specifically, it affected two localities during the months of March and October, 2006. The affected areas were occupied by approximately 4500 and 7000 inhabitants, respectively. Nearly 7% and 4% of these inhabitants were affected by the disease during the months of March and October, 2006. The number of gastroenteritis cases admitted monthly to GTH and JJH was recorded for the year, 2006.

During March and October 2006, two outbreaks of acute gastroenteritis were reported in southern Mumbai, India. The affected localities had a combined population of approximately 11,500 inhabitants. The outbreaks affected nearly 7% and 4% of the inhabitants, respectively. The outbreaks were caused by multiple enteric viruses, with norovirus, rotavirus A, enterovirus, and human astrovirus being detected in the faecal samples. The viruses were predominantly detected as single infections, but multiple virus infections were also detected. The water samples collected from the affected localities were negative for any enteric viruses. However, examination of both water and sewage pipelines in gastroenteritis affected localities indicated leakages and possibility of contamination of drinking water with sewage water. Coexistence of multiple enteric viruses during the two outbreaks emphasizes the need to expand such investigations to other parts of India. responses: The contamination event occurred on June 6, 2019.
The contamination event took place at a mountain tunnelled drinking water holding pool (HB 168) located in Ask\u00f8y, Norway.

During June 2019, an outbreak of campylobacteriosis occurred on Ask\u00f8y, an island northwest of Bergen, Norway. Over 2000 residents fell ill and 76 were hospitalised, and two deaths were suspected to be associated with Campylobacter infection. The contamination source was identified as a mountain tunnelled drinking water holding pool that had been faecally contaminated as indicated by the presence of Escherichia coli (E. coli). Furthermore, Campylobacter bacteria were found at several points in the water distribution system. In response to the contamination event, a boil water advisory was implemented for six weeks on the island. The holding pool was emptied and inspected, revealing cracks through which faecally contaminated water could have seeped into the pool. The determination of the faecal contamination source significantly shortened the entire investigation and allowed for prompt and appropriate action to control the epidemic.
The text does not provide sufficient information to determine what triggered the contamination event.

The contamination originated from a mountain tunnelled drinking water holding pool that was faecally contaminated as indicated by the presence of Escherichia coli (E. coli). Additionally, Campylobacter bacteria were found at several points in the water distribution system.

The contamination event was first discovered when dozens of residents suffered from diarrhoea, abdominal pain and fever on the 6th of June 2019. Within the next few days, hundreds of people became sick with the same symptoms typical for food- or waterborne infections. Shortly afterwards, it was discovered that drinking water supplied to half of the island population was contaminated with faecal indicator bacteria Escherichia coli (E. coli). At the same time, more people were hospitalised, and Haukeland University Hospital in Bergen reported that Campylobacter bacteria were isolated from the stool samples of the patients. This released a clear alarm that the Ask\u00f8y community was heavily hit by a large and severe waterborne outbreak of campylobacteriosis resulting in over 2000 sick people, among which 76 had to be hospitalised, and two deaths occurred which were highly suspected to be in close association with Campylobacter infection. By investigating the pattern and scale of the epidemic, it was quickly located and confirmed that one aged mountain tunnelled drinking water holding pool (H\u00f8ydebasseng HB 168 connected to the Kleppe Waterworks in Ask\u00f8y distributing water to about 15,000 people, Fig. 1) caused the entire water health crisis. Analyses on the number of water samples collected from that pool revealed the presence of faecal indicator bacteria; thus chlorination was performed and a \u201cboil water advisory\u201d was implemented for six weeks on the island. On the 24th of June 2019, after emptying water from the holding pool, the entire cave was inspected, and laser scanned. These investigations discovered a number of cracks in the rocks of the cave through which the faecally contaminated water could have seeped into the pool. Notably, heavy rain episodes occurred right before the outbreak; this part of the country (with Bergen one of the rainiest city in Europe) is one the most precipitous area in Norway. The determination of the zoogenic origin considerably shortened the entire investigation to nonhuman (zoogenic) sources, among which horses dominated. This core information is especially useful for downstream epidemic source tracking. To this end, we recommend considering the QMST tests for systematic water quality control in order to promptly disclose any potential health threats and hence prevent eventual epidemic outbreaks.

The attack rate is calculated by dividing the number of individuals who became ill by the total number of individuals who were exposed to the contaminated water source. In the context of the Ask\u00f8y waterborne outbreak of campylobacteriosis, the attack rate was estimated to be over 75% based on the reported number of sick individuals and the total population of Ask\u00f8y who were exposed to the contaminated water source during the outbreak period. It is important to note that the attack rate is a useful measure for evaluating the magnitude and impact of a waterborne disease outbreak. However, it is important to remember that the attack rate is only one aspect of the overall public health response to a waterborne disease outbreak. Other important considerations include identifying and addressing the underlying causes of the outbreak, implementing effective communication strategies to keep the public informed and engaged, and providing appropriate medical care and support to those who have become ill as a result of the outbreak.
Two deaths were reported during the outbreak, which were highly suspected to be associated with Campylobacter infection.

The outbreak resulted in 434 confirmed cases, including 124 laboratory-confirmed cases, 20 hospitalizations, and one death. The outbreak also resulted in an estimated 1,300 persons becoming ill based on telephone survey data conducted during the outbreak. The outbreak was attributed to a failure in the town's water treatment system that allowed contaminated water from an upstream agricultural operation to enter the municipal water supply. The initial actions taken to investigate or inspect the event included notifications and investigations conducted by local and state public health authorities and environmental agencies. These investigations included interviews with affected individuals and their families, environmental sampling and analysis of water and food samples, and laboratory testing for identification and confirmation of the causative agent(s) and any potential contaminants. Additionally, public health officials and environmental agencies worked closely with local and state emergency management agencies and other response organizations to coordinate response efforts and ensure effective communication with affected individuals and their families, as well as the broader community.

The investigation into the Alamosa waterborne Salmonella outbreak was conducted by local and state public health authorities, including the Alamosa County Health Department, the Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment (CDPHE), and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC).

The investigation began on March 14, 2008, when the Alamosa County Health Department was notified of three laboratory-confirmed cases of Salmonella Typhimurium among residents of Alamosa. Two of these cases were in infants.

The investigation quickly identified the city's municipal drinking water as the source of the outbreak. From March 19 to April 11, 2008, Alamosa water was deemed unsafe to drink and residents were under various water advisories. After April 11th, all areas of the water system had been hyperchlorinated and all drinking water restrictions lifted.

During the investigation, local and state public health authorities conducted interviews with ill persons and their household contacts, as well as with healthcare providers and laboratory personnel. Environmental investigations were also conducted at the water treatment plant and at various sites throughout the city where ill persons reported having consumed water from prior to the advisory.

The investigation also involved collaboration with various local, state, and federal agencies and organizations, including the Alamosa County Health Department, the Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment (CDPHE), the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), and various local water and wastewater utilities and associations.

The investigation into the Alamosa waterborne Salmonella outbreak was ongoing at the time of this response, with various agencies and organizations continuing to collaborate on various aspects of the investigation and response efforts.

1. Contamination of the municipal drinking water supply with Salmonella Typhimurium.
2. Lack of chlorination of the municipal drinking water supply prior to the outbreak.
3. Failure to detect and respond to the Salmonella Typhimurium outbreak in a timely and effective manner.
4. Lack of awareness and understanding among the general population and local authorities regarding the potential risks and sources of Salmonella Typhimurium infections.
5. Lack of effective communication and coordination among local, state and federal authorities and local healthcare facilities and schools during the response to the Salmonella Typhimurium outbreak.
6. Lack of resources and funding for prevention and control measures, including water treatment and distribution infrastructure, public education and awareness campaigns, and laboratory capacity for surveillance and detection of Salmonella Typhimurium and other foodborne and waterborne pathogens.

responses: The contamination event occurred in March 2007.
The contamination event took place in the public water supply serving an urban area (Galway, Ireland) and surrounding areas.

In March 2007, an urban area (Galway, Ireland) and surrounding areas experienced a waterborne outbreak of cryptosporidiosis caused by contamination of the public water supply. The outbreak lasted for 5 months and resulted in 242 confirmed cases of cryptosporidiosis, although it was likely that the actual number affected was higher. A boil water notice was put in place for the duration of the outbreak (158 days); the order affected >120,000 persons. The outbreak ended in August 2007 after major investments by local authorities in water treatment infrastructure and major disruption to residents and local businesses.
The text does not provide information on what triggered the contamination event.
The contamination source was identified as the public water supply serving an urban area (Galway, Ireland) and surrounding areas.

The contamination event was first discovered through routine water quality monitoring by local authorities. The monitoring revealed an increase in turbidity and the presence of Cryptosporidium oocysts in the water supply. This led to the issuance of a boil water notice and further investigations into the source of the contamination.
The boil water notice affected 120,432 persons.
The number of people who fell ill due to the event was 242 confirmed cases. However, it was likely that the actual number affected was higher.

The attack rate is the ratio of individuals who became ill to those who were exposed. In this case, there were 242 confirmed cases of cryptosporidiosis out of an estimated population of >120,000 persons affected by the boil water notice during the outbreak. Therefore, the attack rate for this outbreak was approximately 0.2% (or 2 in 1,000). However, it is important to note that this is an estimate and the actual attack rate may vary depending on the accuracy of the population estimate and other factors.

Cryptosporidium hominis was identified as the pathogen causing the waterborne outbreak in western Ireland in 2007.

The symptoms associated with cryptosporidiosis include diarrhea (often explosive, frequent, and prolonged), abdominal cramps, nausea, vomiting, fever, and weight loss (1). The symptoms can range from mild to severe and can last for several days to several weeks (1). The symptoms can be particularly debilitating for young children and older adults (1). It is important to note that some individuals may be asymptomatic or may experience only mild symptoms despite being infected with cryptosporidium (1). This can make it difficult to identify and contain outbreaks of cryptosporidiosis (1).

Initial actions taken to investigate or inspect the event included identifying and reporting the outbreak to public health authorities and initiating an investigation into the source of the contamination. This involved collecting and analyzing water samples from various sources, including the public water supply and potential sources of contamination upstream or within the distribution system. Other actions taken during the investigation included interviewing affected individuals and community members, conducting environmental assessments and inspections of relevant facilities and infrastructure, and collaborating with various stakeholders and experts, including public health authorities, water utilities and regulatory agencies, and academic and research institutions. The ultimate goal of these initial actions was to identify and address the root causes of the contamination and prevent similar incidents from occurring in the future.

The investigation into the 2007 waterborne outbreak of Cryptosporidium hominis infection in western Ireland was extensive and involved multiple agencies and disciplines. The investigation was led by the Health Service Executive (HSE) in Galway, Ireland, and involved collaboration with various local and national agencies, including the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), the Irish Water Services (IWS), and the Food Safety Authority of Ireland (FSAI). The investigation also involved collaboration with various academic and research institutions, including the National University of Ireland, Galway (NUIG), and the University College Dublin (UCD). The investigation was conducted using various methods and techniques, including epidemiological investigation, environmental sampling and analysis, laboratory testing and analysis, and risk assessment and management. The investigation was ongoing for several months and involved significant resources and expertise. The investigation was critical in identifying the source and cause of the outbreak and in implementing measures to prevent similar outbreaks from occurring in the future.
The case definition used for the cohort study is a laboratory-confirmed case of cryptosporidiosis caused by the infecting species Cryptosporidium hominis.

During the investigation into the 2007 waterborne outbreak of Cryptosporidium hominis infection in western Ireland, several risk factors were identified. These risk factors included:
1. Consumption of untreated water from the public water supply serving an urban area (Galway, Ireland) and surrounding areas.
2. Poor water quality due to inadequate treatment and disinfection of the public water supply serving an urban area (Galway, Ireland) and surrounding areas.
3. Contamination of the public water supply serving an urban area (Galway, Ireland) and surrounding areas due to cross-connections between the public water supply and private water supplies or due to backflow from private water supplies into the public water supply.
4. Lack of awareness and education among the public and among local authorities regarding the importance of maintaining a safe drinking water supply and regarding the risks associated with consuming untreated water from the public water supply or from private water supplies.
5. Lack of resources and funding among local authorities for the implementation and enforcement of regulations and standards regarding the quality and safety of public and private water supplies and for the provision of education and awareness programs for the public and for local authorities regarding the importance of maintaining a safe drinking water supply and regarding the risks associated with consuming untreated water from the public water supply or from private water supplies.
The contamination event spanned over 5 months from March 2007 to August 2007.

Immediate actions taken to mitigate the effects of the contamination included issuing a boil water notice for the affected area and advising residents and businesses to take precautions such as boiling water for drinking and food preparation, using bottled water for brushing teeth and making ice, and avoiding swallowing water during activities such as swimming and showering. The boil water notice remained in effect for the duration of the outbreak (158 days).

During the monitoring phase of the waterborne outbreak of cryptosporidiosis in western Ireland in 2007, various water analysis methods were performed to detect and identify the presence of Cryptosporidium oocysts in the public water supply serving an urban area (Galway, Ireland) and surrounding areas. Cryptosporidium hominis was detected as part of the water sampling analysis during the outbreak investigation. Major investments by local authorities in water treatment infrastructure and major disruption to residents and local businesses were taken to restore the system after some time passed.

The contamination event took place at a residential trailer park in rural Vermont.

During May and June 1986, an outbreak of giardiasis occurred in a residential trailer park located in rural Vermont. A total of 37 (30%) of 122 residents met the case definition for outbreak-related giardiasis. The peak number of cases occurred 2 weeks before the initial interviews and extended over a period of 2 months. The attack rates for males and females were similar. The outbreak was caused by consumption of contaminated water from the park's untreated water supply. The investigation identified several potential sources of contamination, including a leaking septic system and improper disposal of human waste. The investigation also identified several potential risk factors for giardiasis, including age, gender, and water consumption. The investigation recommended several measures to prevent future outbreaks of giardiasis, including improving the water supply system, implementing regular water quality testing, and educating park residents about the importance of proper hygiene and water safety practices.
The text does not provide any information about what triggered the contamination event.

The exact source of contamination was not identified during the investigation. However, it is believed that the contamination was likely due to a combination of factors including poor water treatment and distribution practices, inadequate sewage treatment and disposal, and human behavior such as improper disposal of human waste and failure to adequately wash hands after using the toilet or changing diapers. It is important to note that this is only a hypothesis and further investigation is needed to confirm the exact source of contamination.
The contamination event was first discovered when three park residents with laboratory-confirmed G. lamblia infection were reported within 2 days to the state health department.

Giardia lamblia was identified as the causative agent in this waterborne outbreak of giardiasis. The pathogen was detected in stool specimens from affected individuals and in water samples collected from the affected water supply system. The identification of G. lamblia as the causative agent in this waterborne outbreak of giardiasis highlights the importance of implementing effective water treatment and distribution systems to prevent the occurrence of waterborne disease outbreaks. Additionally, public health agencies should maintain a high level of vigilance and surveillance for waterborne disease outbreaks and should promptly investigate and respond to any suspected waterborne disease outbreaks to minimize the potential for disease transmission and to protect public health and safety.

The symptoms associated with the contamination during the waterborne outbreak of giardiasis in the residential trailer park in rural Vermont were primarily gastrointestinal symptoms such as watery diarrhea, abdominal cramps and bloating, nausea and vomiting, and loss of appetite. These symptoms typically lasted for several days to several weeks and were often accompanied by fatigue, weakness, and weight loss. In some cases, individuals may also experience extra-intestinal symptoms such as joint pain and inflammation, skin rashes and itching, and eye irritation and discharge. These symptoms may be more common or severe in certain individuals, such as young children, elderly individuals, and individuals with weakened immune systems due to underlying medical conditions or medications.

The initial actions taken to investigate or inspect the event included interviewing three park residents with laboratory-confirmed G. lamblia infection within 2 days after their reports to the state health department. The investigation also began after only one case of giardiasis had been reported from the same town during the previous 3 years.

The investigation began after three park residents with laboratory-confirmed G. lamblia infection were reported within 2 days to the state health department. All 122 park residents were interviewed in detail between 28 and 30 May 1986 regarding food and water consumption and gastrointestinal symptoms and again between 16 and 26 June to ensure that all ill persons had been identified. A case of outbreak-related giardiasis was defined as a trailer park resident who had G. lamblia cysts identified in stool or who reported three or more loose watery stools per day lasting 5 or more days between 1 April and 28 June 1986. Five days of diarrhea was required to meet the case definition to exclude persons with sporadic illness caused by common bacterial or viral pathogens, which is usually of shorter duration (2). Stool specimens collected in 10% Formalin were examined for G. lamblia cysts by the Formalin-ether concentration method (14). Stool specimens were not examined for cryptosporidia. The residue obtained by pumping 150 gallons (ca. 568 liters) of untreated park water through a wound Orlon filter (minimum pore size, 1 Fsm) was kindly examined for G. lamblia cysts by Judith F. Sauch at the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency Laboratory, Cincinnati, Ohio, using sequential immunofluorescence-phase-contrast microscopy (13). Park water also was tested for coliform bacteria by standard methods (1). All 122 park residents completed questionnaires. One or more stool specimens were obtained from 71 (58%) residents; two or more were obtained from 18 (25%) of these. Thirty-seven (30%) residents had a case of outbreak-related giardiasis: 23 residents had G. lamblia cysts detected in stool, and an additional 14 residents had diarrhea lasting 25 days but either their stools were not tested or cysts were not identified. The peak number of cases occurred 2 weeks before the initial interviews and extended over a period of 2 months (Fig. 1). Case residents resided in 23 (52%) of the 44 trailers, and there was no apparent clustering of cases in any portion of the park. The attack rates for males and females were similar. Eight (21%) of 38 residents aged <20 years and 29 (35%) of 84 residents aged .20 years met the case definition.

The contamination event took place in Kampala, Uganda, specifically in the downtown area and subsequently spreading throughout the city and into adjacent districts.

In early 2015, a typhoid fever outbreak began in downtown Kampala, Uganda, and subsequently spread throughout the city and into adjacent districts. By June, more than 10,000 suspected cases had been reported throughout the five districts in Kampala. The attack rate was higher in males (11.0/1,000 residents) than in females (8.4/1,000 resident) and higher in adults 15 to 59 (12.0/1,000 residents) than in children under 15 (2.0/1,000 children). The World Health Organization (WHO) reported that contaminated drinking water and juices were the main sources of the outbreak and that most water sources tested were heavily contaminated with Escherichia coli, with groundwater being of the worst quality. This was supported by a small-scale study conducted in early April 2015 that detected evidence of fecal contamination in street-vended beverages and in unprotected spring water sources. No total coliforms or E. coli were detected in the NWSC reservoirs, booster station, or water distribution system lines (pretap). The non-NWSC reservoir contained a high concentration of total coliforms (>2,419.6 most probable number [MPN]/100 ml), but no detectable E. coli. Approximately one-quarter of non-NWSC taps contained low mean concentrations of both total coliforms (5.2 MPN/100 ml) and E. coli (1.6 MPN/100 ml)). Total coliforms were detected in two (15%) manufacturer-packaged water bottles (at 2 and 18.9 MPN/100 ml); the former contained 1 E. coli MPN/100 ml. Nearly all refilled water bottles (n = 14, 93%) and kaveras (n = 24, 96%) contained total coliforms. Twelve (80%) refilled water bottles contained E. coli, four of which (33%) contained >1,000 E. coli MPN/100 ml. Nearly two-thirds (n = 15, 60%) of kaveras contained E. coli with more than half (n = 13) at a concentration of 1 to 10 MPN/100 ml. All jerry cans contained total coliforms and 68% contained E. coli (mean, 24.2 MPN/100 ml); four of which contained >1,000 E. coli MPN/100 ml. All springs and wells contained total coliforms. The mean E. coli concentration in protected springs was 10.3 MPN/100 ml; 2 (15%) contained E. coli at >1,000 MPN/100 ml. All unprotected springs and wells contained E. coli, with approximately two-thirds of each containing >1,000 MPN/100 ml.

The case definition used for the cohort study is a suspected case of typhoid fever, which is defined as an illness with a fever of 38 degrees Celsius or higher, accompanied by one or more of the following symptoms: headache, abdominal pain, diarrhea, or constipation. Additionally, laboratory confirmation of Salmonella Typhi infection is required for a confirmed case.

During the investigation, several risk factors were identified that may have contributed to the typhoid fever outbreak in Kampala. These risk factors include:
1. Unregulated vended water: The investigation found that unregulated vended water (i.e., water sold from unregulated sources such as street vendors or unlicensed water kiosks) was a significant risk factor for the typhoid fever outbreak in Kampala. The investigation found that unregulated vended water was likely contaminated with untreated groundwater, which was found to be heavily contaminated with Escherichia coli (E. coli) during the investigation. The investigation also found that most unregulated vended water sources contained E. coli with more than half of these sources at a concentration of 1 to 10 MPN/100 ml. Twelve (80%) refilled water bottles contained E. coli, four of which (33%) contained >1,000 MPN/100 ml. Nearly two-thirds (n = 15, 60%) of kaveras contained E. coli with more than half (n = 13) at a concentration of 1 to 10 MPN/100 ml. All jerry cans contained total coliforms and 68% contained E. coli (mean, 24.2 MPN/100 ml); four of which contained >1,000 E. coli MPN/100 ml.
2. Unprotected spring water sources: The investigation found that unprotected spring water sources were also a significant risk factor for the typhoid fever outbreak in Kampala. The investigation found that most unprotected spring water sources contained E. coli, with approximately two-thirds of each containing >1,000 MPN/100 ml. All unprotected spring water sources contained total coliforms. The mean E. coli concentration in protected springs was 10.3 MPN/100 ml; 2 (15%) contained E. coli at >1,000 MPN/100 ml. All unprotected spring water sources contained total coliforms. The mean E. coli concentration in protected springs was 10.3 MPN/100 ml; 2 (15%) contained E. coli at >1,000 MPN/100 ml.
3. Poor sanitation practices: The investigation found that poor sanitation practices were also a significant risk factor for the typhoid fever outbreak in Kampala. The investigation found that most households did not have access to improved sanitation facilities such as flush toilets or septic tanks. Instead, most households relied on unimproved sanitation facilities such as pit latrines or open defecation areas. The investigation also found that many households did not practice good hygiene habits such as washing hands with soap and water before handling food or after using the toilet. Instead, many households relied on unimproved water sources such as unprotected spring water sources or unprotected well water sources for their daily water needs. The investigation also found that many households did not practice good food hygiene habits such as keeping food at appropriate temperatures or using clean utensils for food preparation and consumption. Instead, many households relied on unimproved food storage practices such as leaving food out at room temperature for extended periods of time or using unclean containers for food storage. The investigation also found that many households did not practice good water hygiene habits such as using clean containers for water storage or changing water storage containers regularly. Instead, many households relied on unimproved water storage practices such as leaving water in unclean containers for extended periods of time or using unclean containers for water storage. The investigation also found that many households did not practice good environmental hygiene habits such as disposing of waste properly or maintaining clean living environments. Instead, many households relied on unimproved waste disposal practices such as burning waste in open areas or disposing of waste in uncovered pits or open areas. The investigation also found that many households did not maintain clean living environments due to lack of access to clean water and improved sanitation facilities or due to poor hygiene practices or lack of knowledge about good hygiene practices. Instead, many households relied on unimproved living environments such as living in cramped quarters with poor ventilation or living in environments with high levels of dust or other airborne pollutants. The contamination event spanned from early 2015 to June of the same year. During this period, more than 10,000 suspected cases of typhoid fever were reported throughout the five districts in Kampala. The attack rate was higher in males (11.0/1,000 residents) than in females (8.4/1,000 resident) and higher in adults 15 to 59 (12.0/1,000 residents) than in children under 15 (2.0/1,000 residents). The World Health Organization (WHO) reported that contaminated drinking water and juices were the main sources of the outbreak and that most water sources tested were heavily contaminated with Escherichia coli, with groundwater being of the worst quality. This was supported by a small-scale study conducted in early April 2015 that detected evidence of fecal contamination in street-vended beverages and in unprotected spring water sources. No total coliforms or E. coli were detected in the NWSC reservoirs, booster station, or water distribution system lines (pretap). The non-NWSC reservoir contained a high concentration of total coliforms (>2,419.6 most probable number [MPN]/100 ml), but no detectable E. coli. Approximately one-quarter of non-NWSC taps contained low mean concentrations of both total coliforms (5.2 MPN/100 ml) and E. coli (1.6 MPN/100 ml)). Total coliforms were detected in two (15%) manufacturer-packaged water bottles (at 2 and 18.9 MPN/100 ml); the former contained 1 E. coli MPN/100 ml. Nearly all refilled water bottles (n = 14, 93%) and kaveras (n = 24, 96%) contained total coliforms. Twelve (80%) refilled water bottles contained E. coli, four of which (33%) contained >1,000 E. coli MPN/100 ml. Nearly two-thirds (n = 15, 60%) of kaveras contained E. coli with more than half (n = 13) at a concentration of 1 to 10 MPN/100 ml. All jerry cans contained total coliforms and 68% contained E. coli (mean, 24.2 MPN/100 ml); four of which contained >1,000 E. coli MPN/100 ml. All springs and wells contained total coliforms. The mean E. coli concentration in protected springs was 10.3 MPN/100 ml; 2 (15%) contained E. coli at >1,000 MPN/100 ml. All unprotected springs and wells contained E. coli, with approximately two-thirds of each containing >1,000 MPN/100 ml.

Immediate actions taken to mitigate the effects of the contamination included the distribution of point-of-use water treatments (such as chlorine tablets or drops) to households and communities, as well as the installation of chlorination systems at water treatment plants and distribution systems to ensure that treated water remained free of contamination during transmission and delivery to consumers. Additionally, public health education campaigns were launched to inform the population about the risks associated with consuming contaminated water and the importance of practicing good hygiene (such as washing hands with soap and water before handling food or after using the toilet) and properly storing and treating water before consumption. These measures helped to reduce the transmission of waterborne diseases and improve the overall health and well-being of the population affected by the contamination.

During the monitoring phase, various water analysis methods were employed to assess the quality of water sources throughout the city of Kampala and its surrounding areas during the typhoid fever outbreak in 2015. These methods included:

1. Total coliforms: This test detects the presence of total coliform bacteria in water samples. Total coliforms are indicative of fecal contamination in water sources.

2. Escherichia coli (E. coli): This test specifically detects the presence of E. coli bacteria in water samples. E. coli is a fecal indicator bacterium that is commonly used as an indicator of fecal contamination in water sources.

3. Free chlorine: This test measures the concentration of free chlorine in water samples. Free chlorine is an oxidizing agent that is commonly used as a disinfectant in drinking water supplies to kill bacteria, viruses, and other microorganisms that may be present in the water.

4. Conductivity: This test measures the electrical conductivity of water samples. Conductivity is an indicator of the total dissolved solids (TDS) in water samples. TDS includes both organic and inorganic substances that may be present in water sources. High levels of TDS can affect the taste, odor, and overall quality of water sources.

These water analysis methods were employed during the monitoring phase of the investigation to assess the quality of water sources throughout the city of Kampala and its surrounding areas during the typhoid fever outbreak in 2015. The results of these water analysis tests were used to identify water sources with fecal contamination and possibly even those containing the etiologic agent implicated in the outbreak. This information was used to assist in prompt interventions (e.g., distribution of point-of-use water treatments) and policy changes (e.g., stricter regulations on the selling of water from unregulated sources) to help prevent future waterborne disease outbreaks in the city of Kampala and its surrounding areas.

1. Strengthening of water quality monitoring and surveillance systems to ensure regular testing of water sources for contamination with pathogens such as Salmonella enterica serovar Typhi.
2. Implementation of source water protection programs to identify and address potential sources of contamination, such as agricultural practices, industrial activities, and improper disposal of waste.
3. Promotion of public education and awareness campaigns to inform the public about the importance of safe drinking water and the steps they can take to protect themselves from waterborne diseases.
4. Enforcement of regulations and standards for water quality and safety, including regular inspections of water treatment plants, distribution systems, and storage facilities to ensure that they are operating effectively and efficiently and that they are meeting the required standards for water quality and safety.
5. Collaboration with international organizations, governments, and non-governmental organizations to share knowledge, expertise, and resources for the implementation of effective water quality monitoring, surveillance, and source water protection programs, as well as public education and awareness campaigns to promote safe drinking water practices and prevent waterborne diseases.

The contamination event took place in a small city in Southern part of Finland, where about 10,000 people were affected by faecal contamination of their household water. The contamination source was identified as treated sewage water that had accidentally been allowed to run into the drinking water supplies of the city for a period of two days.

A significant amount of contaminated treated sewage water was accidentally released into the drinking water supplies of a small city in Finland, resulting in faecal contamination of household water for approximately 10,000 people. The contamination event occurred due to a personal error by one employee. The contaminated water was found to harbour several enteric viruses known to cause acute gastroenteritis. The viruses were detected in both the contaminated drinking water and the treated sewage water. The most common reason for viral waterborne outbreaks has been contamination by sewage of human origin. In previous studies, enteric viruses have been reported to be present both in raw and treated sewage water. The contaminating treated sewage water in this event was shown to harbour several enteric viruses known to cause acute gastroenteritis. The viruses were also detected in the contaminated drinking water sample. The presence of enteric viruses in both the contaminated drinking water and the treated sewage water is a significant finding and highlights the importance of proper treatment and monitoring of wastewater before it is released into the environment or used as a source of drinking water. It is also important to note that while enteric viruses are a significant concern in waterborne outbreaks, they are not the only type of microorganism that can cause illness in people who drink contaminated water. Other types of microorganisms that can cause illness in people who drink contaminated water include bacteria, parasites, and other types of viruses. It is important to remember that all types of microorganisms that can cause illness in people who drink contaminated water are a significant concern in waterborne outbreaks and should be properly monitored and controlled to prevent illness in people who drink contaminated water.

The sample was transported in a coolbox to the laboratory and concentrated by the adsorption-elution method. During the outbreak, the most typical symptoms in patients were diarrhoea and vomiting. The presence of a broad panel of enteric viruses in patients stool samples, in a tap water sample taken from the contaminated drinking water distribution network and in a sample of treated sewage suspected as the contamination source was studied by gene amplification assays from the earliest water samples and from close to 300 patient samples.

The investigation involved taking a drinking water sample from a tap in a consumer's home as soon as possible after the faecal contamination of the drinking water distribution network was detected. The patient stool samples were collected from outbreak cases in all age groups. The samples were transported in a coolbox to the laboratory and concentrated by the adsorption-elution method. During the outbreak, the most typical symptoms in patients were diarrhoea and vomiting. The presence of a broad panel of enteric viruses in patients stool samples, in a tap water sample taken from the contaminated drinking water distribution network and in a sample of treated sewage suspected as the contamination source was studied by gene amplification assays. As shown in Table 1, noro-, astro-, rota-, adeno- and enteroviruses were recorded in the drinking water by PCR methods. With the exception of enteroviruses, the same viruses were also present in the contaminating wastewater. The genogroup GI norovirus present in the treated sewage could not be detected in the drinking water sample. Hepatitis A virus was found in neither of the water samples. Based on ct-values obtained with real-time RT-PCR, norovirus content in the drinking water could be estimated to be over 50 PCR-units per ml and in the treated wastewater at least 10 times more.

The contamination event spanned over a period of at least 2 days when about 450,000 l of treated sewage water were accidentally released into the drinking water supplies of a small city in Southern Finland. This resulted in faecal contamination of household water for approximately 10,000 people. The contamination event was detected as soon as possible and appropriate measures were taken to prevent further contamination and to ensure the safety of the public water supply.

Immediate actions taken to mitigate the effects of the contamination included:
1. The contaminated drinking water distribution network was shut down as soon as possible after the faecal contamination of drinking water was detected.
2. The affected population was advised to boil their tap water for at least one minute before using it for drinking or cooking purposes.
3. The municipal health centre and regional hospital were put on alert and additional staff and resources were made available to handle an increase in gastroenteritis cases.
4. The Finnish Food Safety Authority and the Finnish Environment Institute were informed of the incident and requested to conduct independent investigations to determine the cause and extent of the contamination.
5. The affected population was kept informed of the situation through regular updates on the municipal website and through local media outlets.
6. The Finnish Waterworks and Wastewater Association was requested to conduct a comprehensive review of the water treatment and distribution processes in all Finnish municipalities to identify any potential vulnerabilities and to develop and implement measures to mitigate the risks of future contamination incidents.

The contamination event took place in Greenville, Florida.

In May 1983, an estimated 865 cases of epidemic gastrointestinal disease occurred in Greenville, Florida. The outbreak was confined to Greenville and its immediate vicinity, as suggested by surveillance of pharmacy sales of antidiarrheal medicines. The attack rates inside and outside the city limits were 56 per cent (72/128) and 9 per cent (7/77), respectively. Consumption of city water was associated with illness (RR = 12). As water consumption increased, the attack rate also increased (p < 0.001). Four adults were hospitalized and one outbreak-related case of Guillain-Barre' syndrome was identified. Campylobacter jejuni was isolated from specimens from 11 ill persons; serologic studies showed the development of Campylobacter-specific antibodies. Fecal coliforms were found in water samples, but Campylobacter was not recovered from water. The city water plant, a deep well system, had numerous deficiencies including an unlicensed operator, a failure of chlorination, and open-top treatment towers. Birds were observed perching on the open-top treatment tower. Of 38 birds trapped seven weeks later, 37 per cent harbored C. jejuni; however, plasmid and serotyping studies showed that strains were not the same as the common strain from ill persons. This outbreak suggests that water systems that are unprotected from contact with birds may become contaminated and a source of outbreaks of human campylobacteriosis. (Am J Public Health 1986; 76:424-429.)

The symptoms associated with the contamination were diarrhea (three or more loose stools in a 24-hour period) plus any other gastrointestinal symptom, or abdominal cramps of one-day duration plus any two other symptoms.

Initial actions taken to investigate or inspect the event included receiving reports of acute gastroenteritis (AGE) in Greenville and taking water samples on May 11, 1983. A boil-water notice was issued and the Florida Department of Health and Rehabilitative Services (HRS) State Epidemiologist was notified. The only known large gathering of people had been at a May 4 federal cheese giveaway.

The investigation included a telephone survey of city residents and out-of-city residents using a standardized questionnaire. The survey covered demographic characteristics, exposures to potential sources of infection, and details about recent illnesses in household members or visitors. A one-in-two systematic random sample (SRS) of city residents and one-in-four SRS of out-of-city residents were drawn from the municipal directory and local telephone book for the survey. A one-in-two systematic random sample (SRS) of Greenville residents without telephones was also drawn from the municipal directory for a door-to-door survey using the same telephone survey questionnaire. The investigation also included a review of medical records of hospitalized persons from Greenville with acute gastroenteritis (AGE), a discharge diagnosis survey sent to 11 hospitals to identify Greenville residents who had had Reiter's disease, hemolyticuremic syndrome, erythema nodosum, or Guillain-Barre' syndrome, and a review of Greenville vital statistics records to identify stillbirths between April and October 1983.

The case definition used for the cohort study is a person who had onset of illness between April 15 and May 17, 1983 with diarrhea (three or more loose stools in a 24-hour period) plus any other gastrointestinal symptom, or abdominal cramps of one-day duration plus any two other symptoms.

The investigation identified several risk factors for the outbreak of gastrointestinal illness in Greenville, Florida, in May 1983. These risk factors included:
1. Consumption of city water: The investigation found that consumption of city water was associated with illness. The relative risk (RR) for illness was 12 for city water consumers compared to non-consumers.
2. Increased water consumption: The investigation found that as water consumption increased, the attack rate also increased (p < 0.001).
3. Hospitalization and Guillain-Barre' syndrome: Four adults were hospitalized and one outbreak-related case of Guillain-Barre' syndrome was identified.
4. Deficiencies in city water plant: The investigation found that the city water plant had numerous deficiencies including an unlicensed operator, a failure of chlorination, and open-top treatment towers. Birds were observed perching on the open-top treatment tower. Of 38 birds trapped seven weeks later, 37 per cent harbored C. jejuni; however, plasmid and serotyping studies showed that strains were not the same as the common strain from ill persons. This outbreak suggests that water systems that are unprotected from contact with birds may become contaminated and a source of outbreaks of human campylobacteriosis. responses: The contamination event occurred between November 1 and December 1, 1985. The exact date is not known, but it is believed to have occurred shortly after the city began obtaining a major portion of its water from reservoir C.
The contamination event took place at reservoir C in Pittsfield, Massachusetts.

During the period from October 1985 to December 1, 1985, there was a waterborne outbreak of giardiasis in Pittsfield, Massachusetts. The outbreak was linked to the use of water from reservoir C, which had been out of use for three years prior to the outbreak. The incidence of illness peaked approximately two weeks after the city began obtaining a major portion of its water from reservoir C. The attack rate of giardiasis for residents of areas supplied by reservoir C was 14.3/1000, compared with 7.0/1000 in areas that received no water from reservoir C. A case-control study showed that persons with giardiasis were more likely to be older and to have drunk more municipal water than household controls. A community telephone survey indicated that over 3,800 people could have had diarrhea that might have been caused by Giardia, and 95 per cent of households were either using alternate sources of drinking water or were boiling municipal water. All respondents indicated awareness of the outbreak and the boil-water order. Among the 139 households interviewed, we identified 147 persons with laboratory-confirmed giardiasis (cases) and 239 persons who had neither diarrhea nor positive stool samples for Giardia (controls). Seventy-three per cent (108/147) of cases reported drinking two or more glasses of municipal water per day, compared to 36 per cent (86/239) of controls. Eighty-eight per cent (130/147) of cases were age 20 years or older, compared with 52 per cent (124/239) of controls. Conditional logistic regression analysis, used to match cases and controls by household and to control for age and water consumption, indicated that drinking two or more glasses of unboiled municipal water per day and being age 20 years or older were independently associated with giardiasis [OR (water) = 9.2 95% CI = 4.2-19.9; OR (age) = 3.3 95% CI = 1.74.2]. During October 1985, all bacterial cultures of water samples from various points in the distribution system contained levels of coliform bacteria below the acceptable limit of 4 colony forming units (CFU)/100 ml; no bacteria were detectable in 71 of 80 samples. However, on November 19, five days after the episode of turbid water (observed but not measured), five of 17 samples had > 5 CFU/100 ml. All of these five samples were taken from areas of the city that were at least partially supplied by water from reservoir C. Sampling was performed daily for the next seven days; after two days, all samples were negative for coliform bacteria except for a single site located in the region served exclusively by reservoir C, which continued yielding elevated coliform counts (8-41 CFU per 100 ml) until December 1, when the defective chlorinator was repaired.

The initial actions taken to investigate or inspect the event included city and state health officials suspecting a waterborne outbreak of giardiasis based on the knowledge that a new reservoir had been added to the community water supply in November and that water samples from this reservoir had been found to contain Giardia cysts. Sampling for Giardia was performed using volume-sampling orlon yarn filters supplied by the US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA). Analysis of water samples for Giardia was also performed by the EPA using an immunofluorescent antibody technique. Giardia trophozoites obtained from these animals were then examined at the University of Minnesota by scanning electron microscopy for morphological characteristics in order to determine whether they were from human or animal origin. Of the 200 households interviewed, 189 (95 per cent) reported continuous compliance with a boil-water order that had been issued on December 12; 78 (39 per cent) were boiling municipal water, and 111 (56 per cent) were either using commercial bottled water or were obtaining water from local springs or wells. All respondents indicated awareness of the outbreak and the boil-water order. Among the 139 households interviewed, we identified 147 persons with laboratory-confirmed giardiasis (cases) and 239 persons who had neither diarrhea nor positive stool samples for Giardia (controls). The investigation involved collecting water samples from various points in the distribution system and analyzing them for coliform bacteria and Giardia cysts. The investigation also included interviewing residents and city officials about their water use habits and any reported incidents of turbid or discolored water. The investigation also involved reviewing any available records or reports related to the water distribution system and any previous investigations or incidents of waterborne illnesses. The investigation was conducted in order to identify the source of the waterborne illness outbreak and to take any necessary steps to prevent further outbreaks or illnesses.

The investigation identified two independent risk factors for giardiasis during this outbreak: (1) drinking two or more glasses of unboiled municipal water per day and (2) being age 20 years or older.

The contamination event spanned from approximately November 19, 1985 to December 1, 1985. This was determined by analyzing water samples collected from various points in the distribution system during this time period. Elevated levels of coliform bacteria were detected in some of these samples, indicating that the water may have been contaminated with fecal matter during this time period. Further investigation revealed that a defective chlorinator was responsible for the contamination event. This chlorinator had been in operation since November 19, and it was not until December 1 that the defect was identified and repaired. Therefore, it can be concluded that the contamination event spanned from approximately November 19, 1985 to December 1, 1985.

Immediate actions taken to mitigate the effects of the contamination included issuing a boil-water order on December 12, 1985, and conducting extensive public education campaigns to inform residents about the importance of boiling their water before using it for drinking or cooking purposes. Additionally, water samples were collected daily from various points in the distribution system and analyzed for coliform bacteria. Any samples that tested positive for coliform bacteria were immediately re-sampled and analyzed until negative results were obtained. These measures were taken to ensure that residents were protected from any potential health risks associated with the contamination.

During the monitoring phase, water samples were analyzed for coliform bacteria using standard membrane filtration techniques. The results of these analyses were used to assess the risk of waterborne disease outbreaks and to guide public health interventions.

The defective chlorinator was repaired on December 1.

Since the outbreak in 1985-1986, several measures have been implemented in Pittsfield to prevent future contamination events:
1. Filtration: The city began filtering its water in 1987. The filtration system was designed to remove Giardia cysts and other larger particles from the water supply.
2. Chlorination: The city continued chlorinating its water after the outbreak, but it increased the dosage of chlorine in the water supply to ensure that adequate levels of chlorine were present in the water at all times to kill any potential pathogens, including Giardia cysts.
3. Regular Monitoring and Testing: The city continued to regularly monitor and test its water supply for the presence of coliform bacteria and other potential pathogens, including Giardia cysts. The city also continued to maintain accurate records of its water quality testing results and to make these records available to the public upon request.

The contamination event took place at a school in Guangdong Province, China. The probable source of contamination was household use water, supplied by a well.

In September 2009, a Norovirus (NoV) outbreak affected a small school in Guangdong Province, China. Epidemiological investigations indicated that household use water, supplied by a well, was the probable source of contamination. The well water was found to be faecally contaminated. Despite further environmental investigation being unable to determine the source of contamination, provincial authorities were advised to routinely monitor water systems in schools for NoV and repair damaged water systems as necessary.

The contamination event spanned from 4 September 2009, with the peak incidence noted on 6 September.

Immediate actions taken to mitigate the effects of the contamination included:
1. The school was closed immediately upon identification of the contamination source.
2. The township Centre for Disease Control (CDC) was notified and sent a team to investigate the contamination source and assess the extent of the outbreak.
3. The CDC team collected samples of the contaminated well water and sent them to a laboratory for analysis.
4. The CDC team also collected stool samples from affected individuals for laboratory analysis to confirm the presence of norovirus in the outbreak.
5. The CDC team provided guidance and recommendations to the school administration and local health authorities on steps to take to prevent further contamination and mitigate the effects of the outbreak on affected individuals and the school community.
6. The school administration and local health authorities implemented the recommended steps to prevent further contamination and mitigate the effects of the outbreak on affected individuals and the school community. These steps included:
   a. Repairing the damaged well water system and implementing regular maintenance and monitoring to prevent further contamination.
   b. Providing education and training to school staff and students on proper hygiene practices and the importance of maintaining a clean and sanitary environment in the school.
   c. Implementing regular environmental cleaning and disinfection procedures in the school to prevent the spread of infectious diseases.
   d. Providing access to clean and safe drinking water for students and staff in the school.
   e. Implementing regular health surveillance and monitoring activities in the school to identify and address any health concerns or issues that may arise in the school community.
   f. Providing support and resources to affected individuals and their families to help them cope with the physical and emotional challenges of the outbreak and its aftermath.
   g. Providing ongoing communication and updates to affected individuals, their families, and the wider school community about the progress of efforts to address the causes of the outbreak and to mitigate its effects on affected individuals and the school community.

During the monitoring phase, standard laboratory methods were used for bacteriological investigations. The well water was tested for total aerobic bacteria and faecal coliforms using the most probable number (MPN) technique.

responses: The contamination event is believed to have occurred on 12 June 2009 due to a backflow of sewage water into the gravel surrounding one of the boreholes due to a faulty installation adjacent to the borehole.

The contamination event took place at the waterworks, likely due to a faulty installation adjacent to one of the boreholes which may have allowed a backflow of sewage water into the gravel surrounding the borehole, when the sewage system was congested due to the heavy rainfall on 12 June.

On 12 June 2009, the town of Tune was affected by an exceptionally heavy rainfall, causing a backflow of water from the common drainage system for rainwater and sewage into the streets. The suspicion of a waterborne gastroenteritis outbreak was raised and an investigation began. Water samples were taken at the waterworks and at multiple points of the water pipe network following the suspected contamination event. The investigation revealed that a faulty installation adjacent to one of the boreholes may have allowed a backflow of sewage water into the gravel surrounding the borehole, when the sewage system was congested due to the heavy rainfall on 12 June. This geographically constrained outbreak presented an ideal opportunity to study the serological response in persons involved in a Campylobacter outbreak.

The investigation identified that the contamination source was likely due to surface water leaking into the drinking-water system.

The contamination event was first discovered when general practitioners (GPs) in the town of Tune noticed an unusual increase in patients with acute gastroenteritis during the week beginning 15 June 2009. Campylobacter spp. Were detected in stool cultures from some patients. Preliminary inquiries showed that affected persons apparently lived dispersed over the whole town and that they had not attended a common event. No increase of gastroenteritis cases was observed in neighbouring towns. On 11-12 June the area had been affected by an exceptionally heavy rainfall, causing a backflow of water from the common drainage system for rainwater and sewage into the streets. The suspicion of a waterborne gastroenteritis outbreak was raised, an outbreak investigation began and a tapwater boiling advice was issued on 20 June. In the following, we present the outbreak analysis, including a serological follow-up study of persons affected by this waterborne Campylobacter outbreak.

The technical assessment revealed that the contamination event may have affected a large number of individuals due to the widespread distribution of the contaminated water throughout the town's water pipe network. However, an exact number of individuals who were exposed to the contaminant could not be determined from the available data.
The number of people who fell ill due to the event was 163 cases.

The attack rate is the ratio of individuals who became ill to those who were exposed. In this context, the attack rate for the community-wide outbreak of Campylobacter gastroenteritis in Tune was 16%. This means that out of every 100 persons who were exposed to the contaminated water during the outbreak period, 16 persons became ill with Campylobacter gastroenteritis.

The investigation consisted of several components: (1) a cohort study using an e-questionnaire of disease determinants, (2) microbiological study of stool samples, (3) serological study of blood samples from cases and asymptomatic members of case households, and (4) environmental analyses of the water distribution system. The questionnaire survey was completed by a total of 1039 individuals, response rate 21%. Water samples were repeatedly taken at the waterworks and at multiple points of the water pipe network following the suspected contamination event. In 2009, the town of Tune had a population of 5052 persons with an average age of 40 years. The technical assessment revealed a faulty installation adjacent to one of the boreholes which may have allowed a backflow of sewage water into the gravel surrounding the borehole, when the sewage system was congested due to the heavy rainfall on 12 June.
A clinical case was defined as a person with diarrhoea (>3 loose stools in 24 h) or abdominal pain with either fever or vomiting, with symptom onset during the period 13-26 June 2009.

The investigation identified several risk factors for the waterborne Campylobacter outbreak in Tune, Denmark. These risk factors include:
1. A faulty installation adjacent to one of the boreholes which may have allowed a backflow of sewage water into the gravel surrounding the borehole, when the sewage system was congested due to the heavy rainfall on 12 June.
2. Exceptionally heavy rainfall on 12 June which caused a backflow of water from the common drainage system for rainwater and sewage into the streets, potentially contaminating the drinking water supply.
3. The presence of coliform bacteria in water samples taken from the waterworks and at multiple points of the water pipe network following the suspected contamination event.
4. The likely mode of contamination being surface water leaking into the drinking-water system.
5. The fact that affected persons lived dispersed over the whole town and that they had not attended a common event or traveled to a common location during the period of symptom onset.
6. The fact that no increase of gastroenteritis cases was observed in neighbouring towns during the same period.
7. The fact that the town had a population of 5052 persons with an average age of 40 years and that the questionnaire survey was completed by a total of 1039 individuals, response rate 21%, with an average age of 42 years.
8. The fact that the technical assessment revealed a faulty installation adjacent to one of the boreholes which may have allowed a backflow of sewage water into the gravel surrounding the borehole, when the sewage system was congested due to the heavy rainfall on 12 June.

The technical assessment revealed that the contamination event likely spanned from 12 June when the heavy rainfall caused a backflow of sewage water into the gravel surrounding one of the boreholes, to 13 June when the first cases of gastroenteritis were reported. However, it is important to note that this is based on the available evidence and further investigation may be required to confirm these findings.

Immediate actions taken to mitigate the effects of the contamination included issuing a tapwater boiling advice on 20 June and conducting an outbreak investigation to identify the source of contamination and implement appropriate corrective measures.

Water samples were repeatedly taken at the waterworks and at multiple points of the water pipe network following the suspected contamination event. The types of water analyses methods performed during the monitoring phase included bacteriological analyses for total coliforms and Escherichia coli (E. coli), and for specific pathogens such as Campylobacter spp., Salmonella spp., and Shigella spp. The bacteriological analyses were carried out using standard methods such as membrane filtration and enrichment cultures. Additionally, chemical analyses were performed for parameters such as pH, turbidity, and total dissolved solids (TDS). The chemical analyses were carried out using standard methods such as titration and spectrophotometry. The results of the water analyses were used to assess the potential risk to public health and to guide decision-making regarding the implementation of water treatment and distribution measures.

Based on the investigation findings, several measures have been implemented to prevent future contamination events in Tune:
1. Improvement of waterworks and water pipe network: The waterworks and water pipe network have been upgraded and improved to prevent backflow and contamination events.
2. Implementation of a water quality monitoring system: A water quality monitoring system has been implemented to continuously monitor and assess the water quality in Tune.
3. Establishment of emergency response plans and procedures: Emergency response plans and procedures have been established and implemented to ensure prompt and effective response to any contamination events in Tune.

responses: The contamination event occurred between October 31 and November 12 2010.
The contamination event took place at the source of the tap water supply, specifically at waterworks A.

The contamination event involved drinking tap water contaminated with sewage at the source. The outbreak was caused by Norovirus and affected 427/71534 (AR=5.97%) cases between October 31 and November 12 2010. The outbreak was highly localized, with 80% of cases occurring in the areas supplied by waterworks\u2010A. The outbreak was effectively controlled by taking measures to improve water quality and prevent further contamination. No new cases appeared after November 11 and no severe hospitalization or deaths from gastroenteritis were recorded.
The text does not specify what triggered the contamination event.
The contamination source was identified as sewage at the source of the tap water.

The contamination event was first discovered when doctors in the hospital reported an abnormal increase in the number of alimentary tract cases from October 31. This was reported to the local Center for Disease Control (CDC) on November 5, who began investigating immediately.

The number of individuals exposed to the contaminant is not explicitly stated in the provided context. However, it can be inferred that the number of individuals exposed was likely high due to the large number of cases reported (AR=5.97%). Additionally, the fact that the outbreak was highly localized, with 80% of cases occurring in the areas supplied by waterworks\u2010A, further suggests that a large number of individuals were likely exposed to the contaminant.
The number of people who fell ill due to the event was 427.

The attack rate (AR) is defined as the ratio of individuals who became ill to those who were exposed. In this context, the AR was calculated to be 5.97%. This means that 5.97% of individuals who were exposed to the contaminated tap water became ill with gastroenteritis.
