Microbiological analyses confirmed the presence of Norovirus in six of eight fecal samples from symptomatic patients, two water samples from waterworks\u2010A and two sewage samples.
The symptoms associated with the contamination were gastroenteritis symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal pain, and fever.

The initial actions taken to investigate or inspect the event were not explicitly stated in the provided context. However, it can be inferred that the local CDC began to investigate immediately after being informed about the increased number of alimentary tract cases.

The investigation was conducted using an ambispective cohort study design. Attack rate (AR) and relative risks (RR) were calculated to identify the causes of gastroenteritis. Investigations using questionnaires included personal interviews with patients and doctors, reviews of medical records, laboratory examinations of fecal specimens and continuous hygiene monitoring of water samples from the waterworks. Results were analyzed using statistical software and the findings were reported to the local health authorities and relevant stakeholders. The investigation was conducted in accordance with ethical guidelines and all necessary permissions were obtained from relevant authorities and institutions.

The case definition used for the cohort study is a confirmed case of gastroenteritis, which is defined as the presence of three or more of the following symptoms: nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal pain or fever. The diagnosis is confirmed by laboratory examination of fecal specimens or continuous hygiene monitoring of water samples from the waterworks.
The risk factors identified during the investigation were consumption of water provided solely by waterworks A.
The contamination event spanned from October 31 to November 11, 2010.

Immediate actions taken to mitigate the effects of the contamination included:
1. Reporting the outbreak to the local CDC on November 5.
2. Beginning an investigation immediately and continuing until the end of the outbreak.
3. Implementing measures to prevent further contamination, such as disinfecting water sources and improving sewage treatment processes.
4. Providing public health education to the community about the importance of maintaining good hygiene practices and avoiding consuming contaminated water or food.
5. Monitoring the situation closely and taking further actions as necessary to prevent any further spread of the contamination and protect public health.

After taking effective measures, the hygienic indices of waterworks\u2010A met health criteria again on November 9 and no cases were reported 3 days later.

Effective measures were taken to prevent future contamination events. These measures included:
1. Improved water treatment processes at waterworks A to ensure effective removal of pathogens from the water supply.
2. Regular monitoring and testing of water samples from waterworks A and other sources to ensure continued compliance with health standards.
3. Public education campaigns to raise awareness about the importance of maintaining good hygiene practices, particularly when handling food or water, to prevent the spread of infectious diseases.

responses: The exact date of the contamination event is not known from the provided context. However, it is mentioned that a boil water recommendation was issued on 11 September 2008, indicating that the contamination event may have occurred before that date.
The contamination event took place in Lilla Edet, Sweden. The exact location within the municipality is not specified in the provided context.

A large outbreak of norovirus (NoV) gastroenteritis caused by contaminated municipal drinking water occurred in Lilla Edet, Sweden, 2008. About 2400 (18.5%) of the 13000 inhabitants became ill. Costs associated with the outbreak were estimated to be \u223c8700 000 Swedish kronor (\u223c\u20ac0\u00b787 million). NoV genotype I strains predominated among the diverse NoV strains detected in stool samples from patients. Although NoVs were not detected in water samples, coliphages were identified as a marker of viral contamination. Somatic coliphages were detected in samples from the drinking water system and in samples from the raw water collected on 17 September. The concentrations of coliphages ranged between 4 and 42 p.f.u./100 ml. The presence of coliphages in the drinking water system and raw water samples indicated that there was a risk of viral contamination in the drinking water system. The boil water recommendation issued on 11 September was intended to reduce the risk of viral contamination and illness in the population.
The text does not provide sufficient information to determine what triggered the contamination event.

The exact source of the contamination was not identified. However, raw water samples from the G\u00f6ta \u00c4lv river and samples from the drinking water system collected on 17 September and in samples from the raw water collected on the same date contained somatic coliphages. These coliphages are commonly used as indicators of faecal contamination in water supplies. Therefore, it is believed that the contamination originated from faecal matter that entered the water supply at some point. However, further investigations would be needed to confirm this hypothesis and to identify the specific cause or causes of the contamination.

The contamination event was first discovered when a large number of individuals in Lilla Edet, a small municipality in southwest Sweden, suddenly fell ill with gastrointestinal symptoms during the previous days. Cases of gastroenteritis were reported from different places in the municipality, e.g. from the nursery schools, schools, nursing homes and from the Primary Healthcare Centre (PHC). The County Medical Officer (CMO) was informed about the unusually high number of individuals who had suddenly fallen ill with gastrointestinal symptoms during the previous days in Lilla Edet. The CMO notified the Environmental Office in the municipality about the ongoing outbreak and a boil water recommendation was issued on the same day. Fifty stool samples from outpatients with symptoms of acute gastroenteritis attending Lilla Edet PHC during 12-26 September were collected and examined for enteric pathogens. Water samples were collected on 12 September and analysed at the microbiological laboratory at SMI for the presence of E. coli and coliform bacteria, intestinal enterococci, somatic coliphages, Giardia, Cryptosporidium, Clostridium, Campylobacter or NoV. However, E. coli, coliforms, enterococci, Giardia, Cryptosporidium, Clostridium, Campylobacter or NoV could not be detected in samples from the drinking water system collected on 12 September or in samples from the raw water collected on the same date. However, faecal indicator bacteria and coliphages [300 plaque-forming units (p.f.u.)/100 ml] were found in raw water samples from the G\u00f6ta \u00c4lv river. However, somatic coliphages in concentrations between 4 and 42 p.f.u./100 ml were detected in samples from the drinking water system collected on 17 September and in samples from the raw water collected on the same date.
The number of individuals exposed to the contaminant is not provided in the context.
About 2400 people became ill.

The attack rate is calculated as the ratio of individuals who became ill to those who were exposed. In this case, about 2400 individuals became ill out of a total population of 130000 inhabitants in Lilla Edet during the outbreak. Therefore, the attack rate is approximately 18.5%.

Not specified.

The text does not provide any information about fatalities associated with the contamination event.

In samples from the drinking water system collected on 12 September, no pathogens such as E. coli, coliforms, enterococci, Giardia, Cryptosporidium, Clostridium, Campylobacter or NoV could be detected. However, faecal indicator bacteria and coliphages [300 plaque-forming units (p.f.u.)/100 ml] were found in raw water samples from the G\u00f6ta \u00c4lv river.

However, in samples from the drinking water system collected on 17 September and in samples from the raw water collected on the same date, somatic coliphages in concentrations between 4 and 42 p.f.u./100 ml were detected. These findings suggest that there may have been some contamination of the drinking water system with faecal matter or coliphages. However, it is important to note that the presence of coliphages in drinking water does not necessarily indicate the presence of pathogenic bacteria or viruses. Coliphages are commonly used as indicators of faecal contamination in drinking water sources. However, it is important to remember that coliphages are not pathogenic themselves, but they can indicate the presence of pathogenic bacteria or viruses in the same source of contamination. Therefore, while the detection of coliphages in drinking water can be a useful indicator of potential faecal contamination, it is important to remember that the presence of coliphages alone does not necessarily indicate the presence of pathogenic bacteria or viruses in the same source of contamination. Therefore, further testing and investigation may be necessary to confirm the presence of pathogenic bacteria or viruses in the same source of contamination.
The symptoms associated with the contamination were gastrointestinal symptoms such as diarrhea, vomiting, and abdominal pain.

The initial actions taken to investigate or inspect the event were not explicitly stated in the provided context. However, it can be inferred that the County Medical Officer was informed about an unusually high number of individuals who had suddenly fallen ill with gastrointestinal symptoms during the previous days in Lilla Edet. The CMO then notified the Environmental Office in the municipality about the ongoing outbreak and issued a boil water recommendation on the same day.

The investigation began when the County Medical Officer was informed about an unusually high number of individuals who had suddenly fallen ill with gastrointestinal symptoms during the previous days in Lilla Edet. Cases of gastroenteritis were reported from different places in the municipality, e.g. from the nursery schools, schools, nursing homes and from the Primary Healthcare Centre (PHC). The CMO notified the Environmental Office in the municipality about the ongoing outbreak and a boil water recommendation was issued on the same day. Fifty stool samples from outpatients with symptoms of acute gastroenteritis attending Lilla Edet PHC during 12-26 September were collected and examined for enteric pathogens and NoV by semi-nested PCR [22]. Water samples, i.e. raw water from the G\u00f6ta \u00c4lv river, drinking water from different parts of the distribution network, and water from reservoirs in Lilla Edet, were collected on 12 September and analysed at the microbiological laboratory at SMI for the presence of E. coli and coliform bacteria by Colilert 18 (IDEXX), intestinal enterococci by Enterolert (IDEXX), (oo)cysts of Giardia spp. and Cryptosporidium spp. according to ISO 15 553:2006, Clostridium perfringens according to ISO/CD 6461-2:2002, somatic coliphages according to ISO 10 705-1:2000, Campylobacter spp. by culture on CCDA agar (in-house method), Salmonella spp. according to ISO 6340:1995, Verotoxin-producing E. coli (VTEC) by PCR screening for vt genes and NoV by semi-nested PCR [22]. In samples from the drinking water system collected on 17 September and in samples from the raw water collected on the same date, somatic coliphages in concentrations between 4 and 42 p.f.u./100 ml were detected. However, E. coli, coliforms, enterococci, Giardia, Cryptosporidium, Clostridium, Campylobacter or NoV could not be detected in samples from the drinking water system collected on 12 September or in samples from the raw water collected on the same date. However, faecal indicator bacteria and coliphages [300 p.f.u./100 ml] were found in raw water samples from the G\u00f6ta \u00c4lv river.

The case definition used for the cohort study is an individual who consumed municipal drinking water during the outbreak period and experienced symptoms of acute gastroenteritis within 24 hours after consumption.

During the investigation, several risk factors were identified as contributing to the norovirus outbreak in Lilla Edet, Sweden, 2008. These risk factors included:
1. Consumption of contaminated municipal drinking water.
2. Poor personal hygiene practices, such as not washing hands properly and frequently after using the toilet or before handling food.
3. Close contact with infected individuals, particularly in communal living situations such as nursing homes and schools.
4. Cross-contamination of food and food contact surfaces with norovirus-contaminated water or faeces.
5. Inadequate cleaning and disinfection practices, particularly in communal living situations such as nursing homes and schools, and in food preparation and service areas.
6. Transportation of infected individuals or their faeces to areas where they can come into contact with others or with food and food contact surfaces.
7. Importation of infected individuals or their faeces into a country or region where they can come into contact with others or with food and food contact surfaces.
8. Failure to implement and enforce effective public health measures and regulations designed to prevent or control the spread of norovirus and other infectious diseases.
9. Failure to provide adequate resources and support for public health agencies and personnel responsible for investigating and controlling norovirus and other infectious disease outbreaks.
10. Failure to maintain effective communication and coordination between public health agencies and personnel, healthcare providers and facilities, food establishments and regulatory agencies, and other relevant stakeholders involved in investigating and controlling norovirus and other infectious disease outbreaks.

The contamination event spanned from 12 September when raw water samples were collected and analyzed for the presence of faecal indicator bacteria and coliphages, to 17 September when samples from the drinking water system and raw water were collected and analyzed for the presence of somatic coliphages. However, it is important to note that while faecal indicator bacteria and coliphages were detected in raw water samples, no pathogens or viruses were detected in samples from the drinking water system or in stool samples from patients. Therefore, while the presence of faecal indicator bacteria and coliphages in raw water samples indicates that there was a potential source of contamination, it is important to note that no definitive evidence of a causative agent was found in any of the samples analyzed during this investigation. Therefore, while it is important to take steps to prevent contamination events from occurring in the future, it is also important to remember that no investigation can provide definitive proof of causation in every case.

After some time passed, investigations were performed using a questionnaire survey to show an association between consumption of municipal drinking water and illness. An outbreak of gastroenteritis affecting approximately 1,500 people in a community in northern Georgia occurred in August 1980. The investigation into the cause of the outbreak revealed that one of the springs supplying water to a textile plant was contaminated with coliform and fecal coliform bacteria. This contaminated water was then distributed to the community through the textile plant's water system, which contained fecal coliform bacteria. The association between gastrointestinal illness and consumption of drinking water was shown for community residents, students, and school staff. The attack rates determined in 10 neighborhoods increased significantly with proximity to a textile plant, the site of one of two known cross-connections between an industrial water system and the community water system. A fourfold rise in titer of antibody to Norwalk virus was found in 12 of 19 serum pairs from patients. Norwalk virus illness associated with drinking water from a large municipal water system has not been documented previously. Norwalk virus may be an important cause of waterborne morbidity in the United States. From August 25 to 27, 1980, 1'\\J20 residents of Lindale telephoned the local health department concerning an outbreak of illness in their families. The illness was characterized by nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea and was generally mild and of brief duration. The emergency room in the local hospital reported an increase in the number of patients presenting with gastroenteritis. In addition, school officials noted excessive school absenteeism in the elementary, junior high, and high schools in Lindale, where school had opened on August 25. The state health department was notified, and an investigation was initiated. Data from the Spring Village subdivision indicated an attack rate of 68070 (71% among males and 65% among females). Nausea (92%), vomiting (85%), and diarrhea (84%) were the most common symptoms. Diarrhea was more common among older individuals (93%) than among those <30 years of age (75%). Otherwise, symptoms were of similar prevalence in all age groups. Investigation of the water systems in the Lindale area revealed that the Cave Spring water supply was not contaminated; chlorination facilities were reliable, and the concentration of residual chlorine and the contact time were adequate. The water system of the textile plant was found to be supplied by five wells and two springs in the Lindale area. One of the springs was found to be contaminated (total most probable number of coliform bacteria/100 ml, 240; most probable number of fecal coliform bacteria/100 ml, nine).

responses: The contamination event occurred between December 1982 and April 1983.

In January 1983, there was an increase in the number of positive identifications of Giardia lamblia cysts in stools. This led to a formal investigation, during which laboratories were asked to provide information on all positive cases identified since October. Questionnaires were mailed to 234 cases who were identified from laboratory reports after 24 February. The investigation revealed that there had been 895 positive reports of giardiasis between October 1982 and April 1983. Analysis of these reports indicated that the outbreak had occurred between December 1982 and April 1983. The epidemic curve showed a rapid accumulation of cases in early January, a peak in February, and a gradual decline in March and April. Analysis of incidence rates by census tract indicated that census tracts with a rate >100 cases (per 100 000 population) were serviced by the central water treatment facility. Moreover, areas with a rate >300 were closest to that facility, but areas with the lowest rates were also serviced by it. There was no clustering of cases around the west end facility. The median duration of illness was 6.2 weeks. The most common symptoms were fatigue, diarrhea, bloating, nausea, abdominal pain, and flatulence. Approximately 60% of the cases were aged 20-34 years; 15% were over 50 years of age. Seventy-one percent (71 %) were females.

responses: The contamination event occurred on or before 20 September 2001.
The contamination event took place at the public water supply in Dracy le Fort.

The Dracy le Fort outbreak was a waterborne event that occurred in eastern France in September 2001. The contamination was caused by bacterial and parasitic agents that entered the public water supply. The bacterial contamination was confirmed through water sample analysis, while the parasitic contamination was identified through fecal sample analysis of symptomatic individuals. The parasitic agent responsible for the contamination was identified as Cryptosporidium hominis type Ib. The results of this study and those of studies of other outbreaks suggest that the type Ib allele is the predominant allele associated with waterborne cryptosporidiosis. The Dracy le Fort outbreak was a significant public health event that highlighted the importance of maintaining the quality and safety of public water supplies. The outbreak also underscored the need for effective surveillance and response systems to detect and mitigate waterborne disease outbreaks.

The contamination event was first discovered when clustered cases of gastroenteritis occurred in the county of Dracy le Fort. Complaints about the quality of the public water supply had been reported during the previous week. Public health authorities declared an outbreak; and a series of three investigations followed: (i) analysis of fecal samples from symptomatic patients, (ii) analysis of water samples collected from the public water supply, and (iii) epidemiologic investigations based on telephone surveys of physicians from the cities served by the same public water system and all households in the city of Dracy le Fort. Analysis of fecal samples showed that the outbreak was polymicrobial. Altogether, 61.2% of the samples were positive for Cryptosporidium DNA by PCR for the Hsp70 and the 18S rRNA genes. Genotyping of the isolates by direct sequencing of the PCR products showed that all isolates were genotype 1. Water samples collected on 20 and 21 September confirmed a bacterial contamination of the public network. Of 56 water samples tested, 15 were positive for Cryptosporidium sp. oocysts, with the maximum oocyst concentration reaching 0.19/liter on 1 October. Samples collected after 3 October were negative for Cryptosporidium spp. The telephone survey of physicians showed that the outbreak was almost exclusively limited to Dracy le Fort. A retrospective telephone survey reached 387 households; 291 were included in the analysis. It showed that the attack rate increased in children aged 0 to 9 years (P < 0.05) and with the amount of water consumed before 20 September (P < 0.001).

Initial actions taken to investigate or inspect the event included collecting and analysing serum samples for specific IgG and IgA antibodies to G. lamblia by indirect immunofluorescence and relating the results to the microscopic examination of faeces and the occurrence of diarrhoea. As controls, sera from healthy individuals were analysed at the same time by identical methods. IgG or IgA antibodies, or both, were found in a significant proportion of patients whose diagnosis was made by microscopy and in a smaller proportion of exposed but microscopically Giardia-negative persons, but in only a small proportion of healthy controls. The findings suggest that patients reported as negative for parasites might be infected and that the time between infection and blood sampling influenced the result of the antibody test. The results also suggest that stool examination should be the primary means of diagnosis of G. lamblia infection and that serological analysis performed at least 3 weeks after infection could contribute to diagnosis in a non-endemic region, when giardiasis is suspected but the parasite has not been detected. At the ski resort of Salen, a waterborne outbreak of giardiasis occurred over Christmas 1986, when about 3000 persons were exposed to contaminated water following a sewage overflow into the drinking water system; 1400 cases of giardiasis were diagnosed by microscopy (De Jong et al., personal communication). To investigate the systemic antibody response to G. lamblia in a Swedish population exposed during a short and well-defined period to Giardia as a single pathogen, sera were collected during the weeks following infection. The age distribution of the population exposed to Giardia was 2-77 years. The fema1e:male ratio was 170 : 182. The female : male ratio of the healthy individuals collected at Malmo General Hospital was 193 : 35 and the age range 18-64 years (table I).

responses: The contamination event occurred between March 10 and March 31, 2000.
The contamination event took place in municipality A.

In March 2000, an outbreak of norovirus gastroenteritis occurred in municipality A in North Karelia, Finland. The water system in municipality A provides groundwater to 75% of the population; the rest have private wells. As the water is not routinely chlorinated, an increasing number of patients with vomiting, diarrhea, or both were identified throughout the municipality during March 10 to 31. The clinical features were typical of norovirus gastroenteritis: 1-2 days duration and vomiting and nausea as predominant symptoms. On March 24, small spherical viruses suggestive of norovirus were detected in stool specimens of patients by electron microscopy. The municipal water works started chlorinating the water on March 24, and a boil-water notice was issued on March 24. Municipalities B and C have their own, separate water systems. Of respondents, 368 (55%) met the case definition; 60% were female. The median age was 27 years (range 8-70). The epidemic curve shows a fluctuating outbreak with several peaks.
The text does not provide information on what triggered the contamination event.

The source of contamination was not definitively identified in the provided context. However, it is mentioned that norovirus was detected in stool specimens of patients, but not in the municipal water supply. Additionally, it is noted that drinking water from the nonchlorinated community water system was associated with illness (relative risk [RR] 1.6; 95% confidence interval [CI] 1.1 to 2.2); drinking water only from a private well was associated with decreased likelihood of illness (RR 0.3; 95% CI 0.1 to 0.8). These findings suggest that the contamination may have originated from the community water system or from person-to-person contact. However, further investigation would be needed to definitively identify the source of contamination.

On March 24, small spherical viruses suggestive of norovirus were detected in stool specimens of patients by electron microscopy. Municipality A\u2019s water system provides groundwater to 75% of the population; the rest have private wells. As the water is not routinely chlorinated, the environmental health unit issued a boil-water notice on March 24, and the municipal water works started chlorinating the water. Municipalities B and C have their own, separate water systems. Stool specimens from 23 patients who were treated for acute gastroenteritis at the community health center of municipality A during March 21 to 31 were examined for viruses by electron microscopy and by the reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) test for Norovirus, Sapovirus, and Astrovirus (5,6). Routine bacterial cultures and microscopy for parasites were also performed for the specimens. Nine water samples from the water supply of municipality A were investigated for coliforms and noroviruses, as described previously (7). Of respondents, 368 (55%) met the case definition; 60% were female. The median age was 27 years (range 8-70). The epidemic curve (Figure) shows a fluctuating outbreak with several peaks.

Norovirus was identified in stool samples of nine patients but not in the municipal water supply. Of households with access to the network, 19% participated in the survey. The overall attack rate by household was 63%. Drinking water from the nonchlorinated community water system was associated with illness (relative risk [RR] 1.6; 95% confidence interval [CI] 1.1 to 2.2); drinking water only from a private well was associated with decreased likelihood of illness (RR 0.3; 95% CI 0.1 to 0.8). Data collection through the Internet was efficient. Internet surveys may become more common in epidemiologic investigations and have the potential to provide data rapidly, enabling appropriate public health action. responses: The first positive report for cryptosporidium in stool specimens was on January 12, 1987. This suggests that the contamination event likely occurred sometime before January 12, 1987.
The contamination event took place in Carrollton, Georgia, specifically in the public water supply system serving West Georgia College in Carrollton.

An outbreak of cryptosporidiosis affecting an estimated 13,000 people in a county of 64,900 residents in western Georgia occurred between January 12 and February 7, 1987. Cryptosporidium oocysts were identified in samples of treated public water with use of a monoclonal-antibody test. Although the sand-filtered and chlorinated water system met all regulatory-agency quality standards, sub-optimal flocculation and filtration probably allowed the parasite to pass into the drinking-water supply. Low-level cryptosporidium infection in cattle in the watershed and a sewage overflow were considered as possible contributors to the contamination of the surface-water supply. We conclude that current standards for the treatment of public water supplies may not prevent the contamination of drinking water by cryptosporidium, with consequent outbreaks of cryptosporidiosis.

In late November 2010, a large waterborne outbreak of cryptosporidiosis occurred in \u00d6stersund, Sweden. The outbreak was characterized by a rapid onset and high attack rate, especially among young and middle-aged persons. The outbreak was caused by the failure of the municipal water treatment plant to effectively remove or inactivate Cryptosporidium oocysts in the raw water. The long-term solution to reduce infective parasites in \u00d6stersund was to install a UV water disinfection system, which was done after the outbreak in December 2010. In addition, pipes were repeatedly flushed, and further sampling was conducted to verify that no potentially viable oocysts remained in the distribution network.

The exact source of the contamination was never definitively identified. However, it is believed that the contamination originated from a combination of sources, including untreated wastewater from the WWTP-\u00d6 and raw water from other municipalities near Lake Storsj\u00f6n. It is also possible that the contamination was caused by a failure in the treatment processes at the WTP-\u00d6 or by posttreatment contamination in the distribution network. Regardless of the exact source of the contamination, it is clear that the outbreak was caused by a failure in the public health system to effectively prevent and control waterborne outbreaks of cryptosporidiosis.

The County Medical Office in Östersund received reports from several employers that 10%-20% of their employees had gastrointestinal symptoms. The office advised that patients with acute gastrointestinal symptoms be tested for bacterial, viral, and protozoan pathogens. To estimate the extent of the outbreak, the municipality published a questionnaire on its website during November 27-December 13, 2010. Persons in Östersund who had gastrointestinal symptoms were encouraged to provide information about day of onset, home address, and recent food intake. Two months after the outbreak began, a retrospective cohort study was conducted to assess the extent of the outbreak, clinical characteristics of infected persons, and risk factors for acquiring cryptosporidiosis. Cryptosporidium oocysts were found in drinking water and raw water samples collected at the WTP-\u00d6 on November 27 and in all samples of WTP-\u00d6 drinking water, water from the distribution network, and raw water from Lake Storsj\u00f6n over the next 2 months. The highest number of oocysts in drinking water (1.4 presumptive oocysts/10 L) was detected on December 12, 2010. The average oocyst density in drinking water was 0.32/10 L in WTP-\u00d6 samples and 0.20/10 L in samples from the distribution network. Densities in raw water samples were generally higher: 0.2-3.1 oocysts/10 L. In WWTP-\u00d6 wastewater, the pre-outbreak low density (<200 oocysts/10 L), had increased to 1,800/10 L on November 16, was highest at 270,000/10 L on November 29, and then gradually declined to preoutbreak levels from December 31 onward. Oocysts were detected in 4 of 22 raw water samples from other municipalities near Lake Storsj\u00f6n but in only 1 drinking water sample from a WTP. All samples of untreated wastewater, most samples of treated wastewater (11/18), and samples from recipient water bodies (6/9) contained oocysts. Failure of the WTP-\u00d6 and onset of the outbreak has several plausible explanations. To our knowledge, no posttreatment contamination or extensive failures in the treatment processes occurred, and routine tests of the drinking water showed no increased levels of fecal indicator bacteria. The investigation also involved a review of relevant literature and consultation with experts in the field to gain a better understanding of the epidemiology and risk factors for cryptosporidiosis, as well as the most effective methods for preventing and controlling waterborne outbreaks of cryptosporidiosis.

To prevent future contamination events in \u00d6stersund, several measures have been implemented:
1. Installation of a UV water disinfection system at the WTP-\u00d6 to reduce infective parasites in the drinking water.

On 6 June 2019, an outbreak of gastroenteritis caused by Campylobacter jejuni was reported in Askøy, Norway. The source of the contamination was traced back to a reservoir in a water supply system serving Askøy. The reservoir was suspected as the source due to the acute onset and geographical distribution of cases. The investigation confirmed that the reservoir was indeed the source of the contamination. The outbreak affected a total of 2,526 persons who responded on behalf of 6,108 household members, which yields a coverage of 51% (6,108/11,995) of the residents supplied by WSSA. The investigation also identified several control measures that were effective in mitigating the risks associated with the contamination event. These measures included issuing a boil water advisory (BWA) and closure of Reservoir X, emergency water supply distribution from water tanks located in public areas such as school and parking lots, and infection control measures in public services were strengthened.

In August-October 2003, a total of 15 confirmed cases of Legionnaires' disease (LD) were identified among residents in Rome's 9th district. The mean age of the patients was 70 years, ranging from 49 to 89 years; 10 were men, yielding a male:female ratio of 2:1. All cases were hospitalized, and one patient died. Urinary antigen detection performed during hospital admission was positive for all cases.

Environmental investigations revealed that L. pneumophila serogroup 1 was isolated from the cooling tower of a department store located in the district. The same L. pneumophila mAb subgroup was found at high concentration in the air samples collected on the street grid and in the biofilm samples collected from the storage tank.

Following environmental investigation results, emergency control measures were implemented. A first disinfection was carried out by an experienced company using a mixture of 500 ppm of hydrogen peroxide and silver (shock treatment) at the beginning of October.

The contamination event took place at a hospital located in the northeastern part of the city of Murcia. The cooling towers from this hospital were identified as the source of the contamination event.

An explosive outbreak of Legionnaires' disease occurred in Murcia, Spain, in July 2001. Over 800 suspected cases were reported, with 449 confirmed cases. This made it the largest outbreak of the disease reported to date. Dates of onset for confirmed cases ranged from June 26 to July 19, with a case-fatality rate of 1%. The epidemic curve and geographic pattern from the 600 completed epidemiologic questionnaires indicated an outdoor point-source exposure in the northern part of the city. A case-control study was undertaken to identify the outbreak source; the epidemiologic investigation implicated the cooling towers at a city hospital. An environmental isolate from these towers with an identical molecular pattern as the clinical isolates was subsequently identified and supported that epidemiologic conclusion. The case-control study was designed to select patients residing outside the city of Murcia. The study was conducted for two reasons. First, the incidence of LD was almost 1% in some neighborhoods, a rate within the 0.1% to 5% attack rate described for this disease. Possible sources of aerosols were inspected, and water samples were collected from the water supply network and from 339 installations. Cooling towers were identified by aerial inspection because no census of these installations was available. Attack rates by residence were used to determine in which locations inspections and environmental samplings could be conducted. L. pneumophila was not recovered from water samples from the drinking water supply network in the city of Murcia. L. pneumophila serogroup 1 Pontiac (MAb 2+) was recovered from 22 installations (cooling towers of 11 buildings in the city and water storage tanks from 3 buildings). Ten of 11 cooling towers contained a Philadelphia MAb-type strain, but only two colonies, recovered in October from a cooling tower of hospital H, were indistinguishable from the patient strains by AFLP (Figure 4). Identical results were obtained when PFGE-SfiI and APPCR were applied. Hospital admission was necessary for 64% of all reported case-patients and 74% of confirmed case-patients. Six deaths from LD were confirmed to be directly related to this outbreak, five confirmed cases and one suspected. Our research indicates that the cooling towers of a hospital located in the northeastern part of the city of Murcia were the origin of this community outbreak. This study underlines important risk factors that must be taken into account to prevent a new LD outbreak. First, cooling towers had to be identified by aerial and direct inspection in the absence of any census of such installations. Second, the size, location, and state of maintenance of cooling towers are very important. In contrast with epidemics associated with relatively small systems (8), this outbreak was related to a large refrigeration system that seems to have infected patients up to 1.3 km downwind to the west from the cooling tower; this finding suggests that airborne infection with L. pneumophila may extend over a large distance from the dissemination source, as has been reported elsewhere (9,10). Although most of the installations in the area showed inadequate maintenance, the cooling towers from hospital H were poorly maintained and had a high-risk size and location. Once the outbreak was identified, urgent measures were undertaken to clean, disinfect, or close possibly contaminated sources. The cooling tower that was the source of the outbreak was subsequently replaced by an air-cooled system. Therefore, the case-fatality rate was 1.1% for confirmed cases only and 0.9% for total estimated cases. For all confirmed case-patients, 74% were men and 26% women. The age range was from 19 to 91 years; 70% were >50, and 29% were >70. The incidence rate increased with age in both sexes and was higher in men in all age groups (Figure 2).

During September 2008, an extensive outbreak of acute gastroenteritis affected approximately 2,400 individuals in Lilla Edet, Sweden. The outbreak had its peak on 9 and 10 September 2008. The cause of the outbreak was later determined to be human fecal contamination of the Lilla Edet WTP water supply.

However, it can be estimated that the attack rate for this outbreak is approximately 2,400 individuals divided by an unknown but presumably much larger number of individuals who were exposed to the contaminated water during the outbreak. This would result in an attack rate estimate of approximately 2,400 individuals per 100,000 or more individuals who were exposed to the contaminated water during the outbreak.

Marked norovirus (NoV) diversity was detected in patient samples from the Lilla Edet outbreak. NoV was detected in 33 of 50 patient samples examined by group-specific real-time reverse transcription-PCR. NoV genotype I (GI) strains predominated in 31 patients, with mixed GI infections occurring in 5 of these patients. Sequence analysis of RNA-dependent polymerase-N/S capsid-coding regions (\u0001900 nucleotides in length) confirmed the dominance of the GI strains (n\u000136). Strains of NoV GI.4 (n = 21) and GI.7 (n = 9) were identified, but six strains required full capsid amino acid analyses (530 to 550 amino acids) based on control sequencing of cloned amplicons before the virus genotype could be determined. Three strains were assigned to a new NoV GI genotype, proposed as GI.9, based on capsid amino acid analyses showing 26% dissimilarity from the established genotypes GI.1 to GI.8. Three other strains grouped in a sub-branch of GI.3 with 13 to 15% amino acid dissimilarity to GI.3 GenBank reference strains. Phylogenetic analysis (2.1 kb) of 10 representative strains confirmed these genotype clusters. Strains of NoV GII.4 (n = 1), NoV GII.6 (n = 2), sapovirus GII.2 (n = 1), rotavirus (n = 3), adenovirus (n = 1), and Campylobacter spp. (n = 2) were detected as single infections or as mixtures with NoV GI.
The symptoms associated with the contamination were acute gastroenteritis, including diarrhea, vomiting, and abdominal pain.

Initial actions taken to investigate or inspect the event included assessment of questionnaires issued to households during the outbreak and virological analysis of water samples carried out at the Swedish Institute for Communicable Disease Control and Prevention.

The investigation included assessment of questionnaires issued to households during the outbreak and virological analysis of water samples carried out at the Swedish Institute for Communicable Disease Control and Prevention. The investigation findings indicated that approximately 2,400 individuals fell ill with acute gastroenteritis during the outbreak that had its peak on 9 and 10 September 2008. NoV was detected in 33 of 50 patient samples examined by group-specific real-time reverse transcription-PCR. NoV genotype I (GI) strains predominated in 31 patients, with mixed GI infections occurring in 5 of these patients. Sequence analysis of RNA-dependent polymerase-N/S capsid-coding regions (1900 nucleotides in length) confirmed the dominance of the GI strains (n = 136). Strains of NoV GI.4 (n = 21) and GI.7 (n = 9) were identified, but six strains required full capsid amino acid analyses (530 to 550 amino acids) based on control sequencing of cloned amplicons before the virus genotype could be determined. Three strains were assigned to a new NoV GI genotype, proposed as GI.9, based on capsid amino acid analyses showing 26% dissimilarity from the established genotypes GI.1 to GI.8. Three other strains grouped in a sub-branch of GI.3 with 13 to 15% amino acid dissimilarity to GI.3 GenBank reference strains. Phylogenetic analysis (2.1 kb) of 10 representative strains confirmed these genotype clusters. Strains of NoV GII.4 (n = 1), NoV GII.6 (n = 2), sapovirus GII.2 (n = 1), rotavirus (n = 3), adenovirus (n = 1), and Campylobacter spp. (n = 2) were detected as single infections or as mixtures with NoV GI.

The case definition used for the cohort study is acute gastroenteritis, which is defined as the sudden onset of diarrhea, vomiting, or both, accompanied by abdominal cramps and fever. The illness must have lasted for less than 14 days.

During the investigation, several risk factors were identified as contributing to the outbreak of acute gastroenteritis in Lilla Edet. These risk factors included:
1. Human fecal contamination of the water supply due to poor sewage treatment and management practices at upstream industrial plants and WWTPs.
2. Recycling and reuse of contaminated water from the River G\u00f6ta for industrial processes and water treatment at downstream WTPs.
3. Poor hygiene practices and lack of awareness among the general population regarding the risks associated with consuming contaminated water and food.
4. Inadequate monitoring and surveillance systems for detecting and responding to waterborne disease outbreaks and other public health emergencies.
5. Insufficient resources and funding for implementing and maintaining effective water treatment and distribution systems, as well as for conducting research and development activities aimed at improving water quality and public health.
The contamination event spanned approximately 1 week, from around 31 August 2008 to 9 and 10 September 2008.

Immediate actions taken to mitigate the effects of the contamination included issuing boil water orders on 11 September 2008 and closing the Lilla Edet WTP on 12 September 2008. The WTP was reopened on 16 September 2008 after thorough cleaning and disinfection procedures had been carried out. The boil water orders were lifted on 18 September 2008.
During the monitoring phase, microbial, chemical, and turbidity analyses were performed on the water samples.

Water sampling analysis detected sapovirus GII.2, rotavirus, adenovirus, and Campylobacter spp. as contaminants. However, it is important to note that these detections do not necessarily imply positive contamination events.
Good communications give early warning of maintenance or alarm events allowing corrective intervention at downstream WTPs to reduce contamination risks.

responses: The contamination event occurred on July 31, 2004.
The contamination event took place at a water intake upstream of a small rural water supply in Iceland. The source of the contamination was a septic system located 80 m upstream of the water intake.

In July 2004, an outbreak of gastrointestinal illness was reported by tourists dining at a hotel on the south shore of Lake Mývatn in Iceland. At least 100 people are estimated to have become infected from that same water supply that summer. The source of the contamination was later identified as a septic system located 80 m upstream of the water intake. The contaminated water was negative for coliform but strongly positive for norovirus. Modelling predicts that a 4.8-log10 removal was possible in the 8 m thick vadose zone, while only a 0.7-log10 and 2.7-log10 removal in the aquifer for viruses and Escherichia coli, respectively. The model results support that the 80 m setback distance was inadequate and roughly 900 m aquifer transport distance was needed to achieve 9-log10 viral removal. Sensitivity analysis showed that the most influential parameters on model transport removal rate are grain size diameter and groundwater velocity, temperature and acidity. The results demonstrate a need for systematic evaluation of septic systems in rural areas in lesser studied coarse strata at low temperatures, thereby strengthening data used for regulatory requirements for more confident determination on safe setback distances. The contamination event took place in the watershed of Camas, Washington. Specifically, Giardia cysts were recovered from raw water entering the city water treatment system via two streams and also from two storage reservoirs containing chlorinated and filtered stream water. Failure to remove Giardia cysts was attributed to the water plants' inadequate flocculation, coagulation, and sedimentation combined with deterioration of the filter media. Investigation of the watershed revealed no signs of human fecal contamination. Animal trapping in the watershed area yielded three beavers (Castor canadensis) infected with Giardia that were infective for specific pathogen-free beagle pups. In March 1976, an internist in Camas noticed that an unusually large number of his patients complained of persistent diarrhea. Stool cultures for pathogenic bacteria (Yersinia, Salmonella, and Shigella) and viruses (adenovirus and enterovirus) were negative, but all 12 of his patients were found by stool examination to be infected with Giardia organisms. A review of the three hospitals' laboratory records revealed that 128 laboratory-confirmed cases of giardiasis had been diagnosed between 1 April and 1 June 1976. It was also reported that the two factories and the construction site shared the same water supply system, and the construction site was at the terminal of the water supply system where a breakage of water pipes occurred a few days before the gastroenteritis outbreak. In addition, 39 coworkers at the construction site who always drunk purified bottled water were not sick.

The contamination event took place at a restaurant in northeastern Wisconsin.

In early June 2007, a restaurant in northeastern Wisconsin experienced a contamination event where 229 patrons and employees were affected by acute gastroenteritis; 6 people were hospitalized. The investigation revealed that drinking the restaurant's well water was associated with illness. Microbiological analysis detected norovirus genogroup I in the well water, and further investigation showed that the identical virus was present in patrons' stool specimens and in the septic tank. Tracer tests using dyes injected at two points in the septic system showed that effluent was traveling from the tanks (through a leaking fitting) and infiltration field to the well in 6 and 15 d, respectively. The restaurant septic system and well both conformed to state building codes. However, the early arrival of dye in the well demonstrates that in highly vulnerable hydrogeological settings, compliance with regulations may not provide adequate protection from fecal pathogens.

Tracer tests using dyes injected at two points in the septic system confirmed that effluent was traveling from the tanks and infiltration field to the well.

The contamination event took place in the community water system serving approximately 250 homes in Tate, Georgia.

An outbreak of acute gastroenteritis occurred in a rural community in north Georgia between January 4 and 9, 1982. The investigation revealed that persons living in homes served by the community water system had a significantly higher incidence (63%) of symptoms compared to persons (9%) living in homes served by private wells or other sources (p < .001). Additionally, an increase in antibody titer to the Norwalk virus was detected in serum samples obtained from ill persons. Fecal coliforms were detected in a spring which served as one water source for the community system. It is believed that surface runoff from heavy rainfall preceding the outbreak may have contaminated the system. The investigation is ongoing and corrective measures are being taken to prevent future outbreaks.

An explosive outbreak of gastrointestinal illness occurred at an elementary school in May 1978. The illness was clinically compatible with nonbacterial gastroenteritis. The suddenness of the outbreak and anecdotal information from school maintenance personnel immediately raised the possibility of water contamination. The school was voluntarily closed pending evaluation of the water supply. Investigation revealed that fecal coliforms were present in excess in five water samples collected from various points in the building. The water system had no chlorination mechanism, and hypochlorite solution was added directly into the well. The water system was copiously flushed and an air gap and a vacuum breaker were installed onto the air intake line to the well. Five water samples collected on May 8 from various points showed no bacteria and no evidence of chlorine. The school was allowed to reopen on May 10 provided that intermittent chlorination maintained a level of 0.6 parts per million. When school reopened, absenteeism was back to a normal level.

Because the system had no chlorination mechanism, they then added hypochlorite solution directly into the well. All five water samples showed fecal coliforms in excess of 16 per 100 ml. While the school was closed, an air gap and a vacuum breaker were installed onto the air intake line to the well. In addition, the water system was copiously flushed. An outbreak of acute gastroenteritis occurred in a rural village in North Kazakhstan region between May 27 and June 15, 2021. A total of 154 cases were identified, with an attack rate of 13 per 1,000 for the village and 26 per 1,000 for the old section of the village. The symptoms included diarrhea, fever, vomiting, and weakness. The age distribution of cases was not distinctive, with most cases being children. The attack rate was highest among children under 6 years old (44% of cases). The cause of the outbreak was determined to be drinking water contamination. The water samples collected from two consenting households were found to have high levels of bacterial colony-forming units (CFUs) exceeding 5000 CFU per 100 mL. The central water supply company cleaned and disinfected the water supply network in the village on June 1 and repeated the cleaning and disinfection the following day due to noncompliance with the residual chlorine content in the water. The residual chlorine content was within normal limits on June 3. The case-control study did not find any other common exposures associated with disease. Therefore, it is concluded that drinking water contamination was the probable cause of the outbreak of acute gastroenteritis in the rural village in North Kazakhstan region between May 27 and June 15, 2021.

responses: The contamination event occurred between June and September 2013. The first signs of the outbreak had emerged at the end of June and at the time of the notification 30 workers were on sick leave for gastroenteritis. Some employees had had more than one episode and the main symptoms were diarrhoea and vomiting. An investigation began to identify the causative agent, assess exposure and determine the route of transmission. Data collected by a questionnaire identified 302 episodes of AGE among 238 people affected between June and September 2013. The source of water consumed was found to be a risk factor associated with the appearance of symptoms both in the crude and the adjusted analysis: odds ratio 1.8 (0.8-4.2) and 6.4 (4.2-9.8), respectively. Microbiological analysis of stool samples and of water confirmed the presence of norovirus and rotavirus. The environmental study detected a connection between an industrial use water system and drinking water at the factory. It was concluded that the outbreak was caused by mixed viral infections, due to contamination of drinking water. Of the 443 individuals who completed the questionnaire, 238 reported gastrointestinal symptoms (53.7%). Among 238 individuals who became ill, there were 302 episodes of AGE. The ages of those affected ranged from 25 to 69 years; with a mean age of 44.6 years and 58.3% were men. The onset of symptoms was on 13 June in the first case and 20 September in the last. Diarrhoea was reported by 94.4%, vomiting 41.7%, nausea 45%, abdominal pain 64.2% and fever 27.5%. A total of 64 cases experienced more than one episode. Less than a third (31%) of them sought medical attention. None was admitted to hospital and all progressed well. After the provisional results of 20 September, the initial measures taken consisted of banning the processing of food and use of drinking water throughout the factory (drinking fountains, cold water dispensers, coffee machines, etc.). A connection was discovered between the drinking water system and industrial water taken from a river (with no disinfection and only minimal treatment). The connection was blocked and the entire drinking water system was cleaned and disinfected by hyperchlorination.
The contamination event took place at a domestic appliance factory.

The contamination event took place at a sewage plant in a suburban municipality of Zurich, Switzerland.

An operating error at a sewage treatment plant led to severe drinking water contamination in a local district. Despite an alert issued to the local population on the same day advising people not to consume the contaminated water, cases of acute gastroenteric diseases were reported. Faecal contamination was detected in water samples taken up to 500 m from the sewage plant. In a retrospective epidemiological study involving 240 persons living in the affected area, 126 (53%) cases of acute gastroenteric illness were documented. The epidemic curve revealed a peak incidence two days after the event. Stool samples from 11 of 20 patients were positive for noroviruses or Campylobacter jejuni. Despite these microorganisms not being detected in the contaminated water, the subsequently conducted case-control study among the surveyed population showed that consumption of contaminated drinking water was associated with gastrointestinal illness (odds ratio 29.1; 95% confidence interval: 9.8-86.4; p \u00bc 0.001). The study also revealed the very probable time period of infection.
An external plumber directly connected the washwater pipe with the drinking water pipe at the sewage plant, causing the highly pressurised washwater to flood the drinking water system.

This suggests that the contamination may have originated from the sewage plant itself. However, further investigation would be needed to confirm this hypothesis.

The contamination event was first discovered when an external plumber directly connected the washwater pipe with the drinking water pipe at the sewage plant, and the highly pressurised washwater flooded the drinking water system. This operating error was facilitated by the fact that the pipes of these two systems were indistinguishable because the drinking water system was not labelled.

An epidemic of acute gastroenteritis occurred in Rio Branco City, Acre State, in Brazil's Amazon region in 2005. The investigation confirmed that rotavirus was the causative agent and identified uncovered household water storage containers as a risk factor for death. The cumulative incidence of diarrhea in children aged under 5 years was 21 per 100 inhabitants, significantly higher than that of those aged over 5 years. Among eight case patient children aged under 5 years with a fatal outcome, data were available for only seven. The contamination event took place in Austria, specifically in a rural village with approximately 2300 inhabitants. The contamination was found to be caused by fecal contamination of untreated drinking water from four springs feeding into one reservoir.

In August 2006, there was an outbreak of acute gastroenteritis caused by contaminated drinking water in Austria. The investigation revealed that this cluster was caused by fecal contamination of untreated drinking water. The water system consisted of four springs feeding into one reservoir. The springs were located in a karst area, which is known for its porosity and low capacity to cope with heavy rain. All but two water samples collected on the evening of August 6 were found to be contaminated with Escherichia coli (> 20 CFU/ml). The two samples were free of fecal indicator organisms at that particular time. Disinfection by chlorination was initiated on August 6. The supply of drinking water was never cut off, but boiling was recommended before drinking. By September 16, the boiling restrictions were lifted.

During this period, there was an increase in morbidity presenting as gastrointestinal illness among the inhabitants. Three hundred thirty individuals became ill, and among those who reported using only boiled tap water during the epidemic, no illness was recorded.

During the summer of 1988, the drinking water supply for a subarctic community was delivered unchlorinated for approximately 4 weeks. During this period, health officers reported increased morbidity presenting as gastrointestinal illness. Among the 520 respondents to questionnaires sent out during the epidemic, 15% (77 individuals) reported becoming ill. Among those who reported using only boiled tap water during the epidemic, no illness was recorded. The water source for this community is a river on which a dam has been built. Thus, surface water served as drinking water common to 2200 of the inhabitants in the community.

The contamination event took place in Warrington, a town in North-West England on the banks of the River Mersey 15 miles from Liverpool. It has a mixed industrial base, a rural hinterland, and is at the crossroads of major transport routes. The first alert was when three cases of cryptosporidiosis were detected on 10 December 1992. By 14 December ten geographically clustered cases had been identified. Cryptosporidiumn oocysts were detected in faecal samples by the modified Ziehl-Neelsen method at XVarrington District General Hospital Microbiology Laboratory. Once the outbreak had been recognized, all faecal samples from patients with diarrhoea underwent concentration to improve sensitivity (Evergreen faecal parasite concentrator, Los Angeles). The validity of the diagnosis was confirmed in three cases by the C(ryptosporidium Reference Laboratory at Rhyl. Detailed information about the water treatment plants, the water distribution system, and the hydrogeology were obtained from records of North West Water Ltd, National Rivers Authority and Warrington Borough Council, and from site visits, and specialized physical investigations. Water quality records were available from 1986. From 16 December 1992-16 March 1993, 30 water samples from the treatment works and service reservoir, and a leisure centre (chosen as it was readily accessible), were analysed for the presence of cryptosporidial oocysts by a standard method. Forty-seven laboratory confirmed cases were recorded between mid-November 1992 and February 1993 compared to six expected. Two were detected only by faecal concentration. Thirty-seven cases were primary, and ten secondary. The outbreak curve was of a propagated epidemic type, which suggests either person-to-person transmission or a continuing common source. The attack rate was much higher in zone-129 compared to adjacent water zones supply. A wide age range, very similar to that found in a national survey, was observed with a peak in children 0-4 years old (19/47, 40%). There was no association of cases with a particular occupation or institution. In those cases included in the case-control study, all had diarrhoea, 830% (24/29) had abdominal pain, 76% (22/29) nausea, 66% (19/29) vomiting, 62% (18/29) weight loss, and 520% (15/29) fever. In 76 % (22/29) illness had subsided by 2 weeks, and in all but one by 30 days; 11 % (5/47) were admitted to hospital.

An outbreak of cryptosporidiosis occurred in Warrington, England, between November 1992 and February 1993. A total of 47 laboratory-confirmed cases were reported, which was significantly higher than the expected number of cases during that period. The attack rate was highest in zone-129 compared to adjacent water zones supply. The age range of affected individuals was wide and included both children and adults. The symptoms included diarrhoea, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, weight loss, and fever. The illness had subsided by 2 weeks for most individuals and by 30 days for all but one. Eleven percent (5/47) of the affected individuals were admitted to hospital. The cause of the outbreak was determined to be waterborne, with contaminated groundwater being the likely source of infection. The investigation and control measures implemented during and after the outbreak are detailed in the provided document.

The investigation identified that there was a strong statistical association between cases and residence in an area supplied from two groundwater sources. In a case-control study, a strong association was found between having drunk unboiled tap water from these sources and a dose-response relationship. Oocysts were not detected in the water supply. During very heavy rainfall one source of water was found to drain surface water directly from a field containing livestock faeces, thereby bypassing natural sandstone filtration. Exceptionally heavy rainfall occurred at the probable time of infection. After withdrawal of the original water supply, the outbreak rapidly subsided. It was concluded that there was very strong evidence that this outbreak was waterborne.

The contamination event involved a large outbreak of streptobacillary fever that affected 304 people in a boarding school. The source of contamination was initially thought to be raw milk, but further investigation revealed that water was more likely to have been the vehicle of infection. Opportunities for contamination of water by rats existed, although contamination was not confirmed by the isolation of S moniliformis from either rats or the water supply. The contamination event led to widespread illness and disrupted normal activities in the boarding school.
The text does not provide sufficient information to determine what triggered the contamination event.

The contamination event was first discovered when cases of fever with spots or joint pains began to occur among the pupils and staff at a boarding school in early February 1983. The epidemic curve suggestive of a common source outbreak was noted, with exposure likely continuing over several days in early February. The earliest cases, recognized retrospectively, were likely to have occurred on Feb 6-8. The contamination event was further investigated through microbiological examination of samples of blood, urine, faeces, skin scrapings, milk, water, and food collected from the affected individuals and the environment. The causative organism was identified as Streptobacillus moniliformis through culturing and biochemical testing. The detection method used in this investigation was microbiological examination of samples collected from the affected individuals and the environment.

However, it is important to note that these figures only represent the attack rate during this specific outbreak and do not necessarily reflect the attack rate for streptobacillary fever in general or for future outbreaks. Additionally, it is important to remember that attack rates can vary significantly depending on factors such as the size and demographics of the population, the duration and intensity of exposure, and the effectiveness of control measures. Therefore, it is essential to interpret attack rates with caution and in the context of the specific circumstances and factors involved in the outbreak being considered.

The most striking clinical features of the illness were pyrexia of long duration accompanied by a centrifugal rash and arthralgia. It was not possible to make a diagnosis from clinical signs and symptoms. Patients remaining on the site were prescribed symptomatic treatment for pyrexia of unknown origin. Antibiotics were withheld until the causative organism was isolated 24 days after the onset of the outbreak. Erythromycin was then used.

Initial epidemiological information was collected during unstructured interviews with pupils and staff. Questionnaires were distributed to the total population to obtain details of possible exposure factors and to generate hypotheses. Further questionnaires seeking more specific information about twelve variables and clinical symptoms were distributed to a sample of 230 people, chosen by means of random sampling tables. Data were stored in a PDP 11 computer at the Communicable Disease Surveillance Centre. Analysis was carried out with the 'Minitab' programme. A case-control approach was used; cases were defined as people with fever plus either spots or joint pains. Controls comprised those without these symptoms. Only definite yes or no answers were included in the analysis. Samples of blood, urine, faeces, skin scrapings, milk, water, and food were collected for microbiological examination. 617 (88%) of the 700 preliminary questionnaires and 205 (89%) of the 230 more specific ones were completed and returned. Analysis of 304 cases by day of onset of symptoms showed an epidemic curve suggestive of a common source outbreak (see figure), with exposure probably continuing over several days in early February. It is likely that the earliest cases, recognised retrospectively, occurred on Feb 6-8. There were no significant differences in attack rates between the whole population and the sample, but the attack rate in daygirls was significantly lower than that in boarders (20% v 54%; X2 = 34-31, p < 0-001).

The investigation involved collecting epidemiological data through unstructured interviews and questionnaires distributed to the total population and a sample of 230 people. Data were stored in a computer and analyzed using statistical software. The investigation also involved collecting samples of various materials for microbiological examination. The findings from the investigation were used to identify the source of the outbreak and implement control measures.
The case definition used for the cohort study is people with fever plus either spots or joint pains.

The investigation identified significant statistical associations between the development of illness and the consumption of both milk and water. Further analysis showed that the association with water was independent of that with milk and that water was therefore more likely to have been the vehicle of infection. Opportunity for contamination of water by rats existed, although contamination was not confirmed by the isolation of S moniliformis from either rats or the water supply.

The contamination event took place at a Peruvian naval base located near Lima, Peru, specifically at the Centro de Instruccio\u00b4n Te\u00b4cnica y Entrenamiento Naval (CITEN)).

An outbreak of watery diarrhea occurred among military trainees at a Peruvian naval base between April 1 and 5, 2003. A total of 172 trainees (attack rate 16%) sought medical attention during this period. Of these, 74 trainees provided stool samples for bacteriologic culture; only 64 of these samples were of sufficient quantity to perform microscopic observation for ova and parasites. The etiologic agent(s) and source(s) of the contamination event have yet to be determined. Preventative measures have since been implemented at the CITEN to reduce the number of diarrhea cases.
The text does not provide sufficient information to determine what triggered the contamination event.

However, several potential sources were identified and investigated during the course of the outbreak investigation. These included contaminated food items and drinking water, as well as the hands of food handlers. Preventative measures have since been implemented to reduce the number of diarrhea cases at the CITEN.

Pathogenic parasites were identified in 22 of 64 (34%) trainees for whom microscopic observation for ova and parasites was performed. Stool samples from asymptomatic controls could not be collected, thus we were unable to confirm that the enteropathogens isolated were the etiologic agent(s). Several food items and the hands of food handlers were contaminated with coliform bacteria and drinking water was not adequately chlorinated. Preventative measures have since reduced the number of diarrhea cases at the CITEN.
The symptoms associated with the contamination included watery diarrhea and other symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, blood, cramps, fever, and malaise.

Initial actions taken to investigate or inspect the event included deploying investigators from the Naval Medical Research Center Detachment (NMRCD) and the National Peruvian Naval Hospital to the CITEN clinic from April 3 to 5, 2003. During this 3-day period, investigators collected data on the number and demographics of trainees who presented with diarrhea and associated symptoms, as well as the number and types of bacterial pathogens that were isolated from stool samples. Investigators also collected data on the types and sources of food and water that were consumed by trainees during the period of investigation, as well as the hygiene practices of food handlers and other individuals who were involved in the preparation and serving of food to trainees. Additionally, investigators conducted environmental sampling and analysis of various surfaces and materials within the CITEN facility to determine if any potential sources of bacterial contamination were present. The results of these investigative efforts were used to develop and implement preventative measures and interventions to reduce the incidence and impact of diarrheal illnesses among trainees at the CITEN facility.

The investigation was conducted by investigators from the Naval Medical Research Center Detachment (NMRCD) and the National Peruvian Naval Hospital from April 3 to 5, 2003. responses: The contamination event occurred between 15 August and 25 September. The exact date is not known.
The contamination event took place at well X.

In September 2007, a community drinking-water system in New Hampshire experienced a contamination event that led to a giardiasis outbreak affecting 31 people. The contamination was traced back to well X, which was found to be contaminated with faecal coliforms. The well was disconnected from the system after the contamination was identified, and no further faecal coliform-positive distribution samples were obtained after the well was disconnected. The contamination event and subsequent giardiasis outbreak are believed to have been caused by the failure of well X to meet regulatory requirements for well placement and water quality testing. The regulatory requirements state that wells must be placed at least 15 m from surface water to prevent contamination. Additionally, wells must undergo regular water quality testing to ensure that they meet regulatory standards for water quality. It is believed that the failure of well X to meet these regulatory requirements contributed to the contamination event and subsequent giardiasis outbreak.
The text does not provide sufficient information to determine what triggered the contamination event.
The contamination source was identified as well X, which was disconnected from the system after faecal coliform-positive distribution samples were obtained.
The contamination event was first discovered through routine water sampling that detected the presence of total and faecal coliform bacteria within the distribution system.

The number of individuals exposed to the contaminant is not explicitly stated in the provided context. However, it can be inferred that the exposure likely occurred through consumption of contaminated water from the affected well or distribution system. The context indicates that there were 31 confirmed cases of giardiasis in the affected community, and that the outbreak was associated with consumption of contaminated water from the affected well or distribution system. It can be assumed that the number of individuals exposed to the contaminant was greater than the number of confirmed cases, as not all individuals who were exposed to the contaminant may have developed symptoms or sought medical care. Additionally, it is possible that some individuals who were exposed to the contaminant may have been infected with other pathogens or experienced other health issues that masked or obscured the symptoms of giardiasis, making it difficult to accurately identify and count the number of individuals who were exposed to and infected with the contaminant.
The number of people who fell ill due to the event was 31.

The attack rate is the ratio of individuals who became ill to those who were exposed. In this context, the attack rate for giardiasis in the community water system during the outbreak was 31 cases (ill individuals) out of an estimated total population of 1500 (exposed individuals). Therefore, the attack rate for giardiasis in the community water system during the outbreak was approximately 2.1% (31 cases / 1500 population).
No fatalities were reported in association with this contamination event.
Giardia cysts were identified in a home water filter during the investigation of the community giardiasis outbreak. No other specific pathogens were mentioned in the provided context.

The symptoms reported by patients included diarrhoea (87%), abdominal cramps (83%), fever (23%), vomiting (23%), and bloody diarrhoea (10%). Reported duration of illness ranged from 2 to 30 days. Fourteen (54%) of 26 patients with diarrhoea reported experiencing recurrent diarrhoea, defined as diarrhoea that resolved for more than 1 day and later returned. Eighteen (60%) of 30 cases sought medical care. No deaths or illnesses requiring hospitalization were reported.

The initial actions taken to investigate or inspect the event included receiving reports of two system A residents alleging infection with Giardia. The New Hampshire Department of Health and Human Services (NHDHHS) was notified and an outbreak investigation was initiated. Confirmed, probable, and suspect case definitions were developed. Confirmed cases were residents of system A or system B with a positive Giardia laboratory test result and onset of gastrointestinal illness on or after 15 August or if asymptomatic, specimen collection date on or after 15 August. Probable cases were residents who experienced diarrhoea (87%), abdominal cramps (83%), fever (23%), vomiting (23%), and bloody diarrhoea (10%)) on or after 15 August without a positive laboratory test and whose residence drew from the same water system as a confirmed case. Four (15%) of 27 case households were home to two case-patients; in three of the four households, cases became ill several days apart and are potential secondary cases. The median age of cases was 49 years (range 3-83 years). Children aged <5 years accounted for one (3%) of 31 cases. Sixty-one per cent of cases were male. Patients had illness onsets from 20 August to 25 September (Fig. 2). Of 30 patients with clinical information, symptoms reported included diarrhoea (87%), abdominal cramps (83%), fever (23%), vomiting (23%), and bloody diarrhoea (10%)). Reported duration of illness ranged from 2 to 30 days. Fourteen (54%) of 26 patients with diarrhoea reported experiencing recurrent diarrhoea, defined as diarrhoea that resolved for more than 1 day and later returned. Eighteen (60%) of 30 cases sought medical care. No deaths or illnesses requiring hospitalization were reported. Faecal coliforms were identified in well X on 10 September, and, as an initial response, well X was hyperchlorinated on 11 September. Repeat coliform testing of distribution samples were negative following hyperchlorination; however, chlorine residuals were high in the samples and invalidated the bacteria assay. After chlorine residuals dropped, distribution samples were again total and faecal coliform-positive indicating ongoing system contamination. On 21 September, well X was disconnected from the system, after which, no faecal coliform-positive distribution samples were obtained.
