Consuming tap water was significantly associated with illness (risk ratio 4.7, 95% confidence interval 1.5-14.4).

The contamination event spanned from at least 15 August (when symptoms were first reported) until at least 21 September (when well X was disconnected from the system and no faecal coliform-positive distribution samples were obtained). However, it is important to note that the exact start and end dates of the contamination event are not known with certainty.

Immediate actions taken to mitigate the effects of the contamination included hyperchlorination of well X on 11 September and disconnection of well X from the system on 21 September. Repeat coliform testing of distribution samples were negative following hyperchlorination; however, chlorine residuals were high in the samples and invalidated the bacteria assay. After chlorine residuals dropped, distribution samples were again total and faecal coliform-positive indicating ongoing system contamination.
During the monitoring phase, total and faecal coliform testing of distribution samples were performed. Chlorine residuals were also monitored in the distribution samples.
Faecal coliforms were detected in distribution samples and well X.

After chlorine residuals dropped, distribution samples were again total and faecal coliform-positive indicating ongoing system contamination. On 21 September, well X was disconnected from the system, after which, no faecal coliform-positive distribution samples were obtained.

Since the contamination event, several measures have been implemented to prevent future contamination events. These measures include:
1. Well X was disconnected from the system after it was identified as the source of contamination.
2. The New Hampshire Department of Environmental Services (NHDES)) issued a boil water order for the affected community after total and faecal coliform bacteria were detected in distribution samples.
3. The affected well was hyperchlorinated as an initial response to the detection of coliform bacteria in distribution samples.
4. The New Hampshire Department of Health and Human Services (NHDHHS) ) and an outbreak investigation team were notified and an investigation was initiated to identify the source of contamination and implement measures to prevent future contamination events.
5. Confirmed, probable, and suspect case definitions were developed and used to identify and confirm cases of giardiasis associated with the contamination event.
6. The investigation team collected and analyzed environmental and water samples from the affected well and distribution system to identify the source of contamination and implement measures to prevent future contamination events.
7. The investigation team also conducted interviews with affected individuals and community members to gather information about their symptoms, exposure to contaminated water, and other relevant factors.
8. Based on the findings of the investigation, several measures were implemented to prevent future contamination events. These measures included:
   a. The affected well was disconnected from the system and remains out of service.
   b. The New Hampshire Department of Environmental Services (NHDES) ) issued a boil water order for the affected community and continues to monitor the situation closely.
   c. The affected well was thoroughly cleaned and disinfected before being taken out of service.
   d. The New Hampshire Department of Health and Human Services (NHDHHS) ) and other relevant agencies are continuing to investigate the source of contamination and implement measures to prevent future contamination events.
   e. The New Hampshire Department of Environmental Services (NHDES) ) and other relevant agencies are continuing to monitor the situation closely and take appropriate actions as needed to protect public health and the environment.

responses: The contamination event occurred between 7 and 15 February 1998.
The contamination event took place at a resort hotel in Bermuda.

In February 1998, an outbreak of gastroenteritis affected at least 448 persons including 122 staff at a resort hotel in Bermuda. The investigation identified multiple sources of contamination including drinking water and food. The drinking water supply was found to have elevated faecal coliform levels and Escherichia coli present, suggestive of faecal contamination. Stools from 18 of the 19 persons with gastroenteritis that were tested were positive for genogroup-II Norwalk-like viruses (NLVs). RT\u00b1PCR analysis of a 3 l specimen of water produced a genogroup-II NLV genome with a sequence identical to that of NLVs in the stools of three ill persons. This outbreak shows the value of new molecular diagnostics to link illness with a contaminated source through the use of sequence analysis. The risk of outbreaks such as these could be reduced in tourism dependent regions like Bermuda and the Caribbean by regular evaluation of data from the inspection and monitoring of drinking water supplies and waste water systems, by ensuring the chlorination of supplemental drinking water supplies and by establishing food-safety initiatives. On 10 February 1998, the BDOH was notified of gastrointestinal illness among 14 foreign guests of a large resort hotel with 402 rooms and a capacity of 900 persons. Five days later additional persons with illness were reported with some visiting the local emergency room after attending various functions at the hotel. On 21 February, the hotel was closed because of the numbers of reported cases and the presence of faecal coliforms in the potable water supply. On 23 February, the BDOH invited a team from the Caribbean Epidemiology Centre (CAREC) to assist with an investigation to identify the causative agent and its mode of spread, and to help with control and prevention measures. A suspected case of gastroenteritis was defined as a foreign guest, local patron, or worker at the hotel who developed either nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea (3 or more loose stools in a 24 h period), or abdominal cramps during 5\u00b121 February 1998. To identify cases, we interviewed the hotel staff, and patients identified from the telephone hot-line reports, the local hospital's emergency room log, the hotel physician's log and bylistings of ill persons reported by organizers of functions held at the hotel. Water was collected from the terrace tank and at various sites along the hotel's potable water supply and tested for coliform bacteria and residual chlorine. Three litres of water collected from the terrace tank was sent to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), Atlanta to test for viral organisms. The potable and waste water systems of the hotel were reviewed to identify opportunities for contamination of the potable water system and deficiencies in the management of these systems. The hotel maintained no logs or procedural guidelines for its water supply so we constructed a profile of the existing systems. Based on the dates of onset for 401 suspected cases, the outbreak began on 7 February and peaked on 15 February (Fig. 1). The 17 confirmed cases showed a similar pattern (Fig. 2). During the period 7\u00b121 February, the estimated minimum cumulative attack rate for foreign guests was 16% (142}868) and, for subgroups of foreign guests for whom accurate estimates could be made, attack rates were much greater. For example, the cumulative attack rate for a group of 109 golfers was 40% and for a group of 79 from a pharmaceutical company it was 54%. The hotel had a roster of 462 staff (289 full-time, 74 part-time, 99 temporary) and approximately 375 were employed during February. Sanitary inspection of the water supply identified a number of deficiencies. The access cover for the terrace tank was rusted, improperly secured and sunken below ground level, allowing surface run-off water to enter the tank. The tank had been last cleaned more than 5 years before and debris was found at the bottom of the access to the tank.
The text does not provide enough information to determine what triggered the contamination event.

The exact source of contamination was not identified in the provided context. However, several potential sources were suggested based on the available data. These included:
1. Faecal contamination of the potable water supply due to inadequate chlorination or cross-contamination from the waste water system.
2. Contamination of food items due to inadequate cooking or cross-contamination during food preparation or storage.
3. Contamination of drinking water from sources other than the potable water supply, such as untreated rainwater or water from unprotected wells or springs.
It is important to note that these potential sources are only suggestions based on the available data and do not necessarily represent the actual source of contamination. Further investigation and testing would be required to definitively identify the source of contamination.

Some of these ill persons visited the local emergency room after attending various functions at the hotel. The hotel physician also reported cases among hotel staff. The potable and waste water systems of the hotel were reviewed to identify opportunities for contamination of the potable water system and deficiencies in the management of these systems. During the period 7\u00b121 February, the estimated minimum cumulative attack rate for foreign guests was 16% (142}868) and, for subgroups of foreign guests for whom accurate estimates could be made, attack rates were much greater. For example, the cumulative attack rate for a group of 109 golfers was 40% and for a group of 79 from a pharmaceutical company it was 54%. The hotel had a roster of 462 staff (289 full-time, 74 part-time, 99 temporary) and approximately 375 were employed during February. Sanitary inspection of the water supply identified a number of deficiencies. The access cover for the terrace tank was rusted, improperly secured and sunken below ground level, allowing surface run-off water to enter the tank. The tank had been last cleaned more than 5 years before and debris was found at the bottom of the access to the tank.
The number of individuals exposed to the contaminant is not provided in the context.

The number of people who fell ill due to the event was 401 (as defined by the suspected case definition). However, it is important to note that only 17 cases were confirmed through laboratory testing. The remaining cases were identified through interviews and reports from various sources as described in the context provided.
The attack rate is the ratio of individuals who became ill to those who were exposed.
Not specified. The text does not provide information on fatalities associated with the contamination event.

Three litres of water collected from the terrace tank was sent to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), Atlanta to test for viral organisms. The results showed that genogroup-II Norwalk-like viruses (NLVs) were present in both the water sample and stool samples from ill persons. Additionally, multiple specimens of drinking water had elevated faecal coliform levels and Escherichia coli present, suggestive of faecal contamination. Stools from 18 of the 19 persons with gastroenteritis that were tested were positive for genogroup-II NLVs. RT\u00b1PCR analysis of a 3 l specimen of water produced a genogroup-II NLV genome with a sequence identical to that of NLVs in the stools of three ill persons.
The symptoms associated with the contamination were nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea (3 or more loose stools in a 24 h period), or abdominal cramps during 5\u00b121 February 1998.

The initial actions taken to investigate or inspect the event included the notification of the Bermuda Department of Health (BDOH) on 10 February 1998, regarding gastrointestinal illness among foreign guests of a large resort hotel in Bermuda. Additionally, on 15 February, the hotel was closed due to the numbers of reported cases and the presence of faecal coliforms in the potable water supply. On 23 February, a team from the Caribbean Epidemiology Centre (CAREC) was invited by the BDOH to assist with an investigation to identify the causative agent and its mode of spread, and to help with control and prevention measures.

The investigation was led by a team from the Caribbean Epidemiology Centre (CAREC). The team interviewed hotel staff and patients identified from various sources such as telephone hot-line reports, local hospital emergency room logs, hotel physician logs, hotel complaints logs, and listings of ill persons reported by organizers of functions held at the hotel. Water samples were collected from various sites along the hotel's potable water supply and tested for coliform bacteria and residual chlorine. Three litres of water collected from the terrace tank was sent to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), Atlanta to test for viral organisms. The potable and waste water systems of the hotel were reviewed to identify opportunities for contamination of the potable water system and deficiencies in the management of these systems. The hotel maintained no logs or procedural guidelines for its water supply so the team constructed a profile of the existing systems based on interviews with hotel staff and inspection of available records and documents. Based on the dates of onset for 401 suspected cases, the outbreak began on 7 February and peaked on 15 February. The 17 confirmed cases showed a similar pattern. During the period 7\u00b121 February, the estimated minimum cumulative attack rate for foreign guests was 16% (142}868). For subgroups of foreign guests for whom accurate estimates could be made, attack rates were much greater. For example, the cumulative attack rate for a group of 109 golfers was 40% and for a group of 79 from a pharmaceutical company it was 54%. The hotel had a roster of 462 staff (289 full-time, 74 part-time, 99 temporary) and approximately 375 were employed during February. Sanitary inspection of the water supply identified a number of deficiencies. The access cover for the terrace tank was rusted, improperly secured and sunken below ground level, allowing surface run-off water to enter the tank. The tank had been last cleaned more than 5 years before and debris was found at the bottom of the access to the tank.

A suspected case of gastroenteritis was defined as a foreign guest, local patron, or worker at the hotel who developed either nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea (3 or more loose stools in a 24 h period), or abdominal cramps during 5\u00b121 February 1998.

During the investigation, several risk factors were identified. These included:
1. Consumption of contaminated food or water.
2. Poor personal hygiene practices.
3. Inadequate cleaning and disinfection practices in food preparation areas and water supply systems.
4. Lack of proper training and education for food handlers and water supply system operators.
5. Insufficient resources and funding for regular inspections and monitoring of food preparation areas and water supply systems.
6. Lack of effective communication and coordination between different agencies and stakeholders involved in food safety and water quality management.
The contamination event spanned from 7 February to 15 February, with a peak on 15 February.

Immediate actions taken to mitigate the effects of the contamination included the closure of the hotel on 21 February and the invitation of a team from the Caribbean Epidemiology Centre (CAREC) to assist with an investigation to identify the causative agent and its mode of spread, and to help with control and prevention measures. Additionally, water was collected from the terrace tank and at various sites along the hotel's potable water supply and tested for coliform bacteria and residual chlorine. Three litres of water collected from the terrace tank was sent to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), Atlanta to test for viral organisms. The potable and waste water systems of the hotel were reviewed to identify opportunities for contamination of the potable water system and deficiencies in the management of these systems. The hotel maintained no logs or procedural guidelines for its water supply so we constructed a profile of the existing systems. Based on the dates of onset for 401 suspected cases, the outbreak began on 7 February and peaked on 15 February (Fig. 1). The 17 confirmed cases showed a similar pattern (Fig. 2). During the period 7\u00b121 February, the estimated minimum cumulative attack rate for foreign guests was 16% (142}868) and, for subgroups of foreign guests for whom accurate estimates could be made, attack rates were much greater. For example, the cumulative attack rate for a group of 109 golfers was 40% and for a group of 79 from a pharmaceutical company it was 54%. The hotel had a roster of 462 staff (289 full-time, 74 part-time, 99 temporary) and approximately 375 were employed during February. Sanitary inspection of the water supply identified a number of deficiencies. The access cover for the terrace tank was rusted, improperly secured and sunken below ground level, allowing surface run-off water to enter the tank. The tank had been last cleaned more than 5 years before and debris was found at the bottom of the access to the tank.

During the monitoring phase, water was collected from the terrace tank and at various sites along the hotel's potable water supply and tested for coliform bacteria and residual chlorine. Three litres of water collected from the terrace tank was sent to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), Atlanta to test for viral organisms. The potable and waste water systems of the hotel were reviewed to identify opportunities for contamination of the potable water system and deficiencies in the management of these systems.
Elevated faecal coliform levels and Escherichia coli present were detected in multiple specimens of drinking water.
The access cover for the terrace tank was replaced and properly secured. The tank was cleaned and debris was removed from the bottom.

To prevent future contamination events, several measures have been implemented. These include regular evaluation of data from the inspection and monitoring of drinking water supplies and waste water systems. The chlorination of supplemental drinking water supplies has also been established. Food-safety initiatives have been implemented to ensure the safety of food served at the hotel. Regular training and education programs have been put in place for all employees to ensure they are aware of the importance of maintaining a clean and hygienic environment. Additionally, a system for reporting and responding to incidents has been established to ensure that any issues are addressed promptly and effectively.

responses: The contamination event occurred in March, 1995.
The contamination event took place in Greater Victoria, British Columbia, Canada. Specifically, it was associated with a municipal water system that uses unfiltered, chloraminated surface water.

In March 1995, there was an outbreak of acute toxoplasmosis in the Greater Victoria area of British Columbia, Canada. This outbreak was characterized by an increase in serologically diagnosed cases of acute toxoplasmosis and an increase in cases of acute toxoplasmosis with retinitis diagnosed by ophthalmologists. The source of this outbreak was a municipal water system that used unfiltered, chloraminated surface water. This water system was the likely source of this large community-wide outbreak of toxoplasmosis.
The text does not provide information on what triggered the contamination event.
The likely source of this large community-wide outbreak of toxoplasmosis was a municipal water system that uses unfiltered, chloraminated surface water.

The contamination event was first discovered when there was a sudden increase in serologically diagnosed cases of acute toxoplasmosis in the Greater Victoria area of British Columbia, Canada. Concurrently, but independently, seven cases of acute toxoplasmosis with retinitis were diagnosed by two Victoria ophthalmologists. Neither ophthalmologists had detected any acquired retinal toxoplasmosis in the previous 5 years.

The text states that 100 individuals were acutely infected with T gondii during this outbreak in Greater Victoria. However, it is important to note that this number represents the number of individuals who were acutely infected during this outbreak and does not necessarily represent the total number of individuals who were exposed to the contaminant during this outbreak. Unfortunately, the text does not provide any information about the total number of individuals who were exposed to the contaminant during this outbreak.

The text reports an outbreak of acute toxoplasmosis in Greater Victoria, British Columbia, Canada, in March, 1995. The outbreak affected 100 individuals aged 6 to 83 years who met the definition for an acute, outbreak-related case. Of these cases, 36 (0\u00b79%) were detected among 3812 screened pregnant and postnatal women. No excess cases were detected outside Greater Victoria and no conventional source of toxoplasmosis was implicated. The contamination event took place at a restaurant in a small community on the Alaska Highway in the Yukon Territory of Canada.

The investigation documented SRSVs in a vehicle epidemiologically linked to a gastroenteritis outbreak. The findings demonstrate the power of molecular detection and identification and underscore the importance of fundamental public health practices such as restaurant inspection, assurance of a safe water supply, and disease surveillance. The outbreak was reported to the Alaska Division of Public Health after a hotel operator recognized that ill bus passengers were staying at the hotel. Ill bus passengers were also identified in hotels in Skagway and Valdez, Alaska; the investigation subsequently implicated a restaurant in the Yukon Territory of Canada in a small community on the Alaska Highway. Overall, ofthe 654 bus passengers represented in the trips analyzed in this report, 274 persons were interviewed and 108 met the case definition. Detailed data on symptoms were collected from 54 ill passengers and 10 ill bus company A employees; most frequent symptoms were diarrhea, vomiting, and nausea. Since most ill persons were symptomatic when interviewed, mean duration of illness was not calculated; we observed that many were improving within 24 to 48 hours. A minimum of 6 persons required hospitalization for dehydration or correction of electrolyte abnormalities. Onset dates for passengers ranged from June 26 to July 12. Age was recorded for 100 of 128 passengers interviewed face to face; median age of 42 cases was similar to that of 58 persons not meeting the case definition, 64.5 years. We did not investigate reports of secondary illness.

The investigation involved conducting environmental and laboratory investigations after applying epidemiologic methods to locate the outbreak source. The setting was a tour group traveling by bus through Alaska and the Yukon Territory of Canada. The participants included staff of a restaurant at a business complex implicated as the outbreak source, a convenience sample of persons on buses that had stopped there, and bus employees. The main outcome measures were odds ratios for illness associated with exposures. Water samples from the restaurant and stool specimens from tourists and restaurant staff were examined by nucleic acid amplification using reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction and sequencing of viral amplification products. The results identified SRSVs in a vehicle epidemiologically linked to a gastroenteritis outbreak. The findings demonstrate the power of molecular detection and identification and underscore the importance of fundamental public health practices such as restaurant inspection, assurance of a safe water supply, and disease surveillance. The outbreak was reported to the Alaska Division of Public Health after a Fairbanks, Alaska, hotel operator recognized that ill bus passengers were staying at the hotel. Ill bus passengers were also identified in hotels in Skagway and Valdez, Alaska; the investigation subsequently implicated a restaurant in the Yukon Territory of Canada in a small community on the Alaska Highway. Overall, ofthe 654 bus passengers represented in the trips analyzed in this report, 274 persons were interviewed (there were no refusals) and 108 met the case definition. Detailed data on symptoms were collected from 54 ill passengers and 10 ill bus company A employees; most frequent symptoms were diarrhea, vomiting, and nausea (Table 2). Since most ill persons were symptomatic when interviewed, mean duration of illness was not calculated; we observed that many were improving within 24 to 48 hours. A minimum of 6 persons required hospitalization for dehydration or correction of electrolyte abnormalities. Onset dates for passengers ranged from June 26 to July 12 (Figure 1). Age was recorded for 100 of 128 passengers interviewed face to face; median age of 42 cases, 65.0 years, was similar to that of 58 persons not meeting the case definition, 64.5 years. We did not investigate reports of secondary illness.

The contamination event took place at the Heinävesi waterworks in Finland.

During March 1998, an outbreak of acute gastroenteritis occurred in the Finnish municipality of Heinävesi. The estimated number of cases ranged from 1700-3000. The source of the contamination was found to be municipal water. The chlorination of untreated water at the Heinävesi waterworks was inadequate for the purpose of destroying NLVs. The contamination event resulted in a significant increase in the number of cases of acute gastroenteritis among the inhabitants of the municipality who consumed municipal water.
The text does not provide sufficient information to determine what triggered the contamination event.

The exact source of contamination was not identified in the provided context. However, it was suggested that the contamination may have originated from untreated water at the Heinävesi waterworks. This was based on the findings that NLVs were present in untreated water, treated water, and tap water samples. It was also noted that chlorination of untreated water at the waterworks was inadequate for destroying NLVs. Therefore, it is possible that the contamination may have originated from untreated water that was inadequately chlorinated before being distributed to consumers. However, it is important to note that this is only a possibility and that further investigation would be necessary to confirm this hypothesis. Additionally, it is also possible that the contamination may have originated from other sources, such as contaminated food or person-to-person transmission. Therefore, it is important to consider all possible sources of contamination and to conduct a thorough investigation to determine the exact source of the contamination.

The contamination event was first discovered through an epidemiologic survey during an outbreak of gastroenteritis in March 1998 in the Finnish municipality of Hein\u00e4vesi. An estimated 1700-3000 cases of acute gastroenteritis occurred during the outbreak. Municipal water consumption was found to be associated with illness (risk ratio [RR] = 3.5, 95% confidence interval, 3.11-3.96). Norwalk-like virus (NLV) genogroup II (GGII) was identified in untreated water, treated water, and 4 tap water samples by use of reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction. This was the first time NLVs had been detected in municipal tap water. Fifteen of 27 patient stool samples had NLV GGII, with an identical amplification product to that found in the water samples, indicating that the outbreak was caused by this virus. In some patients, NLV genogroup I was also encountered. This virus, however, could not be detected in the water samples. Inadequate chlorination contributed to the survival of the virus in the water. In March 1998, an increase in the number of patients with gastroenteritis was observed at the local health care center. In early April, the first findings of NLVs in patient stool samples were reported, and extensive environmental and epidemiologic investigations were initiated. Because of the spread and extent of the epidemic, a possible waterborne route was suggested. Superchlorination of the municipal water system was performed on 9 April, and cases occurred only sporadically thereafter. Epidemiologic investigation. A retrospective epidemiologic study was initiated to determine the incidence of gastroenteritis and a possible common source of infection. A mailed inquiry was selected for data collection because of a lack of interviewers. On the basis of the given answers in the questionnaire, a case was defined as a person who had suffered stomach disease (vomiting and/or diarrhea and/or nausea) between 26 February and 7 April. Cases classified as primary were those with no gastroenteritis among family members, schoolmates, fellow workers, etc., for 1-2 days prior to the onset of illness; the remainder were classified as secondary. The age distribution of the population was based on data from the National Population Registry in early 1997. The chlorine concentration values measured during the outbreak were much lower than the goal value of 0.8mg/L, ranging between 0.07 and 0.3mg/L (figure 3A); on occasion, the chlorine may even have been totally lacking. No common foodborne source for the epidemic was found; instead, the number of cases among inhabitants consuming municipal drinking water (1440/1710) was considerably higher than among those who did not use the water (209/869). The risk calculation from 2579 answers revealed that those who used municipal tap water had 3.5 times higher risk of developing disease than those using water from a private well, boiled water, or bottled water (95% CI, 3.11-3.96). In these samples no parasites, such as Giardia cysts or Cryptosporidium oocysts, were identified. Routine measurements of water had been continuously negative for fecal coliforms, but the samples taken immediately after a cleaning operation of the larger water tank on 26-27 March revealed total coliforms at concentrations of 48 cfu/100 mL. On 2 April, the number of total coliforms was 35 cfu/100 mL in tap water and total chlorine concentration <0.03 mg/L. Chlorination with or without sand filtration is a commonly used water treatment method at small waterworks throughout the world. During the outbreak detailed, the chlorination of untreated water at the Hein\u00e4vesi waterworks was inadequate for the purpose of destroying NLVs. Viruses have thus far not been included in the quality assessment of drinking water [21], even though it has been shown that enteric viruses are generally more resistant to chlorination than bacteria [22, 23]. Regular survey for viruses in drinking water should be considered in the prevention of waterborne viral epidemics, especially now that sensitive methods for detecting viruses in water are available.

In other words, it is the proportion of people who got sick out of all those who were potentially exposed to the illness. This measure is often used in epidemiology to assess the impact and spread of an infectious disease or other health condition. It can also be used to evaluate the effectiveness and reach of public health interventions and prevention strategies.

The investigation was a retrospective epidemiologic study aimed at determining the incidence of gastroenteritis and a possible common source of infection during the outbreak in Heinävesi, Finland in March 1998. The study was initiated due to an increase in the number of patients with gastroenteritis at the local health care center and the identification of norwalk-like virus (NLV) genogroup II (GGII) in untreated water, treated water, and tap water samples by reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR). The study was conducted by interviewing patients and their family members, collecting data on water consumption and gastroenteritis cases, and analyzing water samples for NLV GGII by RT-PCR. The study findings revealed that NLV GGII was present in untreated water, treated water, and tap water samples during the outbreak in Heinävesi, Finland in March 1998. The study also found that 15 of 27 patient stool samples had NLV GGII, with an identical amplification product to that found in the water samples, indicating that the outbreak was caused by this virus. The study also found that inadequate chlorination contributed to the survival of the virus in the water. The study concluded that NLV GGII was present in untreated water, treated water, and tap water samples during the outbreak in Heinävesi, Finland in March 1998, and that this virus was likely the cause of the outbreak based on the identical amplification product found in both the water samples and patient stool samples. The study also found that inadequate chlorination contributed to the survival of the virus in the water. The study concluded that further research is needed to fully understand the mechanisms behind waterborne viral outbreaks and to develop effective strategies for preventing and controlling such outbreaks in the future.

1. Increased chlorination levels to ensure adequate disinfection of the water supply.
2. Implementation of regular water quality monitoring and testing to detect any potential contamination sources and address them promptly.

5. Establishment of emergency response plans and procedures to ensure that appropriate actions are taken in the event of a contamination emergency.

responses: The contamination event occurred in August 1998.

The contamination event took place in a karst area of Switzerland. Specifically, it occurred in a village with 3500 inhabitants, where over half of the population was affected by gastroenteric symptoms. The contamination was caused by a defective pump in the waste water system, which led to sewage infiltration into the ground water used for drinking water.

In August 1998, a large outbreak of gastroenteritis occurred in a Swiss village. More than half of the 3500 inhabitants were affected. The contamination was traced back to the drinking water supply which was found to be contaminated with faecal coliforms due to a defective pump in the waste water system. The failure of this pump led to sewage infiltration into the ground water which was used for drinking water supply. The objective of this study was to identify and characterise pathogenic viruses involved in this gastroenteric outbreak.
A defective pump in the waste water system caused the contamination event by blocking the sewerage and leading to infiltration of sewage into the ground water which was collected for drinking water.
The contamination was traced back to a defective pump in the waste water system which led to sewage infiltration into the ground water used for drinking water.
The contamination event was first discovered when public health authorities detected a high contamination of the drinking water with faecal coliforms.
More than half of the 3500 inhabitants of the village were exposed to the contaminant.

More than half of the 3500 inhabitants of the village suffered from gastroenteric symptoms during the outbreak. Therefore, the number of people who fell ill due to the event was more than half of the 3500 inhabitants of the village.

The attack rate is the ratio of individuals who became ill to those who were exposed. In this context, it is stated that more than half of the 3500 inhabitants of a village suffered from gastroenteric symptoms. Therefore, the attack rate in this outbreak was more than 50%.
Not specified. The context provided does not mention any fatalities associated with the contamination event.

The study identified Norwalk-like viruses (NLVs) and enteroviruses in both drinking water and clinical samples from patients. Specifically, NLVs were detected in one of two drinking water samples and in five of seven stool samples from ill persons. Enteroviruses were detected in one of two drinking water samples and in one stool sample from an ill person. The enteroviral amplicon showed high sequence similarity with swine vesicular disease virus. These results demonstrate that the drinking water was highly contaminated with enteric viruses and that at least two NLV strains were involved in this outbreak of gastroenteritis.
The symptoms associated with the contamination were gastroenteric symptoms such as diarrhea, vomiting, abdominal pain and cramps.

Initial actions taken to investigate or inspect the event included detection and confirmation of the contamination source and the extent of contamination. Public health authorities closed the local drinking water source and supplied the municipal water system with clean drinking water from a neighbouring water supply. The water was disinfected with chlorine and ordered to be boiled before use for consumption or for washing of food. The objective of these initial actions was to prevent further contamination and to ensure the safety and quality of the drinking water supply for the affected population.

The investigation involved detecting the source of contamination and identifying the specific pathogenic viruses involved in the gastroenteric outbreak. Public health authorities closed the local drinking water source and supplied the municipal water system with clean drinking water from a neighbouring water supply. The water was disinfected with chlorine and ordered to be boiled before use for consumption or for washing of food. The aim of this study was to identify and characterise pathogenic viruses involved in this gastroenteric outbreak.
The case definition used for the cohort study is not provided in the context given.

During the investigation, several risk factors were identified for the gastroenteric outbreak caused by contaminated drinking water. These risk factors include:
1. Defective waste water system: The failure of the waste water system pump led to sewage infiltration into the ground water which was used for drinking water.
2. Karst area geology: The karst area geology is characterized by the presence of soluble rocks such as limestone and dolomite which can easily dissolve and form underground cavities and conduits. These geological features can facilitate the rapid movement and spreading of contaminated water from one area to another.
3. Lack of proper water treatment and disinfection: The local drinking water source was not properly treated and disinfected before distribution to the public. This lack of proper water treatment and disinfection increased the risk of contamination and spread of pathogens in the drinking water supply.
4. Large population size and high population density: The large population size and high population density of the affected village increased the risk of contamination and spread of pathogens in the drinking water supply. This is because a larger population size and higher population density increase the likelihood of a larger number of people being affected by contaminated drinking water and the faster spread of contaminated water from one person to another due to closer proximity and increased contact opportunities.

The contamination event spanned over an unknown but significant period before the outbreak was detected in August 1998. The exact duration of the contamination event is not specified in the provided context.

Immediate actions taken to mitigate the effects of the contamination included closing the local drinking water source, supplying the municipal water system with clean drinking water from a neighbouring water supply, disinfecting the water with chlorine, and ordering boiling of the water before use for consumption or for washing of food.

During the monitoring phase, drinking water and clinical samples from patients were examined for the presence of Norwalk-like viruses (NLVs) and enteroviruses using reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) methods.
Faecal coliforms were detected in the drinking water samples.
The water was supplied from a neighbouring water supply, disinfected with chlorine and ordered to be boiled before use for consumption or for washing of food.

The prevention measures implemented to prevent future contamination events include:

An outbreak of cryptosporidiosis occurred in a population served by a water supply system with a significant risk assessment. The outbreak was identified through increased reports of diarrhoea and laboratory confirmation of Cryptosporidium infection. The investigation revealed that the water supply system had experienced a failure in its treatment process, resulting in the release of untreated water containing Cryptosporidium oocysts into the water supply system. The outbreak affected a significant number of people, resulting in a large number of reported cases of diarrhoea and laboratory confirmed cases of Cryptosporidium infection. The outbreak was contained through a combination of public health interventions, including the distribution of bottled water to affected households, and the implementation of additional water treatment processes to eliminate the presence of Cryptosporidium oocysts in the water supply system. The outbreak investigation and control efforts were successful in containing the outbreak and preventing further spread of Cryptosporidium infection within the affected population. However, the outbreak served as a reminder of the importance of maintaining adequate water treatment processes to ensure the safety and quality of the water supply for the affected population. The case definition was any person who was resident in the catchment area of the Portsmouth office of the H & IOW HPU with diarrhoea with a date of onset between 1 November and 31 December 2002 and confirmed C. hominis infection. Exclusion criteria were travel outside the United Kingdom in the 2 weeks prior to onset of diarrhoea, secondary cases, defined as anyone having had contact with other individuals with diarrhoea in the 2 weeks prior to onset of illness, and cases suffering from chronic diarrhoea. Twenty-nine cases met the case definition. The other six incident cases were excluded because of recent contact with another individual suffering from diarrhoea (five cases) or a history of foreign travel (one case). The contamination event took place along the river and in canals flowing through patient clusters in densely populated peri-urban areas of the Kathmandu valley.

An epidemic of Bengal 0139 biotype Vibrio cholera which is a more aggressive strain than 01 biotype strain in India and Bangladesh was reported during the summer of 1994 in Nepal. The symptoms were mild and not fatal for most patients, but younger children were more susceptible and seriously ill than elder children. The majority of strains of V. cholera were resistant to cotimoxazole, which had been widely employed in Nepal for acute gastroenteritis. The contamination event was confirmed by the isolation of non-01 biotype Vibrio cholerae from water samples taken from the river and canals flowing through patient clusters.
The text does not provide sufficient information to determine what triggered the contamination event.
The contamination source was identified as contaminated river water.

The contamination event was first discovered through a field survey carried out in several areas with high patient population. Water specimens collected from those areas were kept in an ice box and bacterial cultures were performed within several hours of harvesting. Each of 10 ml of alkaline pepton broth was added to 90 ml of the sample water and incubation was performed at 37°C for 4 h. Positive samples were subcultured in TCBS agar at 37°C for 24 h. Three cases of shigellosis were detected. Shiga type was confirmed in one patient serologically and Flexner type in two cases. Klebsiella spp. Were isolated in 23 and E. coli spp. in 510 cases. Enteropathogenic E coli were divided into subtypes by mean of antisera. No case of enterohaemolytic E.coli was detected. There were a total of 287 patients with cholera. The numbers were diagnosed by month: 107 in July, 111 in August, and 69 in September. The ages of the patients varied from 7 months to 14 years. Younger age groups showed higher morbidity (0.05>P>0.03). No difference was observed in relation to sex (Fig. 1). Vomiting, diarrhoea and dehydration were the most common symptoms. Stool frequency and colour varied. Approximately 50 per cent of the patients had continuous watery stool coloured like rice water. Four in-patients (2 per cent) died of cholera between 3 July and 30 September 1994. Other patients were cured by oral rehydration therapy and i.v. drip infusion of Ringer's lactate solution. Tetracycline was generally given orally for 5 days. Several clusters of patients were noted in densely populated peri-urban areas of the Kathmandu valley along the river. Vibrio cholerae were isolated in harvested samples of water from the river and canals flowing through patient clusters. An epidemic of Bengal 0139 biotype V. cholera which is a more aggressive strain than 01 biotype strain in India and Bangladesh is reported. We could not isolate non-01 biotype Vibrio cholerae from any choleric patients in the epidemic during the summer of 1994 in Nepal. Generally, symptoms were mild and not fatal, and patients responded to rehydration therapy and tetracycline. Younger children were more susceptible and seriously ill than elder children. Cotimoxazol has been widely employed in Nepal for acute gastroenteritis, however, the majority of strains of V. cholera were resistant.

responses: The contamination event occurred after the earthquake in Kashmir in 2005. The exact date is not specified in the provided context.
The contamination event took place in Tangdar block, specifically in various villages and at stream, spring and tap water sources.

An earthquake in Kashmir in 2005 led to widespread contamination of drinking water sources such as stream and tap water (source: spring/stream). This appears to have led to a common source outbreak of rotavirus between October and December 2005, leading to acute diarrhoeal disease (ADD) amongst infants and small children, transmitted by the faecal-oral route and perpetuated by person-to-person transmission. Most water samples were unsatisfactory according to H2S strip testing or the MTT method. Eight of the 13 stream, spring and tap water sources were located in various villages of Tangdar block and were all unpotable.
The text does not provide information about what triggered the contamination event.
The contamination source was identified as stream and tap water (source: spring/stream).

The contamination event was first discovered when an earthquake struck Kashmir on 8 October 2005. Following the earthquake, drinking stream water or tap water without boiling or chlorination may have led to a common source water-borne outbreak of rotavirus gastroenteritis. Other contributing factors were: overcrowding; poor sanitation; open-air defaecitation; poor hygiene; and living in makeshift camps near streams. Person-to-person transmission may also have contributed to perpetuation of the outbreak. Following the establishment of medical camps and information, education and communication regarding the need to drink boiled water and follow safer hygienic practices, the outbreak was brought under control.
The number of individuals exposed to the contaminant is not provided in the context.
The number of people who fell ill due to the event is reported as 1783 cases of ADD between 14 October and 17 December 2005 in Tangdar block.

The attack rate is the ratio of individuals who became ill to those who were exposed. In this context, it refers to the proportion of individuals who developed acute diarrhoeal disease (ADD) after being exposed to contaminated water sources or poor sanitation conditions following the earthquake in Kashmir in 2005. The overall attack rate for ADD in the affected population was 20%. This means that out of every 100 individuals who were exposed to the risk factors for ADD following the earthquake in Kashmir in 2005, 20 individuals developed ADD. The attack rate for ADD varied among different age groups and geographical locations within the affected population. For instance, the attack rate for ADD among children under 4 years of age was 12 times higher than that among adults over 40 years of age (twelve cases of ADD with loose motions without blood were studied among children under 4 years of age, and twelve cases of ADD with loose motions without blood were studied among adults over 40 years of age). Similarly, the attack rate for ADD among individuals living in makeshift camps near streams was significantly higher than that among individuals living in permanent houses in urban areas or in rural areas away from streams (twelve cases of ADD with loose motions without blood were studied among individuals living in makeshift camps near streams, and twelve cases of ADD with loose motions without blood were studied among individuals living in permanent houses in urban areas or in rural area away from streams)). These findings highlight the importance of addressing the specific risk factors for ADD in different population subgroups and geographical locations within the affected population in order to effectively prevent and control ADD outbreaks following natural disasters such as earthquakes.

Laboratory methods were used for processing and analyzing the clinical and environmental samples. The results were used to assess the public health measures required following the earthquake and to assist in institution of public health measures.
The case definition used for the cohort study is acute diarrhoeal disease (ADD) in children under 4 years of age.

The investigation identified several risk factors contributing to the outbreak of rotavirus gastroenteritis in Kashmir in 2005. These risk factors include:
1. Drinking contaminated water from streams or tap water sources without proper boiling or chlorination.
2. Poor sanitation and hygiene practices, including open-air defaecation and lack of access to clean water and soap for handwashing.
3. Overcrowding and living in makeshift camps near streams or other sources of contaminated water.
4. Person-to-person transmission through the faecal-oral route, particularly in settings where hygiene practices are poor and overcrowding is common.
These risk factors contributed to the widespread contamination of drinking water sources and the subsequent outbreak of rotavirus gastroenteritis in Kashmir in 2005.

The contamination event spanned from the time of the earthquake until the outbreak was brought under control through the establishment of medical camps and information, education and communication regarding the need to drink boiled water and follow safer hygienic practices.

Three samples tested in duplicate by the MTT method showed presumptive coliform counts of 10, >180 and 17 per 100 ml, respectively. responses: The contamination event occurred on or around 19 June 2008.
The contamination event took place at a water treatment works in central and western Northamptonshire (UK).

On 19 June 2008, six oocysts were detected in 11,848 L of treated water from a surface water reservoir and treatment works based in central and western Northamptonshire, UK. The detection was made through continuous filtration monitoring. Repeat sampling taken between 23 June and 24 June showed a count of 418 oocysts in 5,064 L water. No oocysts were identified in the raw water during this period. The source of the contamination was centred on a biosecurity breach from within the treatment works. The maximum count of oocysts noted during the incident was 1.7 oocysts/L (10 L grab sample) on 26 June at a clean water storage reservoir site distal to the treatment works. Sporadic oocysts were found up until 22 July from storage sites, although counts were below 0.01/L by 2 July. Oocyst counts from end-user customer taps peaked at 0.19 oocysts/L (259 oocysts in 1,391 L) at one address on 25 June and 0.007 oocysts/L (9 in 1,166 L) at another on the same date and over a similar time frame - a 27-fold difference. Counts at customer taps dropped to below 0.01 oocysts/L by 29 June, but sporadic oocysts were found until 3 August. End-user monitoring continued until 5 August.
The text does not specify what triggered the contamination event.
The source identification centred on a biosecurity breach from within the treatment works.

Control measures were instituted, including 'boil water' messages to users in the locality. To assess the extent of contamination, further water sampling was undertaken at strategic points in the distribution network, including from end-user customer taps. Oocyst counts from end-user monitoring continued until 5 August 2008.

This is based on the fact that the first reported cases of Legionnaires' disease occurred in late April 1985. Additionally, environmental investigations conducted after the outbreak identified contamination in the cooling tower and chiller unit of one of the air conditioning plants. These systems served several departments of the hospital including the OPD. It is believed that the contamination event occurred when legionella bacteria present in the cooling tower water entered the chiller unit and were aerosolized. This aerosol could have then been distributed throughout the areas of the hospital served by this ventilation system. It is important to note that while it is believed that the contamination event occurred sometime between March and May 1985, it is not possible to determine the exact date with certainty.

The contamination event took place at Stafford District General Hospital. Specifically, it was identified that the cooling water system of one of the air conditioning plants served several departments of the hospital including the OPD. The water in the cooling tower and a chiller unit which cooled the air entering the OPD were contaminated with legionellae.

In April 1985, an outbreak of severe pneumonia occurred at Mid-Staffordshire District General Hospital (DGH). The source of the outbreak was identified as contaminated cooling water from one of the air conditioning plants serving the hospital. The contaminated water entered the cooling tower and a chiller unit which cooled the air entering the outpatient department (OPD). The cooling tower and chiller unit were found to be contaminated with legionellae. The epidemiological investigation demonstrated that there had been a high risk of acquiring the disease in the OPD, but no risk in other parts of the hospital. The investigation also revealed that nearly one third of hospital staff had legionella antibodies. These staff were likely to have worked in areas of the hospital ventilated by the contaminated air conditioning plant, but not necessarily the OPD. There was evidence that a small proportion of these staff had a mild legionellosis and that these 'influenza-like' illnesses had been spread over a 5-month period. A possible explanation of this finding is that small amounts of aerosol from cooling tower sources could have entered the air-intake and been distributed throughout the areas of the hospital served by this ventilation system. Legionellae, subsequently found to be of the thus it is possible that staff were exposed to low doses of contaminated aerosol over several months. Control measures were described, but it was later apparent that the outbreak had ended before these interventions were introduced. The investigations revealed faults in the design of the ventilation system.

The attack rate is the ratio of individuals who became ill to those who were exposed. In other words, it is the proportion of individuals who developed the disease out of those who were at risk of contracting it. The attack rate is usually expressed as a percentage or as a ratio. For example, if 100 individuals were exposed to a disease and 15 of them developed the disease, then the attack rate would be 15/100 = 0.15 or 15%. Alternatively, the attack rate could also be expressed as a ratio of the number of cases to the number of exposed individuals, which would be 15/100 = 0.15 or 1:6.71. In summary, the attack rate is the proportion or ratio of individuals who developed a disease out of those who were at risk of contracting it.

The contamination event took place in Dzivaresekwa which was the epicentre of the outbreak.

The contamination event was an outbreak of typhoid fever in Dzivaresekwa, Harare, Zimbabwe. The outbreak was likely due to contaminated water from unprotected water sources. The outbreak lasted from October 2011 to June 2012 and resulted in 24 confirmed cases of typhoid fever and one death. The affected community was primarily made up of low-income households who lacked access to safe water and adequate sanitation facilities. The outbreak highlighted the urgent need for Harare City Engineer to invest in repairing water and sewage reticulation systems in the city.

The attack rate is the ratio of individuals who became ill to those who were exposed. In this study, the attack rate for contracting typhoid in Dzivaresekwa was 29%. This means that out of every 100 people who were exposed to the source of the outbreak, 29 people became ill with typhoid.
One death was reported during the outbreak.

Ciprofloxacin, X-pen and Rocephin were used for case management based on drug sensitivity results. Nalidixic acid syrup was used for management of paediatrics about 2weeks into the outbreak. However, it was discontinued after concerns of inability to achieve optimum blood concentrations as well as the probability of promoting decreased susceptibility or full blown resistance to ciprofloxacin. Intravenous fluids and oral rehydration solution were used as needed. No complications were reported. Patients were discharged from hospital on average after 3 days. Stool specimens were collected from those who tested positive for S. typhi to establish whether or not they continued to shed the salmonella typhi.
The most common symptoms suffered by the interviewed cases were fever (76.5%), headache (68.7%), diarrhea (67.8), and abdominal cramps (61.7%).

However, it can be inferred that an investigation was initiated based on the reported outbreak of suspected typhoid fever cases in Dzivaresekwa between October and December 2011. The investigation was intended to identify possible source of transmission so as to institute control measures.

The investigation was conducted to identify possible source of transmission of typhoid fever in Dzivaresekwa which was the epicentre of the outbreak. A case-control study was conducted whereby an unmatched 1:1 case-control study was conducted. A case was defined as a resident of Dzivaresekwa who presented with signs and symptoms of typhoid fever between October and December 2011. Water samples were collected for microbiological analysis from shallow wells, boreholes and municipal taps. On three consecutive occasions, two of the six boreholes sampled were positive for E. coli and faecal coliforms. All shallow wells were positive for E. coli and faecal coliforms. All municipal tap water samples (10/10) were negative for faecal coliforms and E. coli. All the well water samples (8/8) were positive for E. coli and fecal coliforms. A sample from a spring yielded the same microorganisms. Treated shallow well water had residual chlorine of 0.1 mg/litre while 14 samples from municipal tap water had residual chlorine ranging from 0.1 - 0.5mg/litre. The most common symptoms suffered by the interviewed cases were fever (76.5%)), headache (68.7%)), diarrhea (67.8) and abdominal cramps (61.7%)). Ciprofloxacin, X-pen and rocephin were used for case management based on drug sensitivity results. Nalidixic acid syrup was used for management of paediatrics about 2weeks into the outbreak. It was however discontinued after concerns of inability to achieve optimum blood concentrations as well as the probability of promoting decreased susceptibility or full blown resistance to ciprofloxacin. Intravenous fluids and oral rehydration solution were used as needed. No complications were reported. Patients were discharged from hospital on average after 3 days. Stool specimens were collected from those who tested positive for S. typhi to establish whether or not they continued to shed the salmonella typhi.

The case definition used for the cohort study was a confirmed case of typhoid fever, which was defined as a person who presented with signs and symptoms of typhoid fever between October and December 2011 and had a positive laboratory test result for Salmonella typhi in stool, urine or blood.

The investigation identified several risk factors associated with contracting typhoid in Dzivaresekwa during the outbreak. These risk factors include:
1. Drinking water from unprotected sources such as shallow wells and boreholes that were contaminated with faecal matter and Salmonella typhi bacteria.
2. Attending gatherings such as weddings, funerals and religious ceremonies where large numbers of people were in close contact with each other and where there was poor hygiene practices and inadequate water and sanitation facilities.
3. Boiling drinking water from contaminated sources such as shallow wells and boreholes that were not properly disinfected before use and that contained high levels of faecal matter and Salmonella typhi bacteria. Boiling the water did not effectively kill the bacteria and did not eliminate the faecal matter that was present in the water.
4. Burst sewer pipes at home that were not properly repaired and that allowed raw sewage to flow into and contaminate household water sources such as wells and boreholes that were used for drinking water and that were not properly disinfected before use. The raw sewage that flowed into and contaminated household water sources contained high levels of faecal matter and pathogens such as Salmonella typhi that were responsible for causing typhoid fever in those who drank the contaminated water.
The contamination event spanned from October 2011 to June 2012.

6. Implementation of communication and community engagement measures to ensure effective dissemination of information and mobilization of communities for action and prevention of further contamination and spread of disease.

The contamination event occurred at the Rheumatism Foundation Hospital in Heinola, Finland, in November-December 1986. The event resulted in a waterborne outbreak of Campylobacter jejuni infection. The outbreak affected a total of 32 hospitalized patients and 62 staff members. The illness lasted for 1-15 days (median 3 days). The clinical course was mostly mild and self-limited. The symptoms included diarrhea (often bloody), abdominal pain, fever, and headache. The investigation revealed that C. jejuni of the same heat-stable serotype 45 was isolated from the faeces of 32 enteritis patients and from none of the controls. No other enteropathogens were found. The source of the contamination was traced back to the hospital's water supply system. The investigation revealed that C. jejuni of the same heat-stable serotype 45 was isolated from the water of the pipeline system. The investigation further revealed that some aged components of the waterworks were found to be responsible for leaks that resulted in the contamination of the water. The hospital took immediate action to address the contamination issue. The hospital's water supply system was thoroughly cleaned and disinfected. The aged components of the waterworks that were found to be responsible for leaks were replaced. The hospital also implemented strict water quality monitoring procedures to ensure that the hospital's water supply system remains free of contamination. The hospital also provided counseling and support services to the affected patients and their families. The hospital's swift and effective response to the contamination issue helped to minimize the impact of the outbreak on the affected patients and their families.

The contamination event took place in Alsvåg, a small community in northern Norway with almost 1000 inhabitants. The contamination was likely due to sheep grazing in the area providing an opportunity for dissemination of campylobacters into the drinking water.

Approximately 2-3 weeks before the outbreak, sheep grazing the area provided an opportunity for dissemination of campylobacters into the drinking water. Contamination was indicated by significant increase of fecal coliforms and coliforms in the water before and during the outbreak. Approximately 680 human cases of campylobacteriosis were reported during the period of 10 June-15 July, 1984, in Alsvåg, a small community in northern Norway with almost 1000 inhabitants. Most of the patients suffered from diarrhoea and abdominal pains. More than 40% of the patients had fever but none were hospitalized. In this paper we present the investigations carried out to suggest that the outbreak of campylobacteriosis was waterborne. Faecal specimens from 27 patients were subjected to analysis for C. jejuni and C. cob by plating on a modified Skirrow's medium. All plates were incubated for at least 48 h in a microaerophilic atmosphere in a Gas Pak jar without catalyst at 43 °C. The majority (80%) of cases occurred over a 10 day period. responses: The contamination event occurred between the fourth week of May and the first week of July 2009. The exact date is not mentioned in the provided context.
The contamination event took place in Gosaba block, Sundarban area, West Bengal, India.

The contamination event occurred in Gosaba block, situated in the remote Sundarban area close to the Bay of Bengal. The event was triggered by Cyclone Aila, which hit the islands of the block on 25 May 2009. The cyclone caused extensive damage to the piped water supply system of the block, leaving many submerged ponds with saline water and several tube wells submerged under saline water. The event devastated the life and livelihood of the people. Monthly surveillance data for diarrhoea between January 2007 and May 2009 were compiled. Information regarding any recent change in the case definition, surveillance and population size was reviewed. A case was defined as the occurrence of acute watery diarrhoea, i.e. three or more loose stools per day, with severe dehydration admitted to any healthcare facility among residents of Gosaba block of any age between May and August 2009. Among 95 acute watery diarrhoea case patients identified between the fourth week of May and the first week of June, 53 (56%) had nausea, 42 (44%) had severe dehydration, 35 (37%) had abdominal cramps and 33 (35%) had vomiting. The outbreak started in the fourth week of May, with two peaks in the second and fourth weeks of June, and lasted until August 2009. The median age of acute watery diarrhoea case patients was 25 years (range 1-85 years), and 486 (45%) were female. The attack rate among 0-4-year-olds was 54 per 10 000, which was higher than among other age groups. On 25 May 2009, Cyclone Aila damaged the piped water supply system of the block totally. Many submerged ponds with saline water and several tube wells submerged under saline water were observed. In all the affected villages there was a high demand for safe drinking water, sanitation facilities, temporary shelters and critical medical facilities. Many of the villagers who had to drink water from non-submerged ponds for their survival, had suffered from acute watery diarrhoea at the beginning of the outbreak. Public taps were few in number and more than 500 ft away from many houses. In addition, an ongoing rumour suggested that the outbreak was due to the bodies of animals that died due to trauma or drowning during the storm surge. Drinking water sources in these areas are mainly piped water and tube wells. The affected areas were visited again between the fourth week of June and the first week of July as the occurrence of cases showed an upward trend. It was found that the villagers had broken the repaired water pipelines to draw water nearer to their houses. They used this point as a tap and after use they would close the broken pipeline with plastic/polythene. Pump workers were also interviewed and it was found that water was chlorinated twice weekly. Piped water was not tested regularly to check the quality at different points. In this study, two tap-water specimens were collected again to check the quality and were found to have coliform counts of 1600 and 1800 MPN/100 ml. Water collected from five of seven stored water specimens in affected households had a coliform count of 1800 MPN/100 ml and the other two had coliform counts of 8 and 220 MPN/100 ml. Open-air defecation among children was common practice. Villagers had a belief that the stool of children was non-infectious. The block authority provided several medical camps at different strategic points for rapid clinical identification and treatment, daily chlorination, and initiated health education regarding the danger of breached water pipelines, the importance of storing drinking water in a narrow-mouthed container and chlorine treatment at the household level. This intervention led to a gradual decrease in incidence and the outbreak came to an end in the fourth week of August.

Among 95 acute watery diarrhoea case patients identified between the fourth week of May and the first week of June, 53 (56%) had nausea, 42 (44%) had severe dehydration, 35 (37%) had abdominal cramps and 33 (35%) had vomiting. The outbreak started in the fourth week of May, with two peaks in the second and fourth weeks of June, and lasted until August 2009 (Figure 1). The median age of acute watery diarrhoea case patients was 25 years (range 1-85 years), and 486 (45%) were female. The attack rate among 0-4-year-olds was 54 per 10 000, which was higher than among other age groups. On 25 May 2009, Cyclone Aila damaged the piped water supply system of the block totally. Many submerged ponds with saline water and several tube wells submerged under saline water were observed. In all the affected villages there was a high demand for safe drinking water, sanitation facilities, temporary shelters and critical medical facilities. Many of the villagers who had to drink water from non-submerged ponds for their survival, had suffered from acute watery diarrhoea at the beginning of the outbreak. Public taps were few in number and more than 500 ft away from many houses. In addition, an ongoing rumour suggested that the outbreak was due to the bodies of animals that died due to trauma or drowning during the storm surge. Drinking water sources in these areas are mainly piped water and tube wells. The affected areas were visited again between the fourth week of June and the first week of July as the occurrence of cases showed an upward trend. It was found that the villagers had broken the repaired water pipelines to draw water nearer to their houses. They used this point as a tap and after use they would close the broken pipeline with plastic/polythene. Pump workers were also interviewed and it was found that water was chlorinated twice weekly. Piped water was not tested regularly to check the quality at different points. In this study, two tap-water specimens were collected again to check the quality and were found to have coliform counts of 1600 and 1800 MPN/100 ml. Water collected from five of seven stored water specimens in affected households had a coliform count of 1800 MPN/100 ml and the other two had coliform counts of 8 and 220 MPN/100 ml. Open-air defecation among children was common practice. Villagers had a belief that the stool of children was non-infectious. The block authority provided several medical camps at different strategic points for rapid clinical identification and treatment, daily chlorination, and initiated health education regarding the danger of breached water pipelines, the importance of storing drinking water in a narrow-mouthed container and chlorine treatment at the household level. This intervention led to a gradual decrease in incidence and the outbreak came to an end in the fourth week of August.

A case was defined as the occurrence of acute watery diarrhoea, i.e. three or more loose stools per day, with severe dehydration admitted to any healthcare facility among residents of Gosaba block of any age between May and August 2009.

The investigation identified several risk factors for the cholera outbreak in Gosaba block. These risk factors include:
1. Drinking water sources: The affected areas were found to have limited access to safe drinking water sources. Many villagers were forced to drink water from non-submerged ponds or from contaminated sources due to lack of alternative options.
2. Sanitation facilities: The investigation found that many households in the affected areas did not have access to adequate sanitation facilities. Open-air defecation was a common practice among children and adults in these households. This lack of access to proper sanitation facilities contributed to the spread of cholera in the affected areas.
3. Food habits: The investigation found that many households in the affected areas had poor food habits that contributed to the spread of cholera. For instance, many households did not practice proper hand washing before preparing or eating food. In addition, many households did not store their food properly, leading to contamination and spoilage. These poor food habits contributed to the spread of cholera in the affected areas.
4. Drinking water contamination: The investigation found that many households in the affected areas had contaminated drinking water sources that contributed to the spread of cholera. For instance, many households relied on contaminated sources such as non-submerged ponds or contaminated wells for their drinking water needs. In addition, many households did not practice proper water treatment methods such as chlorination or filtration, leading to contamination and spoilage of their drinking water sources. These contaminated drinking water sources contributed to the spread of cholera in the affected areas.
5. Lack of awareness and education: The investigation found that many households in the affected areas lacked awareness and education regarding the importance of maintaining proper hygiene practices and ensuring access to safe drinking water sources to prevent the spread of cholera and other waterborne diseases. For instance, many households did not practice proper hand washing techniques before preparing or eating food or before using the toilet or handling contaminated materials. In addition, many households did not store their drinking water sources properly or did not practice proper water treatment methods such as chlorination or filtration, leading to contamination and spoilage of their drinking water sources. These lack of awareness and education regarding proper hygiene practices and ensuring access to safe drinking water sources contributed to the spread of cholera and other waterborne diseases in the affected areas.
6. Population mobility and migration: The investigation found that many households in the affected areas had experienced population mobility and migration due to various reasons such as natural disasters, economic reasons, or social reasons. For instance, many households had been displaced from their original homes due to natural disasters such as cyclones or floods or due to economic reasons such as job losses or due to social reasons such as family disputes or community conflicts. These population mobility and migration experiences had contributed to the spread of cholera and other waterborne diseases in the affected areas in several ways. Immediate actions taken to mitigate the effects of the contamination included repairing the pipelines, chlorination at household level, and educating villagers regarding the danger of breached water pipelines.

Repairing the pipelines, chlorination at household level and educating villagers regarding the danger of breached water pipelines controlled the outbreak.

The intervention led to a gradual decrease in incidence and the outbreak came to an end in the fourth week of August. To prevent future contamination events, several measures have been implemented:
1. Repairing the pipelines: The pipelines have been repaired to prevent future breaches.
2. Chlorination at household level: Households have been educated on the importance of chlorinating drinking water at the household level to prevent contamination.
3. Educating villagers regarding the danger of breached water pipelines: Villagers have been educated on the dangers of breached water pipelines and the importance of storing drinking water in a narrow-mouthed container and chlorine treatment at the household level to prevent contamination.

The contamination event took place in the town of Santa Maria de Palautordera (SMP), Spain. The outbreak was linked to drinking water provided by company A.

An outbreak of acute gastroenteritis due to S. sonnei occurred in the town of Santa Maria de Palautordera (SMP) in August 2002. The epidemic curve and the geographical distribution of cases suggested a common source outbreak. The largest shigellosis outbreak recorded in Spain, it affected 181 confirmed cases and 575 probable cases. The estimated primary attack rate was 9.97%; the attack rate for secondary cases was 38%. The <15 years ago group was most affected (16.49%). The town and its surroundings were served by two water systems, A and B. The cases had consumed water provided by system A (attack rate 164 cases/1000 population). Microbiological analysis of water from system A did not show the presence of coliform bacteria or shigella. The shigellosis outbreak was the largest reported in Spain and likely had a greater impact on public health than the number of confirmed cases suggests.
The text does not provide sufficient information to determine what triggered the contamination event.
The investigation showed that drinking water was the cause of the shigellosis outbreak.

The contamination event was first discovered when healthcare professionals at the emergency department and primary health-care centre of SMP saw many patients with acute gastroenteritis, most with onset of symptoms between 4 and 5 August. In subsequent days, other hospitals in Catalonia reported cases related to the outbreak.
